content.title: Which Weapons?
content.introtext:
'We do not wage war as the world does.' 2 Corinthians 10:3 NIV

When we feel under attack or threatened, God wants us to call on Him. He doesn’t want us to call our assailant names or switch over to human manipulation. In the surrounding context of today’s verse, Paul is responding to other preachers’ criticism of him: they’ve been saying he’s a dodgy speaker, only brave on paper. Worse, they seem to have been muddying and distorting the Gospel message Paul’s been so painstakingly preaching. Paul’s response? He doesn’t defend himself, or call the competition names, but points to the power of God to fight for His own Gospel, and defend His faithful speakers whilst He’s at it. What if we told you that the weapons we usually use in arguments did more harm than good? That reflex we have on sniping back, or resorting to a personal jibe when someone criticises us, don’t achieve much but wounded souls on both sides (and unfixed problems). So, what about us? Romans 8:9 NIV says we are ‘…not in the realm of the flesh but are in the realm of the Spirit…’ God wants us close enough to reach for Him as our default, not for human weaponry. ‘...pray in the Spirit on all occasions.’ (Ephesians 6:18 NIV) If our response under threat is to ask God to sort things out, He’ll move behind the scenes, and He’ll equip you when you’re challenged. Today, when anyone talks to you, send up a silent, instant prayer: ‘JESUS!’ in your head. In that moment, ask Him to be with you in that, and every conversation. See what difference it makes.



SoulFood: Esther 4:9-5:3, Heb 4:7-16

content.title: Dead Broke
content.introtext:
'Not My will, but Yours be done.' Luke 22:42 NIV

We’ve all been there; you’re waiting on an answer to prayer, longing for God to step into that tricky situation or relationship. It can get difficult. And we don’t mean ‘can’t get past that level on Candy Crush’ difficult. We mean ‘feeling entirely lost, hurt and broken’ difficult. Real, end–of–the–road broken-ness, the kind of difficult that leaves us with huge questions. Surely God can see you’re not having the best time? Why would He let that happen? Isn’t it about time for a bit of a dramatic movie–style solution, like, giant eagles swooping in to whisk you out of your situation or something? Well, the truth is He can see it, and He is working towards the best possible resolution (it may not include eagles, though, sorry). Psalm 56:8 NLT says, ‘You keep track of all my sorrows. You have collected all my tears in your bottle. You have recorded each one in your book.’ God knows the pain you’re going through. He knows better than anyone how much it hurts to have the people you love turn away from you, He knows the true meaning of sacrifice and He’s massively aware of what it means to suffer loss. But then, why let us go through it all? He’s not oblivious, but He’s also not going to let our pain be pointless. He uses ordinary, broken people all the time in the Bible; just look at the likes of Paul and Peter. So, how’s He going to use your brokenness? We don’t know. Maybe you should ask Him…



SoulFood: 2 Cor 5-8, Matt 21:18-32, Ps 144:9-15, Prov 16:4-7

content.title: It Starts with a Funeral...
content.introtext:
'...I want my share...now...' Luke 15:12 NLT

Ever eaten your cake before your birthday or sneakily opened a Christmas present the day before? Well, how about having a funeral for someone be-fore they’ve died...? In Jesus’ story of the ‘Prodigal Son’, the antihero of the story asked for his dad’s inheritance while his dad was still fully alive and functional. The inheritance was the father’s identity. So, we’re not talking about a bit of cheek here. We’re actually not even talking about something that was downright rude. By saying, ‘I want my share now,’ the son was making a move on his father’s identity, and really saying, ‘I’m prepared to act as if you’re dead.’ The Prodigal Son’s story starts as the son wipes the father from his mind and heart. The world around us has declared God is dead quite a few times and held more than a few ‘funerals’ for Him. Declaring that we don’t need His morality, that science has removed a need for Him as a reason for the universe, that frankly, ‘He was getting in the way’ of our fun… And here’s the kicker, Christian: we reckon you have too. In fact, in every sin—in every moment of ‘just this once…’—we effectively say to Him: ‘I’m prepared to act as if you’re dead.’ Heavy message today? If Christianity is a relationship with Jesus, then sin is more hurtful than rule–breaking. Have some one–to–one time in that relationship today, a Jesus–coffee–catch-up, a walk, whatever, and talk with Him about those moments you acted as if He wasn’t there. Can you decide to put turning your whole life to Him above them?



SoulFood: 2 Cor 9:1-11:15, Matt 21:33-46, Ps 8, Prov 16:8-11

content.title: Wasted Hours Come Back
content.introtext:
'...he wasted everything he had...' Luke 15:13 GWT

Of course the father accepted him back. Really the Prodigal Son story is about Him (the character of God we see through the character of the father) and His forgiveness, even when we treat Him like dirt. It’s a story that continues to be played out today by us all. We try to go it alone for whatever reason and reap the consequence. And God accepts us back. You’d think He’d get tired, but this story is one He’s still happy to write in each of our lives. And then, as Christians, we play it out again. We might be saved, but in our still–sinfilled life, the story of the prodigal son haunts us, echoes through our decisions. We damage others. We still get tangled up in hurtful situations and wound others. We waste friendships, we waste the wealth of our new lives in Christ. You might feel like you’ve put wasted hours into friendships, relationships… even into Church... only to see them burned up, even by your own decisions. But. He. Doesn’t. Waste. Anything. Even though the loss is real, God can make beauty from ashes. He makes good use of all that happens. Not only will He welcome you back, hold you in your self–inflicted hurt, but He will also turn the situation around for good. Are there times that have ended in calamity, or times you’ve left others in pain? These things are hard and people aren’t always around to say sorry. Ask God for the calm and stillness that will help you to trust in Him, and to trust that He will make all things turn out for good (Philippians 4:7 and Isaiah 26:3 style).



SoulFood: 2 Cor 11:16-13:14, Matt 22:1-14, Ps 17, Prov 16:12-15

content.title: To Die For
content.introtext:
'He made us accepted in the Beloved.' Ephesians 1:6 NKJ

Ever sent a friend request on Facebook and regretted it for fear that they’ll hit ignore? ‘It’ll be awkward next time they see me, so they’ll have to accept, right?’ Acceptance can be a tough one. Much of our world today is more about how popular we are and less about who we are. The social media world often measures our worth based on how many Twitter followers we have, how many times our cat meme gets reblogged, or how many likes on our ‘Thanks for the bazillion birthday wishes’ Facebook post. Seeing as Jesus wants you as you are now, not just who you might become some day, you’d think we might want to draw our self–esteem from there. He actually lived out the ‘you’re worth dying for’ concept. Ephesians 1:6 NKJ says, ‘He made us accepted in the Beloved.’ Amazing, so we’re good, yeah? Not quite. God loves us enough to accept us, just as we are. But He loves us too much to leave us just as we are. Titus 2:11–12 NIV says God’s grace ‘teaches us to say “no” to ungodliness and worldly passions, and to live self–controlled, upright and godly lives.’ We can’t ‘earn’ God’s love, but we can let that love impact the way we do life. We can use that amazing acceptance as a motivation, a life–long well of joy that helps us make God–filled choices. So: text Ephesians 1:6 to a Christian friend today. It might be just what they need to hear.



SoulFood: Song 1-4, Matt 22:15-22, Ps 21, Prov 16:16-19

content.title: See Yourself
content.introtext:
'Predestined to be conformed to the image of His Son.' Romans 8:29 NIV

In Elizabethan England, the hot trend in cosmetics was to mix white lead and vinegar together and apply to your face. The problem with this was that it led to lead poisoning. Hygiene wasn’t a big priority either—Queen Elizabeth I reportedly said she had a bath once a month, whether she needed it or not. We’ve luckily moved a long way in cosmetics and sanitation since the 16th century. Every cosmetics brand has its own science lab, and hopefully none of them will be slipping deadly chemicals into your bath or shower gel. Yet despite the sheer volume of stuff out there that promises to make us look good, we all tend to be more insecure than we’d actually like to admit. It’s heart–breaking. Especially when our value just doesn’t change because of what’s on the outside. There’s nothing wrong in (healthily) trying to look good, but not as the be–all and end–all for our self–worth. ‘...because of Christ, we have received an inheritance from God, for He chose us from the beginning, and all things happen just as He decided long ago.’ (Ephesians 1:11 NLT) Jesus loves you, and if you’re a Christian then today’s scripture should remind you of His purpose for you—something He destined you to become before you were even born. That’s really important. And, if you ask, He’ll slowly start to help you see it. When you learn to see yourself as God sees you, confidence soars and purpose roars. It’s what God says that makes the difference. So—if you’re someone who really struggles with how you see yourself, talk to someone. Seriously. Today. Get some support from a trusted member of your church, or family.

content.title: Converter Obscura
content.introtext:
'He will lift you up.' James 4:10 NKJ

Rodney Smith was born in a tent, raised in a travelling community, and never attended a school—not even for one day. Yet, despite the fact his begin-nings weren’t stable or glamorous, God used him to influence the lives of millions around the globe. In 1876, General William Booth (the founder of the Salvation Army) saw potential in this humble man and put him to work as an evangelist. By the time of his death in 1947, he had preached in the United States and Britain for over seventy years. He once said, ‘I didn’t go through your colleges and seminaries. They wouldn’t have me… but I have been to the feet of Jesus where the only true scholarship is learned.’ God loves to lift the humble, the hidden, the obscure: David went from shepherd boy to king; Joseph went from prisoner to prime minister; Abraham went from childless to father of nations. You may feel like a ‘nobody’ right now, but God sees a ‘somebody.’ When the voice within whispers, ‘Who are you? What can you do? You’ll never amount to anything,’ that’s not God. It’s the deceiver, trying to throw you off course. That’s why it’s so important to spend time in prayer, renewing yourself in what God says about you. Mull over these words tonight, before you go to sleep: ‘So humble yourselves under the mighty power of God, and at the right time He will lift you up in honour. Give all your worries and cares to God, for He cares about you.’ (1 Peter 5:6–7 NLT) 



SoulFood: 1 Sam 1-3, Matt 22:34-46, Ps 59:9-17, Prov 16:23-26

content.title: Drained?
content.introtext:
'All things are possible to him who believes.' Mark 9:23 NKJ

Ever been here? You need to make an urgent call but—gah!—you’ve bled your battery dry checking Facebook / listening to music / watching animals make ridiculous noises on YouTube. We can get caught by a similar pothole with our minds, actually. Maybe we prioritise Netflix or gaming to a point where we’ve stayed up late, and ‘don’t have time’ to read the Bible. You were designed to check in with God first—everything else is mere add–ons. While day–to–day stuff on your phone may be a proper part of life, it’s really just a secondary bolt–on to the soul–stuff we get from God. It’s a risky business running your phone on 10% charge, hoping your battery doesn’t die before you make it home. But it’s far riskier running your spirit on 10%—time with God re–awakens our lives, enabling us to inhabit the fullness He promises. When we run on low we’re susceptible to damage. Our thoughts can darken, temptation can brighten. We may turn in on ourselves or on others, nit–picking and fault–finding. Tiredness has a way of bringing out the worst in us, whether it’s physical tiredness or spiritual tiredness. When you feel so drained you can’t lift yourself up, tap into prayer–power; let God lift you up. Repair, restoration and re–commissioning all happen in the quiet place. Instead of seeing prayer as an obligation, see it as a vital power–up. Choose a time to turn your phone off and charge it. While it’s charging, spend time in prayer and worship.



SoulFood: Exod 34:29-35, Mk 9:2-27, 2 Cor 3:7-18

content.title: Different Sinners
content.introtext:
'Accept one another, then, just as Christ accepted you.' Romans 15:7 NIV

The sum of Jesus’ teachings adds up to this: love God, love others. Everything else is a working out of that. Loving God is hard enough—we pick up all kinds of mess and shame along the way, which can warp our picture of Him, if we leave it unattended. But loving others, with their bad attitudes and selfishness and inconsistencies—oh puh–lease! How can you love someone who stabs you in the back and doesn’t seem to think they’ve done anything wrong? How can you like someone who believes stuff you know is wrong? How can you love someone who won’t forgive you but expects you to forgive them? How can you accept someone who lives like they do? We’re all sinners. So maybe the question should be turned around: ‘How can they love someone who lives like you do?’ We are all fallen. We all fail. Our struggles may be different to others, but none of us is perfect. Only Jesus lived a life without sin—and yet He accepts you, despite yours (yes, even your worst and most recent sins). Isn’t the best response to accept others, despite theirs? Jesus said, ‘I give you... freely, so help other people freely.’ (Matthew 10:8 NCV) Live generously with your material stuff, yes, and live generously in spirit with one another. You know that person who you wouldn’t spit on, even if they were on fire? (Be honest.) Ask God to show you how God sees them. Ask God to help you love and accept them. Then, do one encouraging thing for them in the next week.

content.title: End of an Era
content.introtext:
'The Lord will withhold no good thing from those who do what is right.' Psalm 84:11 NLT

Soooo… here we are halfway through 2015. Time to take stock. Feel as though you’ve taken some good steps forward so far? Maybe some of it’s been hard. Know what? Every day is perfect for a fresh start. ‘...His compassions never fail. They are new every morning; great is Your faithfulness.’ (Lamentations 3:22–23 NIV) Messed up? God knows. His arms are still wide open. Been hurt? God heals. Every morning He’s waiting with new refreshment, new strength for the day, new compassion. Yet it’s frustrating when you feel like you’ve done your bit, and... nothing. You’ve sent up prayers but nothing’s changed. Still you can be sure of this: God has heard every prayer. Psalm 56:8 NLT goes as far to say, ‘You keep track of all my sorrows. You have collected all my tears in your bottle. You have recorded each one in your book.’ God feels your pain. He meets you in your pain. But He knows why sometimes He gives a ‘yes’, sometimes a ‘wait’, and other times a ‘no’. ‘The Lord will withhold no good thing from those who do what is right.’ (Psalm 84:11 NLT) God hasn’t overlooked you or preferred someone else. ‘And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love Him, who have been called according to His purpose.’ (Romans 8:28 NIV) Leave the hurts of the first half of the year to past history. And now look forward to the rest of 2015.

content.title: Buddy Up
content.introtext:
'Let him...boast...that he understands and knows Me.' Jeremiah 9:24 NIV

Know what God wants most from you? Not a tally of names you’ve helped convert. Not a list of good deeds you’ve ticked off. Not an in–depth knowl-edge of the Old Testament minor prophets. Nor does He want your songs most, nor your church attendance, nor your good intentions. All of those things are great, but most of all, He wants your friendship. God wants the deepest part of you; the part that defines you: your heart. When everyone is busy doing something for Him, few want to know Him. They’ll talk about Him, write about Him, sing about Him; and yet ignore Him. He wants more than to just be an item on your to–do list or a Sunday obligation or guilty ‘must–pray–more’ feeling in your conscience; He wants you. ‘…pray without ceasing’ (1 Thessalonians 5:17 ESV) means an ongoing dialogue. Friends don’t chat out of obligation; they want to share life together. God wants to share your life; to be right in the centre of involvement, and to share Himself with you: ‘The Lord confides in those who fear Him; He makes His covenant known to them.’ (Psalm 25:14 NIV) Will you get to know Him better by the end of this year? What can you do to help yourself speak and listen to God? Will a journal help? A regular prayer time? A Bible commentary? Make a commitment today, to something of that sort, and write your commitment on paper to remind you.

content.title: The Everyday You Can't See (1)
content.introtext:
'God and... the word of His grace... can build you up and give you an inheritance.' Acts 20:32 NIV

Right. Story time: ‘There are these two young fish swimming along and they meet an older fish swimming the other way, who nods at them and says, “Morning, boys. How’s the water?” And one young fish looks over at the other and goes: “What in the seven seas is water?”’ A similar story was told in a graduation speech by a guy called DF Wallace, who then went on to make his point: that the normal, the everyday, the cli-ché bits of our lives (even clichéd story about fish) can have colossal value that we skip over because we know them so well. Sometimes we have to defend the value of the totally obvious to ourselves. How much more so with God’s grace—the everyday truth of our lives that we can’t always see? God’s grace simply means God giving us more of Him-self than we have any right to. For our day’s work. For the work of talking to other people about Jesus. For our hearts and their emotional well–being. For the people around us. For our healing. For their healing. God will always give us more of Himself than we hope or deserve. He wants to ‘build you up and give you an inheritance.’ We forget this. The worship songs get over–learned and the sermons get stale unless we remind ourselves, even daily. You are not just a spring of God’s grace that pops up in a desert—you’re part of God’s great river of grace, rushing through history, carrying every believer. He’s our water. And He wants to flow through us.



SoulFood: 1 Sam 14-15, Matt 24:1-14, Ps 102:1-11, Prov 17:4-6

content.title: The Everyday You Can't See (2)
content.introtext:
'God and... the word of His grace... can build you up and give you an inheritance.' Acts 20:32 NIV

Alrighty, then. Inheritance, me hearties. Rolling in gold dubloons as diamonds tinkle down the marble steps of our multi–floored mansions. Sorry! Let that idea be marooned on a desert island while we look at what Jesus had to say about our inheritance. ‘In My Father’s house are many rooms. If it were not so, would I have told you that I go to prepare a place for you? And if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again and will take you to Myself, that where I am you may be also.’ (John 14:1–3 ESV) In Jesus’ time, guests would be ‘received’ in a room by their host. But if there were too many guests, and not enough rooms, the guests would be turned away and the host would never get around to welcoming them. Jesus’ words in the verses above are a great comfort—they are often spoken at funerals and deathbeds, and not without reason. They’re our inheri-tance as Christians. Simply: ‘where I (God) am, you will be.’ You won’t be turned away and He won’t have too little time to get round to you. It should build you up today, too. God’s warm welcome is part of the everyday that you can’t always see. This is the gift passed down to you from our Father—you are never alone, never abandoned even in a seeming absence. Your hospitality is part of how other people see God’s welcome. Welcome someone into your home and make them a meal—preferably someone you don’t know greatly (but trust to invite over!) If you don’t live by yourself, spend some time planning how you might make it happen.



SoulFood: 1 Sam 16-17, Matt 24:15-25, Ps 102:12-17, Prov 17:7-10

content.title: God Ltd?
content.introtext:
'He couldn't do any miracles among them...And He was amazed at their unbelief.' Mark 6:5-6 NLT

Sometimes, God does what’s best for us, despite our lack of faith (and praise Him for intervening, regardless!) But, most times He also wants to involve us. He wants to work in and through us to bring His kingdom to earth. Great stuff and a MASSIVE privilege. Except for the flipside… This means there are times when He seems to answer prayer in a manner directly related to our level of faith. Our almighty God, our universe–creating King–of–Heaven sometimes limits Himself, deliberately. When we’re living out of little faith, or even unbelief, God may re-strict Himself from doing everything He could do. Jesus has no trouble healing crowds, multiplying packed lunches, and raising the dead in front of masses who were open to letting Him do His thing. Yet to a group who knew Him from when He was growing up—‘Isn’t this the carpenter? Isn’t this Mary’s son and the brother of James, Joseph, Judas and Simon?’—who ‘took offence at Him’ (Mark 6:3 NIV), Jesus ‘could not do any miracles there, except lay His hands on a few sick people and heal them.’ (Mark 6:5 NIV) What? Jesus couldn’t do something? Huh? Doesn’t sound like the Jesus we know, does it? But it shows the importance of the part God wants us to play—being open to Him, to working with Him to bring healing, and bring His Kingdom. It matters to God that we’re part of His Kingdom–bringing plan. Today, make a hole in your plans to read Mark 1–6 in your Bible. As you read, challenge yourself: am I open to God moving like this in my life?



SoulFood: 1 Sam 18:1-20:29, Matt 24:26-35, Ps 102:18-28, Prov 17:11-14

content.title: And It Came To Pass
content.introtext:
'You will forget your trouble...as water gone by.' Job 11:16 NCV

These are the times God works on our character and faith. There’s nothing like a long wait to work on our patience. Or overwhelming odds to stretch our faith. Even when it feels never–ending, ‘You will forget your misery; it will be like water flowing away.’ (Job 11:16 ESV) Forgetting doesn’t mean losing a block of memory. It means reaching the point where the memory is free of pain, just as poison is pulled from a snake bite. As healing begins, the mind’s continual replay of the event reduces and the memory becomes like ‘water gone by’. And so the King James Version has a phrase, often used, which is loaded with meaning: ‘And it came to pass.’ It speaks of a profound truth: life doesn’t stand still. There will always be challenges, but no matter how bad things look, the phrase is, ‘It came to pass’, not ‘It came to stay’. There will be times when your life feels like a rollercoaster car reeling off the tracks. But there’s good news: we can submit our troubles under God’s authority, and they will pass. Kristin Armstrong says: ‘When someone died in Old Testament times, those...in mourning marked their faces with ashes. They allotted a specified sea-son, after which they scrubbed up and moved on... [But] we’re so busy hiding, we’re buried under ashes on the inside. God will call us to arise and shine when our light has come (Isaiah 60:1). Ask Him to set your time limit, and be ready to wash your face.’ Then, whatever your grief is—over the death of a person or a relationship—move on.



SoulFood: Exodus 20:1-17, Matt 5:1-12

content.title: Dog Tired
content.introtext:
'God...told His people..."Let the weary rest."' Isaiah 28:12 NLT

It’s not like Elijah’s prayer life has died, nor has he committed some terrible sin. Far from it—he’s been on the frontline of God’s purpose. His faith is bold and exemplary. It’s just that he’s tired. Exhausted, in fact. He’s been running from one spiritual battle to another and now his body is fatigued. His mind is drained, his spirit worn out. When you’ve been running on adrenalin your body and mind eventually have to play ‘catch up’. For Elijah, there’s no exclusive spa to recuperate in. And so, after defeating hundreds of prophets of the bloodthirsty god Baal, he runs away, crawls under a tree in the hot sun and asks to die. (1 Kings 19:4) A bit dramatic? When we’re bone weary, our minds can lose perspective completely. At times like this, we need to stop. Completely. Elijah crawls to a quiet place and bares his soul. In the quiet place he finds God. And you can too. ‘Jesus said... “Come to Me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. ...I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls... My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”’ (Matthew 11:25–30 NIV) What’s all that about, then? If you’re feeling burned out, your ability to appreciate life and make the most of opportunities will seem to fade. Does that resonate? Come to God before you get worn down completely. Take yourself to a quiet place and read about Elijah’s fatigue in 1 Kings 19. Follow it up with a time of soul–baring prayer.

content.title: Totally Tired
content.introtext:
'Be still, and know that I am God.' Psalm 46:10 NIV

Athletes train to excel—pushing the limits of what their bodies can usually handle. Yet one twinge of a hamstring and they’re on red alert. Not stopping to heal means that they’ll face greater damage down the line. Psalm 46:10 is our warning for spiritual hamstring tweaks: ‘Be still, and know that I am God.’ The temptation is to do more or do it faster; this is the ‘distraction’ deceit—it keeps us going for the time being, but somewhere down the track we are going to pull up in pain. Jesus never said, ‘Keep going, it’s like a stitch, eventually you’ll run it off.’ No, He said, ‘Come to Me, all of you who are weary and carry heavy burdens, and I will give you rest.’ (Matthew 11:28 NLT) If you think you can take it into your own hands and recharge yourself, think again. ‘Jesus said, “I am the Vine; you are the branches. Those who remain in Me, and I in them, will produce much fruit. For apart from Me you can do nothing.”’ (John 15:5 NLT) If we want to do anything well, we need to prioritise time with the Father, Son and Spirit. Why? It’ll not only help you to be more effective as a well–rested worker, but also help you to step outside of the thick of life to get a better perspective and appreciate all you have. Matthew 6:33 NIV says: ‘...seek first His Kingdom.’ When you ‘come near to God…He will come near to you.’ (James 4:8 NIV) Fit in a rest period today to recoup your strength. Even if it’s just five minutes. Say: ‘God, I am seeking You and Your Kingdom first,’ then sit for a while in quiet and stillness.

content.title: Mind Your Mind
content.introtext:
'Above all else, guard your heart.' Proverbs 4:23 NIV

Let’s hit the ground running from yesterday’s reading: some thoughts are easier to keep out than others. We all need help in different areas. But here’s something we can all agree on: doubt can feel like a killer, right? Just as we’re starting to keep our minds close to God, we feel the carpet sliding out from under our feet. Did. You. Know. That God’s hold on us isn’t loosened every time we have a back–and–forth with ourselves over His love for us? Or even His existence. Clearly it’s good to have a sense of security but, during those times/nights/philosophy lessons where we’re not so sure, He’s right there. How does this link to today’s verse? Like this: God can and does guard us even when we don’t feel safe ourselves. Best way to deplete the enemy’s chance of shoulder–barging us off course? Don’t rely on yourself to keep your faith; being saved by faith is a ‘gift of God.’ (Ephesians 2:8 NIV) When we’re going through times of doubt, it’s probably best not to wholly rely on ourselves (or even other well–meaning folk) reassuring us that God is with us. Simply ask God for faith in Him. And, just as brilliantly, God has ‘bought at a price’ (1 Corinthians 6:20 NKJ) the rights to every part of us: including our minds. Present it back to Him, and He’ll take the lead. Be honest with God—what do you struggle to believe? Pray about it, ask Him to settle your mind, then find a wiser–older Christian to discuss those things with at some point this week.

content.title: Mind Yourself
content.introtext:
'For we are God's handiwork.' Ephesians 2:10 NIV

Recap: your mind matters. In case you hadn’t picked up on it by now, it’s a serious business, this whole does–God–have–the–keys–to–my–mind chat. And, truth be told, we need to be aware there’s a spiritual war going on around (and within) us. Sometimes, it can feel like we’re torn in two directions: to stay faithful to God’s thoughts on us, or to leave room for doubts. Know what we mean? We’ve all been there at some points, whether it’s gos-sip/lust/anger/whatever. To add to the list, there’s an especially damaging item: self–negativity. Making mistakes can result in pointing a steady blame–finger at ourselves. And in lots of cases, it stays there. Most of us have experienced it in some way; if you’ve been on the receiving end of your internal blame–voice, rational or not, it’s not a good idea. Why? Jesus is all about peace. We have to let God clear the path for us to know we’ve been forgiven. Jesus is keen for us to know peace, and not ‘as the world gives.’ (John 14:27 NIV) How do we let that forgiven–and–free peace in (especially when we’ve settled into a negative pattern of thought toward ourselves)? It’s a process of turning back. Most likely not an overnight one, but a process that takes long enough to learn how God sees us as ‘handiwork’, completely covered by Him. The ‘renewing of your mind’ (Romans 12:2 NIV) is a process that only God can work in us. Have a time of prayer right now, asking God not only to renew your internal voice but to settle only the peace Christ can bring in you.

content.title: Work. Hard.
content.introtext:
'Hard work brings a profit.' Proverbs 14:23 NIV

Some of the Proverbs seem like they state the obvious. To paraphrase a few: laziness is bad, wisdom is good, lust isn’t a great idea. Today’s verse seems to be no exception: working hard does have its rewards. But are we missing something if we gloss over it? First off, why are we encouraged to work? Didn’t God’s original plan include us idling about in Eden all day, before the Fall happened? Genesis 2:15 tells us that God put Adam to work pretty much straight away, taking care of the whole Garden—hardly a minor responsibility. But then we jump back even further and we see that God Himself sets the pace for a hard–working attitude in the first chapter of the Bible: six days of work, one day of rest. If we’re made in His image, it follows that we’re also designed with a strong work ethic in mind. So what’s our work for? And why should we care about a profit? Colossians 3:23 says, ‘Work willingly at whatever you do, as though you were working for the Lord and not for people.’ Why? Because, the next verse says, your reward will come from Him. The profit might not look like a whopping annual bonus or a holiday home on a Barrier Reef island. More than likely it’ll last a little longer, satisfy a lot deeper, and benefit not only you but those around you. What task today are you not looking forward to? (Either because it’s hard, or boring… both can be daunting). Decide that you’ll ‘Pray Continually’ through it today, that God would give you new vision and passion to work for Him.

content.title: Life as an Open Book
content.introtext:
'I have finished the work You gave Me.' John 17:4 GNT

Ever feel like your life is a constant attempt to suppress a growing to–do list? No specific task, but a hazy mixture of work/study/church/you–name–it commitments swim around your head (especially when you’re trying to sleep?) Without wanting to sound too much like a self–help thing: sometimes, less is more. Yup. Jesus sets the best example of this: ‘He departed again to the mountain by Himself alone.’ (John 6:15 NKJ) Hmmm: ‘Again’. Flicking through the Gospels, it becomes apparent that Jesus is busier than any of us. But ‘again’, He’s trekking back up the mountainside to simply hit pause. Why, then? Well, rather than panicking about the sheer number of people desperate for His attention, Jesus left every detail of His life open to His Father’s will. He left the book of His life open for His Father to write. In John 17, Jesus was coming toward the end of His time with the disciples. He says this: ‘I have brought You glory on earth by finishing the work You gave Me to do.’ (John 17:4 NIV) That’s all that matters. When we feel like there are a thousand different voices pulling us in different directions, we need to take a leaf out of Jesus’ book and make sure God’s voice is the loudest. To keep a focus on what really matters, some voices/responsibilities might need to quieten down. And others will need to go. Jot down all of your responsibilities, whether they’re weekly/monthly/daily. Bring them to God in prayer. What might He want you to get stuck into more, and which ones might need to step aside? 



SoulFood: Ezek 27:25-30:26, Matt 18:10-20, Ps 80:1-11, Prov 15:11-14

content.title: Make God Known
content.introtext:
'I must be about My Father's business.' Luke 2:49 NKJ

It’s really, really easy to slip into claiming the fame/honour/glory that’s meant for God for ourselves. It’s not always a conscious effort. In fact, the most dangerous can be the little thoughts that find their way into our actions: ‘Saying these wise words will make me seem like more mature than you’ or ‘Giving this time will make me look like a good Christian in (insert boss or friend’s name) eyes’… Instead of showing God off, we’re throwing fertiliser on our own pride. So, what to do? As Christians, Jesus has paid the price for our freedom, so we’re His. In Galatians 2:20 NIV, Paul goes as far to say that ‘I no longer live, but Christ lives in me.’ As God’s representatives (or ‘ambassadors’, 2 Corinthians 5:20) on earth, that’s far more motivation to reflect praise back at Him (or, where applicable, avoid creating situations that weren’t meant for His praise.)

Let’s make sure people are getting a glimpse of God in us, not just… us. Jesus had this nailed down from an early age. At twelve years old, He said, ‘I must be about My Father’s business.’ (Luke 2:49 KJV) Sounds fairly posh, but essentially He didn’t come to this world to do anything but make God known. And likewise, our work, play, study, you–name–it, is all His. Even our ‘work’–times can be used for God. No excuses. Wherever you are, what can you make a habit of doing that will help others see God in you?



SoulFood: Ezek 31-33, Matt 18:21-35, Ps 80:12-19, Prov 15:15-17

content.title: Fight, Fight For Your Line
content.introtext:
'All of you together are the temple.' 1 Corinthians 3:16 NLT

Back in the vintage days, the Romans had some sweet battle tactics. Each soldier’s shield had a hook to attach it to the next guy’s. You move, they move. Like it or not, everyone fought with, and for, their entire line. Church? That’s a similar deal. Paul made a point of getting us to share our lives with our ‘fellow workers’ (Romans 16:3 NKJ). Why should we look out for people that we might have only met in the Sunday coffee area once or twice, then? Look back to today’s verse. The Church, is where God dwells. We reckon engaging with a couple of things will strengthen our relationships with/ increase our engagement with the Church. Tell people what things you like about them. Simple stuff. God–honouring things. Just tell them.

1 Thessalonians 5:11 ESV says ‘Therefore encourage one another and build one another up…’ We think it’s worth doing. Asking God to bless people. Ever had a spontaneous prayer session? The ones where you’re so keen to see God–breathed change that you didn’t need an organised meeting or conference to seek God together? Brilliant. Now do it again. And, here’s some extra news: God is always ‘near to all who call on Him.’ (Psalm 145:18 ESV) He listens. Do you struggle to think of a way to un–awkwardly approach all of those people and have a simple interaction? Pick one positive thing out about someone you know. Go tell ’em.

content.title: Mind your Thoughts
content.introtext:
'...take captive every thought to make it obedient to Christ.' 2 Corinthians 10:5 NIV

Your mind’s a pretty big door into your life. How you think about God/parents/friends/anyone, and what you do about them, is rooted in what you let in and out of your mind. What else? Well, it’s a conscious battle to keep ourselves in check; to let God always have the first and last words (and everything in between) in our internal conversations. Paul writes this: ‘take captive every thought to make it obedient to Christ.’ (2 Corinthians 10:5 NIV)

So… this means that when you’re tempted by negativity, it’s not wise to let it run its course (back–chat a little, or let that not–quite–appropriate lustful thought stick about) and then put it behind you before it affects your Christian life. You might think, ‘What’s the harm?’ Well, actually, the harm is all over it. In Matthew 5:27–30, Jesus explains that even teeny–tiny lustful thoughts are no different to adultery. Just before that in Matthew 5:21–26, He mentions that hating someone is effectively murder.

Leaving small thoughts free to linger is dangerous because of where they are heading... far away from God. Soooo. Stop thinking altogether? …Not that either. When you’re spending time with God, you’ll get to know what He does and doesn’t enjoy. And so, when we find ourselves slipping into thoughts that don’t match His will, we have to ask ‘is this what God wants for me?’ By doing that, we’re taking it captive. Thoughts might find their way in, but when they’re met with Jesus, they have to bow to Him.

Today, bow every time you catch yourself thinking something Jesus wouldn’t and hand the thought to Him.



SoulFood: Ezek 34-36, Matt 19:1-14, Ps 73:1-16, Prov 15:18-21

content.title: Dating Non-Christians
content.introtext:
'They will be won over by observing your...lives.' 1 Peter 3:1-2 NLT

Not without controversy. Is it ok to get into a relationship with someone who doesn’t know Jesus? The Bible’s a good place to start, but unfortunately, different people read the relevant verses differently. ‘A wife is bound to her husband as long as he lives. But if her husband dies, she is free to be mar-ried to whom she wishes, only in the Lord.’ (1 Corinthians 7:39 ESV) Does the new husband have to be a Christian? Or does ‘in the Lord’ mean that the marriage itself is to be a God–honouring one? But: how can you possibly honour God with a marriage that doesn’t put Him at the centre of it? Other verses, about being ‘unequally yoked together’ (2 Corinthians 6:14 KJV) are also brought up to help work it out... but also questioned. Confusing. Practically speaking, it’s not easy. An old preacher put it bluntly: ‘Any time a child of God marries a child of the devil, they’re going to have trouble with their father–in–law.’ Any relationship without the foundation of both people trusting in God will run into tension whenever ‘trusting God for money/the future/guidance’ comes up. But that in itself doesn’t mean that God forbids them. It probably comes down to a question: ‘Is this relationship leading me towards God, and His things (going to church, reading your Bible, prayer)?’ Relationship review. Are your relationships leading you towards, or away from God? Sidenote time: If you’re already married to someone who doesn’t share your beliefs, this is NOT a call to divorce (see 1 Corinthians 7:12–14). If however your relationships are leading you away from God, what can you change today, to sort that out?



SoulFood: Ezek 10-13, Matt 15:29-39, Ps 129, Prov 14:25-28

content.title: Love vs Desire
content.introtext:
'Many waters cannot quench love.' Song of Solomon 8:7 NIV

A tricky part of any romantic relationship (and some awkward friendships...) is the confusion between love and desire. Love is the act of will to make space for the other person, to give out, to help. Desire is the wish to consume, to take in, to look out for the next meal. Sure, they can overlap—it’s fine, for example, to want a marriageable partner for yourself if you’re unmarried—but they often feel like a pull in opposite directions. It’s hard because desire can come as a rush of feeling. But without love, desire turns into sheer animal want—it increases while the pleasure it seeks out decreases. And as it grows, so CS Lewis said in The Screwtape Letters, ‘the sooner it must eat up all the innocent sources of pleasure and pass on to those God forbids.’ Love—that willpower to be responsive to each other’s needs, to put aside our own selfishness in order to serve the other, that quick forgiveness and slow remembrance of wrongs—sets things straight. It gives desire the right scaffolding to hang from: seeking the other person’s best before your own. When it’s the backbone, nothing can break that relationship. It outlives desire, carrying on wanting and working for the other person’s best when romantic love passes. (And, y’know, other loves too—friendships live and die on these same principles.) Ok, so this might be a touch English Lit, but Shakespeare’s sonnet number 116 expresses today’s ideas well. Reflect on this: ‘Love is not love which alters when it alteration finds.’ Which is just a different way of saying what Paul said in 1 Corinthians 13:6–8 NIV, ‘Love... always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres. Love never fails.’ 



SoulFood: Ezek 14:1-16:52, Matt 16:1-12, Ps 1, Prov 14:29-32

content.title: No Straight Roads
content.introtext:
'...Nor are your ways My ways.' Isaiah 55:8 NKJ

‘The Lord works in mysterious ways’ is not just a cop–out used when Christians are confronted with difficult questions. Sure it has been used like that when people don’t know what else to say, but there’s still truth in it. We don’t have all the answers or know God’s thoughts. Moses didn’t either. He was told by God he’d lead the Israelites out of slavery. Great; he’d be a hero then. He’d be God’s mouthpiece and convince Pharaoh to free the slaves and life would be grand. Is this what happens? Nope. He speaks to Pharaoh and lands the Israelites in worse trouble. But then he frees them… and, well, the Red Sea episode was definitely not how he expected his prayers to be answered. God doesn’t give up on His plans for us when they seem to hit a roadblock. Most of the time you’ll find His plans aren’t off track. Our expectations are. Sometimes we think our lives are so mundane or so off–course that it can’t be what God had planned. Feel like that? You’re not the only one. Seriously, scan the Bible, there are loads of people who’ve felt it. But God doesn’t miss things. When Joseph was sold and imprisoned and his life seemed out of control, God was at work. When Daniel was taken as a captive to Babylon and his life seemed out of control, God was at work. When Mary was told she’d have a baby who would be born to save the world and her life seemed out of control, God was at work. So we’d say trust Him, whether that’s through boredom, or even through pain.



SoulFood: Gen 1:1-2:3, John 1:1-18

content.title: Reboot
content.introtext:
'Go in the strength you have...Am I not sending you?' Judges 6:14 NIV

Gideon is the ultimate reluctant hero; timid, indecisive, full of doubts. Whereas the modern Hollywood action hero shoots first and then thinks later, Gideon puts out a woollen fleece and goes to sleep. Getting the exact answer he asked God for (dew on the fleece with dry ground around about it), he hesitates and asks for the reverse. (Judges 6:36–40) Although Gideon was plagued with self–doubt and hesitancy, his story is one of a massive win. Gideon teaches us that God’s idea of wimps and warriors is anti–Hollywood. Unlike the movie action hero, Gideon had no previous secret service training. He had no training at all, in fact. He wasn’t a seasoned fighter—the only thing he had going for him was God. And what more do you need? Don’t let the odds scare you. Don’t even let reason and logic shout you down. Don’t be intimidated by the size of the job—you have God. ‘With God’s power working in us, God can do much, much more than anything we can ask or imagine.’ (Ephesians 3:20 NCV) Only one opinion matters—God’s. And He told Gideon, ‘Go in the strength you have and save Israel…Am I not sending you?’ (Judges 6:14 NIV) The strength of the Sender, not the weaknesses of the sent, is what saves the day. Read more about the adventures of Gideon in the book of Judges. See what tips you can pick up from how Gideon learned to deal with his uncertainties.



SoulFood: Ezek 16:53-19:14, Matt 16:13-28, Ps 48, Prov 14:33-35

content.title: Sale! Sale! Sale!
content.introtext:
'Where your treasure is... there your heart will be also.' Matthew 6:21 NIV

What would Jesus think about the absolute retail madness that ensues leading up to Christmas and at the Boxing Day sales or as the end of the financial year approaches? Well, there’s nothing in the Gospels about maxing your credit card on ‘buy 1, get 1 free’ department store deals, but there’s plenty in there on the state of our hearts. Luke 18 tells the tale of Jesus and the rich young ruler. This guy has the lot—but the lot isn’t enough. And so he asks Jesus for the secret of eternal life. Jesus tells him: ‘Sell all you have and give the money to the poor, and you will have riches in Heaven; then come and follow Me.’ (Luke 18:22 GNT) This story reminds us that wealth, power, reputation, and even human desire cannot bring us spiritual salvation (Luke 18:27), it’s only possible by God’s free gift of grace through Christ. Jesus does care about our needs, but he’s primarily interested in the condition of our hearts. So, we need to assess those hearts. Would we give Him all? Would we be prepared to sell everything? Will we give Him our ambitions? Instead of fo-cussing our tunnel–vision on building a career, will we seek to (without glory, without salary) to build His Kingdom? Will we give Him all of our lives, not just our Sunday mornings? Jesus said, ‘Where your treasure is…there your heart will be also.’ Your ‘treasure’ can be material stuff, relationships, a career, an identity, or even comfort. Where’s Jesus in your list of priorities? Re–shuffle this list in order of priority: career, relationship, free–time, church, education, money, recognition, friends, prayer time, food, hobbies, holiday, Bible reading, family, ambition, Jesus. Be honest: what needs to change?

content.title: Shake It Up
content.introtext:
'I consider everything a loss because of the surpassing worth of knowing Christ.' Philippians 3:8 NIV

Paul was the super–rigorous, righteously religious poster–boy of the Jewish world. He ticked all of the traditional holiness achievements, and had an impeccable Jewish family bloodline to boot. Then he met Jesus. And he realised that his achievements, his acclaim, his heritage all meant diddly squat compared to the worth that Jesus gave to Him for free. It’s the same for you. None of your world–approved achievements, your church–elder father and grandfather, or your killer Bible knowledge, count to-wards any of your worth once you have God. And, on the beautifully providential flipside, none of your failures, your actually–not–so–together family, or the fact that you don’t know where the book of Zephaniah is, mean that you’re worth any less. Because you have been given the gift of Jesus, you share in His worth, His beauty, and His power. You are precious, and are now able to be made righteous, simply by believing in Christ alone. And that’s flipping huge. Attitude–flipping, perspective–flipping, behaviour–flipping huge! Whatever the world (and even, sometimes, the Church) would consider a massive achievement, or a massive failure, doesn’t make any difference to your God–given ability or value. The only One who does that is Jesus. And, regardless of your worldly situation, He makes you capable of shaking the globe, of changing lives, and of being a part of love–filled revolutions in His name. So go get ’em. Change the world. We’re serious. Believe what you’ve just read above, and live it out. Start today by taking one step, no matter how small, towards changing something that hurts your heart about this world. Trust the power, and responsibility, that Jesus has given to you.



SoulFood: Ezek 22-23, Matt 17:14-27, Ps 132:11-18, Prov 15:5-7

content.title: Real-ationships (1)
content.introtext:
'Unless the Lord builds the house...' Psalm 127:1 NKJ

Maybe you’ll marry, maybe you won’t. Maybe the idea fills you with joy and sepia–filter dreams of dresses and confetti, maybe it fills you with deep un-ease at sharing everything (and everything you are) with another person, for the rest of your life. Maybe you’ve no idea what we’re on about, and would rather go and run around outside. But most of us have experienced glancing over at someone attractive and wanting to spend a bit of ‘quality time’ with them… So what about this ‘Marriage’ thing then? Shall we have a chat? Get comfy. The first and, by now pretty obvious, bit of wisdom we have for you is the same as we have for every other thing in life: start with Jesus. Put God in charge of your relationships, even (especially) if that’s marriage or marriage–plans, and you won’t go far wrong. (Keeping Him there can be hard work, but is essential). With closeness to God, grace, peace, and selfless love begin to adorn our lives. The Bible’s got some real smarts on how to love and live for other people, which are pretty useful for this whole relating business, whether that’s in looking for/maintaining relationships with life–partners, friends or, well, anyone (y’know, those billions of neighbours Jesus reckons we’ve got). We’ll be looking at some of these over the next few days, and getting wise to some of the threats and solutions might make for stronger love–lives all round. Love–ly.

content.title: Real-ationships (2)
content.introtext:
'The wise have wealth and luxury...' Proverbs 21:20 NLT

Any emotional baggage we’re carrying about friendships and relationships gets more intense as we get closer to someone. Wherever you’re at, with mates or marriages, there’s wisdom here we reckon applies to you. Money strains relationships. Whether it was your best friend at kindy or your bestie now, things can be going great until one of you points at a pile of sweet stuff and declares ‘it’s all mine’. A signpost as to how far the world’s idea of marriage has strayed from God’s view is the existence of prenuptial agreements. There’s a step you take when you get married, where everything you have becomes each other’s. But even if we didn’t look at dividing stuff within a relationship, all the money-worries you can face in life (‘Can I afford this?’ ‘How will I pay that bill?’ ‘What will happen if I don’t get that job?’) get shared, and risk getting magnified. You’ll have seen it, we’re sure: two people, both stressed, winding each other right up, until a tough situation feels crushingly impossible. So what to do? Again, keep Jesus at the centre of your life. Money isn’t a safe place for your trust. If it’s getting the most attention in your relationship and not God, it’s time for your priorities to change. It’s tough, but striking that balance between being a ‘good steward’ of what God gives you, and not putting your trust in it above your trust in Him, is well worth striving for. And it’s worth remembering that He doesn’t bless you so you can have ‘wealth and luxury’ (Proverbs 21:20 NLT) for yourself: He blesses you so you can bless others.

content.title: Love, A Decision
content.introtext:
'Marriage should be honoured...for God will judge the adulterer and...the...immoral.' Hebrews 13:4 NIV

We tend to think of love as a feeling. But love is really an act of our will. Sometimes, we’re not in that happy–place of ‘feeling’ loving toward our family members or friends or spouses. That happens, it’s normal. In those moments, you can ‘love’ someone through a decision to put them first. It’s true, even if you’re not quite ‘feeling’ you even like them at that exact moment. Great. But it works another way too. Sometimes, even after you’ve committed to someone, a bright–sparkly new someone walks past with a cute smile, and your heart begins to wonder (and wander) after them instead. Unfortunately this is not unusual, but normal. In that moment, your commitment should be a decision to not smile back, to not entertain the thought–train that pops into your mind... a strong, self–imposed NO. STOP. In a culture that doesn’t seem to value commitment, we’ve been told that ‘how I feel’ in that moment is what’s important. That’s a recipe for a life of not–really–ever trusting anyone, or knowing the intimacy that God designed relationships to contain. Bad news: our feelings aren’t always trustworthy. Sometimes our feelings of love need to be topped up with will–power. (Some more advice. Not every relationship is right. Also normal. Use that same will–power to assess if a relationship is right and healthy for you both, rather than feeling trapped by expectations.) Read 2 Corinthians 10:5. Take a few minutes to consider what ‘taking captive a thought’ might look like for you. How could you present such a captive thought to God so He can deal with it for you?

content.title: Harass the Heathens
content.introtext:
'Friend, do what you came to do.' Matthew 26:50 NCV

Whip out the placards. Strike up the marching bands. Get some rubber tyres burning. Today, we’re looking at Matthew 18, where Jesus says that if people don’t repent, then they should be treated ‘like a pagan or a tax collector’. That’s Matthew 18:15–17. Read that, then get crafting those hateful signs and flags. Back? Good. Before we start the pagan purge, it’s worth looking up what Jesus meant by treating someone ‘like a pagan or a tax collector’. Ok, they were the lowest life-form as far as the Jews were concerned. But funnily enough, whenever we see Jesus interacting with any sinners, pagans or tax collectors, it doesn’t look anything like today’s public protests.

Jesus shows each sinner He meets a soft heart and honest care. When He came across someone who He disagreed with, ‘Jesus, looking at him, loved him.’ (Mark 10:21 ESV) When He met an outcast tax collector, He told him: ‘I must stay at your house today.’ (Luke 19:5 NIV) When Judas, His betrayer, sold Him out, He called him ‘friend’ (Matthew 26:50). He wasn’t pretending they weren’t sinners. But He loved them to the point of spending so much time with them that others thought He was just as drunk and sinful as them. He didn’t care that others saw Him as naïve or mistaken—everything He did was to show sinners a way to a restored connection with the Father. What would Jesus have you do and say regarding the unrepentant, ‘least–worthy’ person you know? Make a mini placard that bears His message of love to them. 



SoulFood: Gal 1-3, Matt 13:24-35, Ps 101, Prov 13:20-23

content.title: No Robes, No Problem
content.introtext:
'Friends sharpen the minds of each other.' Proverbs 27:17 CEV

1 Samuel 18 has two strong friends performing an ancient covenant ritual. This was a bit like playground ‘blood brothers’, but much more serious—a promise to cover the other person’s back until death. ‘After David had finished talking with Saul, he met Jonathan, the king’s son. There was an immediate bond between them…Jonathan made a solemn pact with David, because he loved him as he loved himself. Jonathan sealed the pact by taking off his robe and giving it to David, together with his tunic, sword, bow and belt.’ (1 Samuel 18:1–4 NLT)

It’s a peculiar bit of Bible passage, isn’t it? Why would Jonathan go to those (probably fairly chilly) extremes to prove his friendship—what’s wrong with a coffee and a chat? Jonathan does something humble and costly by making a covenant with David. He’s the king’s son and heir to the throne. By handing over his tunic, sword and belt, he symbolises giving up his inheritance to David. Jonathan is dressing David to be the next king. Wow. The highest form of friendship puts others before ourselves. Do you want the best for your mate or do you secretly, even mentally, one–up them, so you have the higher status? Do you give up the things that you’ve been privileged with for your friends’ sakes? 1 Corinthians 13:4–5 NLT tells us, ‘…Love is patient and kind... not jealous or boastful or proud or rude. It does not demand its own way. It is not irritable, and it keeps no record of being wronged.’ Every time you ‘covet’ something today, do a good deed for the person whose stuff you’ve wanted.

content.title: BFFL* Shuffle
content.introtext:
'Two people are better off than one.' Ecclesiastes 4:9 NLT

Ok, maybe we’re risking getting a little primary school here, but we reckon it’s worth it. We don’t care how old you are, the whole making friends thing is always relevant. It doesn’t really get any easier, does it? Whenever we hit a new stage in our life, we can find ourselves feeling that familiar ‘how do I make friends?’ feeling. So here’s some practical tips.

First of all, try talking. Practice really does make perfect. Don’t worry about being witty and original—just try speaking. This will build your confidence as well as allowing others an opportunity to get to know you.

Second, learn to listen. You don’t have to have a life–or–death story of ‘How I scaled Everest without an inhaler’ for people to want to talk to you. Actually people generally love talking about themselves so, by listening, you give them a chance to be centre stage.

Thirdly, have the courage to be you. Don’t apologise for the lame bands you like or pretend to be the ‘life and soul’ if you’re more happy with a quiet coffee and a chat. You’re a masterpiece in God’s eyes (even if there’s a bit of spiritual renovation still to go). And finally, choose your friends. There will always be cliques and tribes who think everyone should know their place (yawn). But there will also be those not bothered about ‘who’s in’ and ‘who’s out’. People who won’t judge you are going to make better friends anyway. So, thank God for the people around you. If you feel like there’s something missing for you, people–wise, ask God to fill that gap somehow. He put you together and He not only knows you need friendships, but what sort as well.

*Best Friends For Life 



SoulFood: Lam 1:1-3:39, Matt 13:47-58, Ps 113, Prov 14:1-4

content.title: Galvanise
content.introtext:
'He will give you the mighty inner strengthening of His Holy Spirit.' Ephesians 3:16 TLB

The author Edith Schaeffer came up with the idea that Heaven’s museum has two exhibits. In the first one there’s a display of Satan’s weapons, his trials and torments thrown against God’s people. They’re in pieces—broken when God miraculously stepped in. The second shows Satan’s weapons broken when believers couldn’t see God in their situation but trusted He was good anyway, and so they overcame.

Collapsing beneath the weight of everything around you? Just about done with your secrets, failures and weaknesses? And, worst of all, does it feel like God isn’t going to show up to help? If you’re the sort of person who seems to see God miraculously moving in everyone else’s life, but gets frustrated at the silence in your own, there absolutely is something for you, too. There is no worse–off Christian ‘class’ that gets less than others. God promises strength for you, a mighty inner strength that comes from above and girds your heart with iron. You’ve got the Holy Spirit in there already, so it’s a case of praying to Someone closer than close. Meditating on God’s Word can be a useful prayer–tool for that. Meditating isn’t a spooky other–world–y thing—it’s simply slowly down and actively looking at what God said.

A good way to meditate is to go through these five steps: Pause (slow down and think deeply about what Scripture you’re reading), Presence (acknowledge God is present, speaking to you through His Word), Perspective (what did it mean to those it was originally written to), Ponder (how does it apply to your life?) and Promise (take away a promise from God for your life.) Practise with today’s verse. Stop and examine it, using these five steps.



SoulFood: Lam 3:40-5:22, Matt 14:1-12, Ps 82, Prov 14:5-8

content.title: Christ-like-ness
content.introtext:
'We share in His sufferings...that we may also share in His glory.' Romans 8:17 NIV

Who wouldn’t want to follow Christ? He is the Way, the Truth and Life. He is the bridge between you and eternity. He has your healing in His hand and forgiveness for your wrong. He has your purpose, meaning and direction. He is light in your darkness. He is love hanging on a cross. He knows you and loves you with a perfect love.

True. And some of us have got the idea that all He expects in return is for us to relax in His grace and wait until our number is called for Heaven. Right? Wrong. If you’re thinking God owes you, you’d best read your Bible. God’s goal for you isn’t comfort; it’s Christ–like–ness. And to head in that direction, you’ll have to experience some of the stuff Jesus did—like being misunderstood or betrayed or facing rejection. Basically, it isn’t an easy ride. Jesus said, ‘If anyone would come after Me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross…’ (Matthew 16:24 ESV) God’s goal isn’t comfort. Still want to follow Him? To be Christ–like in this broken world will take some serious, deep, re–moulding of us. If you want the good stuff you’ve got to take the tough stuff. Remember: ‘We share in His suffering…that we may also share in His glory.’ (Romans 8:17 NIV) God wants to get you out of your comfort zone so the only place you’ll be comfortable is in Him.



SoulFood: Gen 24:1-51, 2 Cor 6:14-7:1

content.title: Yours, Sincerely
content.introtext:
'The Lord has hidden Himself...but I trust Him.' Isaiah 8:17 GNT

Once upon a time being part of God’s family all seemed so simple. Heart ascending a ladder to Heaven during worship. Bible verses leaping from the pages. Prayer was a spine–tingling soul–stirring experience. But then... one day the songs all sounded the same, the Bible was tougher than trigonometry, and prayers seemed to bounce off the ceiling. What happened? Did you sin once too often? Did God have a huff? Are you not singing loud enough? God isn’t a tease. He doesn’t ditch you when a better offer comes His way. Nor does He drop the whole ‘would have died for you if you were the only human on earth’ thing because your Bible reading has gone skewiff. Sometimes it may feel like God has hidden Himself for a while. No, He isn’t playing at cosmic peek-a-boo; He’s working on your maturity. He’s not even playing a ‘long game’ of chess, with you as a piece. This is about Him being yours, and you being His, in the very best way. God wants to grow us into people who are more interested in being with Him than in receiving the gifts He delights in giving us. If a relationship with Him consisted only of fuzzy feelings during our favourite songs, we’d never grow up. God is still with us even when we don’t ‘feel’ Him. Sometimes He prioritises trust over emotions. Faith, not feelings, is what pleases Him (Hebrews 11:6). There’s something to be said about prayer and worship and Bible time, when you’re not ‘feeling’ the benefit. Although it’s difficult, stick with it; the discipline will mature you. Also remember, God says, ‘Never will I leave you; never will I forsake you.’ (Hebrews 13:5 NIV)



SoulFood: Amos 1:1-5:17, Matt 14:13-21, Ps 117, Prov 14:9-12

content.title: Scare Tactics
content.introtext:
'God has not given us a spirit of fear.' 2 Timothy 1:7 NKJ

Jesus doesn’t want us to spend our lives worrying. During His ‘Sermon on the Mount’, He essentially writes it off it as useless: ‘Can any one of you by worrying add a single hour to your life?’ (Matthew 6:27 NIV) He’s right (shocker). It is useless and we should be able to cast it aside.

But we can’t always do that so easily. Paul’s advice to worriers in his letter to the Philippians is pretty standard Christian advice, but it’s still mega–useful: pray. Replace bad habit with good habit. Don’t hold back the things you’re stressing about from God. He’s big enough, and wise enough, to handle anything you’ve got swirling around your head. In fact, one of the names for the Holy Spirit is ‘Counsellor’, so helping us when we feel overwhelmed is one of His specialties. Praying about worry can sometimes feel like ‘just the Christian task to do’, but it’s actually how we put ourselves in the hands of the Father who comforts us. It’s no trite task. The next time you feel particularly worried about something, take Paul’s advice and just hammer out a prayer. You don’t have to feel guilty about not having had your eyes fixed on Him. Obviously the ideal is for us to ask God into everything from the get–go, but even if we turn to Him at the last min

ute, He will still smile, reach down and pick us up. Every time you worry about something today, even the smallest thing, write it down. Then, write a prayer about it. Cross the worries out once they’re dealt with. 



SoulFood: Judg 4-6, Matt 12:1-14, Ps 93, Prov 13:7-8

content.title: 'Some Sin With Your Anger, Sir?' (1)
content.introtext:
'Get rid of all bitterness, rage and anger.' Ephesians 4:31 NIV

Pretty much everyone gets angry, including people we think are ‘super holy’ Christians. There are thousands of reasons we get angry and a lot of them come from having to deal with other people. Ever since there’s been a Church, there have been problems with members of Christ’s Body getting angry with one another. That’s why Paul wrote about how God wants His people to respond to their anger.

Anger itself isn’t bad, but it’s what we decide to do with it that can be seriously destructive. That’s why Paul says in Ephesians 4:26 NIV, ‘In your anger, do not sin’ (quoting the Greek translation of Psalm 4:4). He meant: ‘Sure, you’ll get angry sometimes but, when you do, make sure you don’t do anything stupid.’ Anger makes a great mixer for sin. It has all the right flavours: the turning inwards, the impulse to only think about yourself, the rashness. Instead of letting our anger control us, Paul advises us to just dump the whole lot down the drain: ‘Get rid of all bitterness, rage and anger.’ (Ephesians 4:31 NIV)

Really easy to say, way harder to do. Choosing to let go of our anger when we’ve been hurt by someone doesn’t always feel like the natural thing to do. It’s difficult, but not only is it better for us in the long run, it’s what God has done for us. God doesn’t hold His anger against us because He chose to let go of it and forgive. Next time you get explosively angry at someone or something, it’s a good idea to leave the room. Pray about the anger and hand the situation over to God.



SoulFood (Ascension): Lk 24:50-53, Acts 1:1-11, Eph 4:7-10

content.title: 'Some Sin With Your Anger, Sir?' (2)
content.introtext:
'See to it that no bitter root grows up to cause trouble.' Hebrews 12:15 NIV

Obsessing over how you’ve been wronged and how you are so in the right can make you feel better. A bit. It does, however, make you a seriously sad person to be around, for everyone else. God doesn’t like it either. Choosing to let go of your bitterness when someone’s ‘wronged you’ is hard but it’s what He asks us to do: ‘Be kind and compassionate to one another, forgiving each other, just as in Christ God forgave you.’ (Ephesians 4:32 NIV)

The thing is, forgiveness isn’t impossible. Because it’s been made possible. As Jesus was being crucified, some of His last words were: ‘Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they are doing.’ (Luke 23:34 NIV) That’s THE example of forgiveness we’re given, which you might think is pretty insane. You may think that Jesus was well within His rights not to forgive the people who were in the process of murdering Him. Instead of holding onto His anger and bitterness, He let it go and forgave them. Incredible, right? It’s made even more impressive when you remember that the people responsible for torturing Him didn’t rush up at the last moment to say, ‘Oh Jesus, I’ve seen the error of my ways! I’m so sorry that I’ve done this. What can I do to make amends?’ No, that’s not what happened. They continued to kill Him. And He continued to forgive them.

Think back to when you were a little kid. Make a list of the things from back then that still make you angry. God made all those ‘impossible forgive-nesses’ possible. Why wait to ask Him to work His power of forgiveness in your mind and heart?



SoulFood: 1 Pet 1-5, Matt 10:21-31, Ps 18:1-29, Prov 12:23-24

content.title: Where is God?
content.introtext:
'Oh, that I knew where I might find Him.' Job 23:3 NKJ

Job is a gritty book that doesn’t avoid the difficult questions. A lot of what happens to Job seems unfair—he loses his family, security and health in the opening chapters. The rest is dedicated to people trying to wrap their minds around what he did to deserve it all. We hear Job’s pain, we feel his grief, and we come across three of his well–meaning friends with some suspect theology.

Yet through it all, Job keeps his eyes looking up to God, despite his clouds of doubt. He had massive struggles at times but he refused to accept the blame his friends were trying to make him shoulder. He also refused, despite the painful circumstances, to blame God; instead he tried to make sense of them. He tried desperately to find God, and work out what He was up to, rather than assume He wasn’t there for him. In his struggle, his desire is: ‘Oh, that I knew where I might find Him.’ (Job 23:3 NKJ) Are you going through a rough ride? Maybe you’re feeling broken, at a loss, hurting, with or without an explanation. If so, take a note from Job, whose quiet times weren’t so quiet—groans, moans, tears, shouts are all in there. Cries and sighs are just as legit as words (Romans 8:26)—God knows what you mean. And if Job tells us anything about how to go through those tough times, it’s this: take your pain to God. So when you need to have some unquiet quiet–time with God, go somewhere private. Whatever is going on inside you, good or bad, talk to Him as honestly (and loudly) as you need to.



SoulFood: Deut 30:1-32:28, Matt 10:1-10, Ps 62, Prov 12:18-19

content.title: A Thorny Issue
content.introtext:
'A thorn in the flesh was given to me...' 2 Corinthians 12:7 NKJ

A jab from a rosebush isn’t the end of the world. You may bleed a little, but that’s about it. Thorns of the New Testament were a different beast altogether. Nature’s brutal weapon of choice in the desert more accurately describes them. These things really made their point (pardon the pun).

Paul’s statement from 2 Corinthians 12:7 becomes all the stranger: he accepted the fact that God had sent to messenger of Satan with an agonising ‘thorn’ to help him! Help? Say, what?!

It’s true that wasn’t his first conclusion. Something had to change in Paul; at first he begged God to remove it. Three times he begged. But over time, he learned to not only accept it, but to celebrate it. The weakness it brought had a way of drawing God’s strength out. Accepting his limitations allowed God to work through him. The gift of a thorn takes Paul to the cross: ‘I have been crucified with Christ and I no longer live, but Christ lives in me. The life I live in the body, I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave Himself for me.’ (Galatians 2:20 NIV)

So think about this: if you’ve been complaining about your own thorny issue, perhaps God is using it to highlight your limitations. Spend a moment thanking Him for the work He’s doing, or planning, through that issue. Ask God to use your weakness to draw out His strength.



SoulFood: Deut 32:29-34:12, Matt 10:11-20, Ps 49, Prov 12:20-22

content.title: Up All Night
content.introtext:
'I will not let you go unless you bless me.' Genesis 32:26 NIV

Jacob was a sinner. He took what wasn’t his: first he cheated his older brother, Esau, to get his father’s blessing. Then he cheated his father–in–law, Laban, so he could get wealthy. Even his name meant deceiver—this guy knew he didn’t deserve goodness. So, he ran off in fear.

Then one night the ‘Angel of the Lord’ showed up as Jacob was left alone and was trying to figure out how to deal with his furious brother. Jacob wrestled with the Angel all through the night until daybreak. As you do, right? Actually, it’s one of the weirder stories in the Bible. It’s found in Genesis 32:22–32 and tells us Jacob had the gall to fight and refuse to give up, despite injury, until God blessed him.

Jacob was a sinner. Like you, and us. But he wasn’t going to let go of God. So God gave him a new name: Israel. (Yep, this is where the name comes from!) Israel meant prince with God or wrestles with God. His identity was totally changed. No longer driven by fear, he turned to healing his wounded family relationships. This kind of transformation isn’t only on offer to special guys from the Bible thousands of years ago—it’s for us too! The Bible says, ‘Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, the new creation has come: The old has gone, the new is here!’ (2 Corinthians 5:17 NIV) Have you ever asked God what unimaginable things He might have for your life? Or what family relationships He might want you to have a part in healing? Talk to Him tonight about them before you go to sleep.



SoulFood: Obad, Mal 1-4, Matt 10:32-42, Ps 18:30-50, Prov 12:25-28

content.title: No Sads, Ever?
content.introtext:
'"For I know the plans I have for you," declares the Lord, "plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you hope and a future."' Jeremiah 29:11 NIV

Ever had someone at church try to cheer you up with Jeremiah 29:11? People often use that verse in a ‘God has plans, so no sads, ever’ sort of way. But, God’s plan won’t always be what we want for our lives...

The Israelites (the people God was speaking to in this verse) had put their hopes and plans above God’s, and were unpleasantly surprised when they ended up in a place they didn’t expect to be. They were taken captive by their enemies, the Babylonians. The verse before Jeremiah 29:11 (imaginatively called Jeremiah 29:10) says: ‘When seventy years are completed for Babylon, I will come to you and fulfil my good promise to bring you back…’ So the thing which the Israelites really wanted, to be freed and go back home, wouldn’t happen for 70 years. 70 years! That’s 280 more issues of word4U2day! It’s a pretty long time to wait for something you want. They must have been gutted when they heard Jeremiah 29:10 (although they probably called it differently back then…)

But.

God promises them that it isn’t hopeless and that they can do well in their lives, even though they’re not where they expected to be. If we trust God with what’s in front of us, good things can come even out of our most unexpected disappointments. So spend some time thinking about what you’ve had in mind for your life that hasn’t lined up in the way your expected. Talk to God about any disappointment you’ve experienced because your ideas don’t align with His. Then pray about changing your plans to line up with His.



SoulFood: Gen 2:7-25, 1 Cor 15:39-55

content.title: Growing in God
content.introtext:
'He came seeking fruit on it and found none.' Luke 13:6 NKJ

Jesus said: ‘A man had a fig tree growing in his vineyard, and he went to look for fruit on it but did not find any. So he said to the man who took care of the vineyard, “For three years now I’ve been coming to look for fruit on this fig tree and haven’t found any. Cut it down! Why should it use up the soil?” “Sir,” the man replied, “leave it alone for one more year, and I’ll dig around it and fertilise it. If it bears fruit next year, fine! If not, then cut it down.”’ (Luke 13:6–9 NIV) How long have you been a Christian? Figured out yet that it’s more than being ‘good’?

Like we said in yesterday’s reading, God really does have a plan for us, which is definitely exciting. And, it tends to mean engaging with the world around us and doing stuff, rather than hiding away. God made you with a specific set of skills and there will be heaps of ways you can use those skills to worship Him. This parable warns us about being lazy and not doing what God made us to do. It’s the fig tree’s job to make figs. That’s its ‘thing’. But also notice: the man looking after the tree believed that it would flourish. God wants to help you grow in Him (John 15:5) and He’ll look after you as you do. So, spend some time thinking and praying about what you’re good at (maybe ask someone who knows you well what that is?) then see if you can use it worship God.

content.title: Fiscal Fallacies
content.introtext:
'Keep your life free from love of money, and be content with what you have, for he has said, "I will never leave you nor forsake you."' Hebrews 13:5 ESV

People who put their trust in money often learn about the risk in the worst crash. History, anyone? In 1923 German money became practically worthless due to a series of catastrophes. The cost of a loaf of bread shot to 200,000,000,000 marks: that’s about 10 billion per slice! People lost everything. Looking back over the last 100 years you can see plenty of financial crises which left lives devastated—some closer to home.

Money isn’t the answer to life’s problems; it doesn’t love you or free you and it isn’t reliable. It can be tempting to trust in providing for yourself but we are called to completely trust in God, in all things, no matter how uncomfortable that can make us. It can feel incredibly awkward stepping out into places or careers that God’s called us to, not knowing where the support will come from. But He says: ‘I will never leave you nor forsake you.’ That certainly doesn’t mean ‘lie back and do nothing because God will make money rain from the sky’—generally we are called to work in some way. It does mean however, that you can completely trust God with your whole financial future, no matter what crises hits. It also means that everything we’re given is His in the first place; it’s never really ours to hold onto, which is a pretty good springboard thought to help us get our hearts around living generously. If giving to others isn’t something you can sustain right now, ask God that you would have the means to live contentedly and joyfully, provided for by Him. He will make a way.
