content.title: No Fear In Death (2)
content.introtext: '...Thanks be to God, Who gives us the victory [over death] through our Lord Jesus.' 1 Corinthians 15:57 NKJ
content.fulltext:
‘Easter Saturday’ is a weird time. It’s the middle day, between the sorrow of Good Friday and the joy of Easter Sunday. So we wait, twiddling our thumbs, not even bothering to name this day. But actually, we think it’s really important. The disciples spent ‘Easter Saturday’ grieving. Jesus was dead. Murdered by the authorities they’d hoped He might overthrow. But, a verse we often skip over might give us a wake–up call: ‘graves were opened; and many bodies of the saints who had fallen asleep were raised…they went into the holy city and appeared to many.’ (Matthew 27:52–53 NKJ) Jesus died, right then and there. Becuase we have the benefit of hindsight, something the disciples didn't have Easter Saturday is a day of impending hope becuase we the resurrection is coming on Sunday. The disciples would see that resurrection is real. But their fear and grief kept their hearts from knowing the hope that Jesus’ own resurrection promises would be fulfilled. Our hearts can live in the same place. Resurrection’s a lovely story, we may even see proof of God’s power, but it 'almost' doesn’t seem real enough. We can get on with life without ever fully living in the hope that Jesus offers. We acknowledge that He died for us, but sometimes forget that He rose for us. But... He did rise. For real. We haven’t yet seen what God has planned for us in Heaven, but Jesus beat death, for you to know that His life–giving power is real. He, the prototype, has gone on before us and made the way.

content.title: Home
content.introtext: '... I will come and get you...' John 14:3 NLT
content.fulltext:
Paul wrote ‘...if Christ has not been raised, then all our preaching is useless, and your faith is useless... and you are still guilty of your sins. In that case, all who have died believing in Christ are lost! And if our hope in Christ is only for this life, we are more to be pitied than anyone in the world.’ (1 Corinthians 15:14–19 NLT) Jesus rising from the dead on Easter Sunday is creation–shaking news. God died, God rose again, and beat death, so that you can leave death behind and be reunited to Him, too! Without that, there is no ‘Christianity’. But there’s more. Jesus says, ‘...I am going to prepare a place for you... when everything is ready, I will come and get you...’ (John 14:3–4 NLT) History lesson: when an ancient Israelite marriage was agreed upon, the groom went back to his dad’s house, and built a new home for the bride. When it was finished, he’d collect her, they’d have a wedding, then they’d live there together. Jesus’ words to the disciples set the scene for the ‘Bride’ of Christ (that’s us, His Church) to be reunited to Him. God as Groom, and His people as Bride, paints a wondrous picture of how much He loves us, how close He wants us to be, and what He has planned for us when He comes to take us home. Easter Sunday turns a funeral into a wedding feast. Today, take some time out from the chocolate egg feast to spend with the God who’s preparing a home for you, with Him.



SoulFood Easter Sunday: 1 Cor 15, Luke 24:1-12

content.title: Easter Message
content.introtext: 'Looking for the blessed hope...' Titus 2:13 NKJ
content.fulltext:
The hope we can have because of Jesus’ resurrection isn’t an airy ‘in–an–ideal–world’ hope. Jesus secured our future in Heaven with a promise: ‘…Because I live, you will live also.’ (John 14:19 NKJ) Paul records the amount of witnesses who saw Jesus soon after the resurrection: ‘five hundred of His followers at one time’ (1 Corinthians 15:6 NLT) amongst several other instances. Hold up. That’s quite a lot, isn’t it? More than that, these witnesses saw Jesus in the flesh. Not some sort of ghost, or a ‘warm feeling’ in their memory. Jesus’ followers didn’t follow up His death with eulogies; the resurrection changed that. The disciples carried on acting as if He was alive—because something had convinced them He was. Anyone ever who has been convinced and changed by Jesus’ resurrected life has the same hope they had. Heaven is a reality we can look forward to. And more than that, just like the disciples, eternal life with God is something we can start living out right now. Discipleship isn’t a remembrance club, it’s a living walk with a real life God. When Jesus rose on the third day, He proved that sin could no longer come between us and God (Romans 6:18). We’re free. Today, as well as looking back to the world’s greatest sacrifice, let’s look ahead to the fact that our lives, and the lives around us, can change because of it. Does it feel like a while since you last asked God to change something in your life? Maybe you’ve gone back to an old habit. Don’t let anything delay you—invite Him to bring His resurrected life into those parts of you.



SoulFood: Jer 31-32, Luke 24:13-18, Ps 32, Prov 9:10-16

content.title: Be Consistently Strong
content.introtext: 'We must pay the most careful attention, therefore, to what we have heard, so that we do not drift away.' Hebrews 2:1 NIV
content.fulltext:
What if there’s more to staying in tune with God in easy times than meets the eye? Take Samson. If you know one thing about him, it’ll be that he could push a pillar or two. Samson’s enemies tried time and again to discover the secret of his stupendous strength. Time and again, God helped Samson overcome his enemies, even when Samson was disobeying Him. Samson thought God would be with him always, no matter what sin he was involved in. He didn’t realise God was giving him time to repent. In the final (and successful) attempt of Samson’s enemies to take him down, it was his own pride that undid him. ‘“I will go out as before, at other times, and shake myself free!” But he did not know that the Lord had departed from him.’ (Judges 16:20 NIV) Look up the story in Judges 16. Surrounded by enemies and his own fame, he forgot that he had been drawing on God’s strength the whole time. Matthew Henry said, ‘Our minds and memories are like a leaky vessel, they do not, without much care, retain what is poured into them.’ Samson’s story is an extreme, but it illustrates quite a lot. If you’re strong at one point, don’t rely on yourself to keep that up. All good comes from God (James 1:7), and He wants you to move forward, not drift back. If there’s a sin you keep on committing, don’t assume like Samson that God will be with you, regardless. This is the time of His mercy. Don’t knock it back.



SoulFood: Jer 33:1-36:26; Luke 24:19-24; Ps 25:1-7; Pro 9:17-18

content.title: Just Sit Back and Receive
content.introtext: 'All our busy rushing ends in nothing.' Psalm 39:6 NLT
content.fulltext:
If you were offered an access–all–areas tour of the inside of your head, would you take it? For a lot of us, this idea would send us bolting. We know that our restlessness and endless activity is coming from somewhere, but we’re not quite sure where and why. We’re not totally comfortable with being alone with ourselves. Some of us try to escape that feeling of blandness by rushing around all the time, but it doesn’t work. We’re just moving mental shadows. If we’re honest, what we really long for is for God to take our minds, rinse them out in His cool living water, and set them to dry in the warmth of His light. If we’re always rushing to escape our own heads, though, we’ll never be still enough for God to deal with the problem. God wants to fling the shutters open, and let the fresh air of His Holy Spirit blow in over your peace of mind, health, and your closeness to others. Doing more or less won’t be what helps. It starts as He fills your mind and renews your soul in stillness, so you have to be ok with being still for a bit. Today take a minute to simply sit still and receive this blessing: ‘The Lord bless you and keep you; the Lord make His face shine upon you and be gracious to you; the Lord turn His face toward you and give you peace.’ (Numbers 6:24–26 NIV) Now spend a moment thinking about someone you could send this blessing to. Text it, Facebook it, Instagram it or just use the old way: speak it.



SoulFood: Jer 36:27-40:16; Luke 24:25-35; Ps 25:8-15; Pro 10:1-3

content.title: Reboot
content.introtext: 'The Lord is my portion...therefore I hope in Him.' Lamentations 3:24 NKJ
content.fulltext:
We know… when you were little, you were going to be President of the Universe. LOL. Unfortunately, you’ve not quite made it yet and, guess what? That’s ok! And, even with your more realistic ambitions—graduating with top marks, getting the perfect job as a steppingstone to that Cosmic Presidency—it’s actually ok you’re not quite there yet either. Yes. You heard it correctly. It’s ok to not meet your own high–as–the–sky expectations. In fact, it’s impossible not to fail at the most important thing of all: pleasing God. Can’t do it. Just. Not. Possible. Sin gets in the way. But there’s hope. In the words of the prophet Jeremiah: ‘Through the Lord’s mercies we are not consumed, because His compassions fail not. They are new every morning; great is Your faithfulness. The Lord is my portion…therefore I hope in Him.’ (Lamentations 3:22–24 NKJ) What’s that? God doesn’t have any less compassion for us, no matter what we do or don’t achieve? Even better than that, He renews His concern and interest in us every single day. Regardless of what happened yesterday, God is raring to faithfully refresh and provide for you today. He is with you in this new day. He’s already picked you back up. And, once you ask Him to, He’s ready to point you in the right direction for today’s fresh new plans. Give yourself a break. Allow God to renew and refresh you right now. Take the load off yourself and press the ‘Reboot’ button. God’s mercies are new every day—and that’s His promise! Wow, that’s a relief!



SoulFood: Jer 41-44; Luke 24:36-44; Ps 25:16-22; Pro 10:4-7

content.title: Fishing for Peace
content.introtext:
'Cast all your anxiety on Him.' 1 Peter 5:7 NIV

We’ve been told it many times but when we’re stressed, we don’t really think about it. Here it is again: ‘Cast all your anxiety on Him.’ (1 Peter 5:7 NIV) First, put this verse into context. ‘...be submissive to those who are older... “God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble.” Humble yourselves, therefore, under God’s mighty hand, that He may lift you up in due time. Cast all your anxiety on Him because He cares for you.’ (1 Peter 5:5–7 NIV) The verses just before the ‘cast all your anxiety’ bit are about being humble. Seems humility and ‘casting anxiety on the Lord’ are interconnected. Casting anxiety on God starts when we are humble enough to say: ‘God, I can’t handle it alone, I don’t have the strength without You.’ Also, let’s think about that word ‘cast’. It’s what you do with a net when you’re fishing. So, it’s to do with catching stuff. No coincidence that Peter the apostle who’d been a fisherman wrote this. So, when we think about how to ‘cast all [our] anxiety on Him’, it’s about that fishing technique of throwing out and pulling back in. Yes, it’s about casting out worries and drawing God close—catching and pulling in a glimpse of His presence and His peace. And that’s the practicality of 1 Peter 5:7. Use the throwing away of worries to draw in closer to God. Use the high–stress times as a sign that we should step back, and try to catch sight of God.


SoulFood: Jer 45-48; Luke 24:45-53; Ps 50:1-15; Pro 10:8-10

content.title: PAUL, AT YOUR SERVICE
content.introtext:
'The Gospel...of which I, Paul, have become a servant.' Colossians 1:23 NIV

 

In the early Corinthian Church, certain people were becoming very jealous over their favourite leaders and causing a lot of strife amongst themselves because of it. A whole bunch of people were siding with Paul, ready to argue down the supporters of Apollos or Peter.

But Paul wasn’t having any of it. And he was right. He had a properly balanced opinion of himself, and of those around him. Look at what he said—he was quite happy to say of himself and the other leaders in the church: ‘This is how one should regard us, as servants of Christ and stewards of the mysteries of God.’ (1 Corinthians 4:1 ESV) He never thought of himself as a superhero of the Church, as superior to anyone. It was because he saw them all, himself included, as servants and stewards of the Gospel. He also wrote: ‘What then is Apollos? What is Paul? Ministering servants [not heads of parties] through whom you believed, even as the Lord appointed to each his task.’ (1 Corinthians 3:5 AMP) He and the other leaders were a team, under the orders of God, and so they were all completely equal.

And so are you. Being a Christian, whether that’s the Christian–church–leader or the Christian–who–makes–the–coffee–after–the–service, means you are a servant of God. No more, and no less. Whatever role we’ve been given, it’s clear from Scripture and from the example of His Son Jesus, we are to serve. And in our serving others we are serving God.

 

 



SoulFood: Num 7, Luke 6:27-36, Ps 107:1-9, Prov 3:13-18

content.title: APPRECIATE, DON'T HESITATE
content.introtext:
'If your gift is to encourage others, be encouraging.' Romans 12:8 NLT

 

We all need encouragement. Sometimes life is exhausting and we want to give up. Sometimes the apple of temptation is too shiny and we want to give in. All sorts of people around you may be in very weak places today, under the surface. So, do a beautiful thing today—and encourage. The Bible gives us different ways to do it…

(1) Encourage through gifts: ‘All those about them encouraged them with articles of silver, with gold, with cattle and with valuables…’ (Ezra 1:6 NAS) So begins the story of God’s people pooling together gifts to encourage a group from Judah to rebuild God’s house. Perhaps you know a missionary or someone going on a short term mission trip—encourage them by giving a gift.

(2) Encourage with kind words: ‘And he who smooths metal with the hammer encourages him who beats the anvil…’ (Isaiah 41:7 NAS) A compliment on the quality of somebody’s work goes a very long way. How about complimenting your church leader about the sermon this Sunday?

(3) Encourage through writing: ‘When they had read it, they rejoiced because of its encouragement.’ (Acts 15:31 ESV) We’ll leave you to figure out your way of doing that. You never know when a humble ‘thanks’ or an honest compliment might just be the thing that keeps somebody going. So, use your imagination. Get creative in how you show your appreciation for someone today. You could make sure your church knows what you appreciate about it. Whether it’s a note or an email (or whatever you like, really), it’s important to point out the good stuff.

 



SoulFood: Jas 1-2, Luke 5:1-11, Ps 91, Prov 3:3-4

content.title: INVENTING A NEW WORD (1)
content.introtext:
'...When He saw the multitudes, He was moved with compassion for them...' Matthew 9:36 NKJ

 

‘Let us not love with words or tongue but with actions and in truth.’ (1 John 3:18 NIV) Jesus set a pretty strong example, actually. Turns out He didn’t say: ‘Oh go on guys, play nice, please?’ or throw casual platitudes over His shoulder at the homeless and hurting as He passed: ‘Mm, yeah, bless you…’ Jesus was massively concerned about the wounded world He’d stepped into.

So concerned, the Gospel writers had to create a new word to describe that compassion. They said that Jesus was ‘moved in the depths of His gut’ (yep, it’s splagchnizomai, Greek fans) for people. And then there’s the shortest verse in the Bible: ‘Jesus wept.’ (John 11:35) Ours is a God who, when He stepped into this messy and broken world of ours, chose to heal the sick, feed the hungry and restore outcasts. It turns out they were (and we are...) pretty precious to Him.

So, what about the poor and hungry in your city? What if your area has a people–trafficking problem, behind closed doors? What if one Sunday the back row of your church was filled with homeless, (literally) unclean, maybe even alcohol–dependent people who had wandered in to see what your church was like? Do we get stirred up for these precious–to–Jesus people?

Is it time to put your compassion into action, rather than cross the road? Ask at your church about ways to serve in your area.

 



SoulFood: Jas 3-5, Luke 5:12-26, Ps 96, Prov 3:5-6

content.title: INVENTING A NEW WORD (2)
content.introtext:
'...Faith...if it does not have works, is dead.' James 2:17 NKJ

 

Ever heard the word ‘chuggers’? It’s short for ‘Charity Muggers’, a not very complimentary name for people who stand in the streets stopping passersby, trying to persuade them to sign up and to give money to their cause. Our society doesn’t seem to like ‘chuggers’ very much… But why do they even exist?

Probably because the needs exist, and not enough people are doing/giving enough to fix them. Charities talk about us having ‘donor fatigue’—we’ve seen so many ‘Please, give just $20 a month…’ ads they just don’t have an effect on us anymore.

Contrast that with Mother Theresa, who gave her life to rescuing sick babies and caring for the dying. She said: ‘The biggest disease today isn’t leprosy or cancer. It’s the feeling of being uncared for, unwanted—of being deserted and alone.’ She was asked why she did what she did, and her response? ‘Because Jesus did.’ Hmm.

Of the 1,189 chapters in the Bible, 250 contain the words of the prophets. That’s over 1 in 5. Half of what they say calls out sin and the other half calls out those who see people suffering and do nothing about it. If we call ourselves God’s children—we call ourselves to His action.

Today’s title verse isn’t meant to be a guilt trip, about forcing you to donate regularly to a charity—it’s a reminder that our faith is the sort that has actions partnered with it. If your faith is all words and no action at the moment, you’ll probably find that choosing to serve strengthens your faith. So, if you haven’t yet asked at your church about places to serve, tomorrow would probably be a good opportunity.

 



SoulFood: Num 1-2, Luke 5:27-39, Ps 100, Prov 3:7-8

content.title: HARDWIRED FOR GIVING
content.introtext:
'This High Priest of ours understands our weaknesses, for He faced all of the same testings we do...' Hebrews 4:15 NLT

 

Dr Joseph Parker once told his theology students, ‘Preach to the suffering and you will never lack a congregation. There is a broken heart in every pew.’ Have you ever heard a preacher give a message about suffering that ‘moved your gut’? (Yep, that would be splagchnizomai again, folks.) Some of the most powerful preaching we’ve come across has been when the preacher was the most connected to the hurt in the world. And some of the least when the preacher just... wasn’t.

Jesus gets our brokenness. He went looking for the loser, the lost, the lonely—the lowest. He was comfortable around them. He served them naturally, without a ‘mask’ to hide behind. Serving these people did a lot for them. Just like you can make a real difference to those near you.

Newsflash, though: giving’s not a one–way street. It’s good for you! Yep, there are some major benefits to being a giver. Apparently a survey across 44 major universities suggests that giving actually protects your overall health twice as much as aspirin does against heart disease! (Incredible! God has hardwired the human body to be healthiest when we’re expressing gratitude and actually giving to others! Not that that’s why you should give, but it’s nice to know that God’s planned it to be good for us, isn’t it?)

 



SoulFood: Ezek 47:1-12, Rev 21:22-22:5

content.title: GROW UP AND KEEP GROWING
content.introtext:
'...You need someone to teach you...' Hebrews 5:12 NIV

The end of Hebrews 5 and the beginning of chapter 6 is a bit of a smack–down. The writer of that letter said to his readers that they should really be further on in their understanding of God. It’s pretty blunt: basically saying, ‘Grow up!’

Actually… come to think of it, that’s pretty good advice for all of us. ‘Surely we don’t need to start all over again with the importance of turning away from evil deeds and placing our faith in God. You don’t need further instruction about baptisms, the laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment.’ (Hebrews 6:1–2 NLT) The writer tells us to stop being stuck in a rut with this basic stuff and get on with digging into the meaty principles of following Jesus. Hands up who knows everything there is to know about this Christian life, and about God? Yeah. Thought so. There’s just so much to learn about God and how to live for Him, that we can never say we’re done with learning. Part of being a Christian is being open to absorbing truth that is new to us. That’s why we have sermons in Church. That’s why you’re reading these Bible notes. That’s why there’s a Bible in the first place.

God is eager to pull us deeper into relationship with Him. No matter how much you already know, or don’t know, there is so much for Him to reveal. And, when you devote the time to study Him and ask Him to teach you, He will start to grow you in knowing Him.


SoulFood: Num 3:1-4:33, Luke 6:1-16, Ps 104:1-23, Prov 3:9-10

content.title: CITY WALLS
content.introtext:
'Whoever has no rule over his own spirit is like a city broken down, without walls.' Proverbs 25:28 NKJ

 

Back in ancient times, one of the most effective defences a city could have was whopping great walls around its perimeters. Without those walls, anyone who fancied having a crack at invading could just waltz right in. With them, though, a city had much less chance of being taken over. Walls provided a first line of defence. There’d be trained watchmen stationed on top of them, and the minute they caught sight of an incoming enemy, they’d raise the alarm for the guards to rush to the gates and fight back.

‘Whoever has no rule over his own spirit is like a city broken down, without walls.’ (Proverbs 25:28 NKJ) So, when we don’t bother with self–control, we leave ourselves wide open to an incoming enemy we wouldn’t want to settle down in the city of our soul. The minute we allow ourselves to do just–that–one–thing–we–know–we–shouldn’t, we start to let our walls down. And once those walls are down, it becomes ever–easier to let one more thing slide. And then another thing. And another. And…

You get the idea. The bottom line is this: letting something slide, even one tiny little thing, doesn’t work. We may not feel the impact immediately, but even the smallest thing changes the way we think about what’s right. It draws us a step further away from God. And each step further away makes the next one a little easier to take. So ask the Holy Spirit for His help in growing self–control. And then ask for His help in maintaining it and keeping your walls intact.

 



SoulFood: Num 4:34-6:27, Luke 6:17-26, Ps 104:24-35, Prov 3:11-12

content.title: He Did It.
content.introtext:
'...What must I do to be saved?' Acts 16:30 NIV

An old lady spent her first flight sitting forwards awkwardly in her chair, elbows firmly on both armrests, looking straight ahead for the whole journey. When the plane landed the passenger next to her asked if she’d enjoyed the flight. ‘It was alright,’ she said, ‘but I didn’t put my whole weight on it...’ The punchline: we do the same thing when we try to get along with God based on our own awesomeness—by working harder, praying longer, having a super–lovely personality, or whatever. There’s no way to do work that Jesus has already done for us. Christianity says we’d never be able to walk with God because all the wrong we’ve done acts as a huge obstacle—one we cannot move ourselves. Sin prevents us from seeking or wanting God. We can’t trust in our own ability to get on God’s good side; we just don’t have that ability, any more than old ladies can cruise at ten thousand metres without putting their full weight on the plane. But God’s done something for you. He loves you. So He took the punishment which you justly deserved, pouring His wrath out fully on Jesus—on the Cross. He did it, and only He did it. And the moment you place your trust in Jesus, His sinlessness is placed in you. You’re flying with something you can lean back into with your full weight, and the full forgiveness of God bearing you up and onward. If you haven’t already put your ‘full weight’ on Jesus, today might be the day to start. See http://word4u2day.com.au/Christianity.


SoulFood: 1 Chron 3:1-4:23; Luke 11:29-44; Ps 78:65-72; Pro 20:11-14

content.title: SPRINT OR MARATHON?
content.introtext:
'...When he died...his eyes were not weak nor his strength gone.' Deuteronomy 34:7 NIV

 

Ever heard Christianity described as a race? It’s much less of a sprint, and more of a marathon.

Think of Usain Bolt. His sprint is spectacular. But ask him to keep that speed up for 42 km, though, and he’d end up needing an inhaler and ambulance. It’s impossible to sprint a marathon. Trouble is, so many of us are impressed by the sprinters in church. It’s good to be ‘on fire’ for God (in fact, it’s not only pretty brilliant but what we’re aiming for). But without those steady, do–it–even–when–you–don’t–feel–like–it times of devotion where we let God take the lead, it’s too easy to burn out. There’s nothing wrong with stepping out for God. But Jesus set an example of clocking in regularly for the ‘upward’ God time as well as the ‘outward’ service.

Life is a marathon, not a sprint. King Saul ran like a sprinter. He got out of the blocks well enough but he compromised and ran without God. King David on the other hand, ran marathon style—he waited fifteen years to be crowned King. A lesser athlete would’ve given up years before. Despite his shortcomings (a whole heap of them), the marathon approach meant that, as long as he was heading towards the finish line, there was time to get up again. Ask yourself: do you need to think longer ahead in life than the day or week ahead of you? This is a simple question but it might need lots of mulling–over time.

content.title: WHERE ELSE COULD THIS GO?
content.introtext:
'But seek first the Kingdom of God and His righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.' Matthew 6:33 ESV

 

American pastor and author Francis Chan uses a piece of rope as an illustration. He holds a piece that stretches the length of a stage and points to the very end which is painted red. The majority of the rope is white and he asks us to imagine this representing eternity. The red part represents our lifetime on earth. The red part is insignificant compared to the white. He suggests that too many of us focus on the small red part of the rope when there is a lifetime of white awaiting us.

Most stuff here comes and goes. And where we invest our time, money and energy has a lot to do with that. Using your resources to bless others is going to have a lasting effect in their lives. Now, we aren’t dead set on having a dig at your shopping habits… but holding back on your next impulse–buy will, frankly, leave more room to give generously. Asking ‘where else could this go?’ can apply to anything: time spent watching TV, scrolling through Facebook; whatever, any ‘non–necessities’. We all need rest. We all need chill–space. But sometimes it helps to toughen up on our habits. It leaves that space open for us to pray about where we can invest. What areas of your life do you need to reassess in view of eternity? It’s helpful to keep this question in mind, at least some of the time: when you’re about to impulse–buy or spend an afternoon in front of Quickflix, ask yourself ‘where else could this go?’

SoulFood: Dan 8-10, Luke 4:14-30, Ps 89:15-37, Prov 2:21-22

content.title: DO MORE THAN SURVIVE - FORGIVE
content.introtext:
'...Forgive as the Lord forgave you.' Colossians 3:13 NIV


In 1977 at the age of 14, Sokreaksa Himm saw thirteen members of his family killed by soldiers in the killing fields of Cambodia. Miraculously surviving the massacre, Sokreaksa swore revenge. Years later, after surviving refugee camps and roving death squads, the man became a Christian. Through years of Bible study and prayer, Sokreaksa was able to let go of his hatred and desire for revenge. Through the act of letting go in his heart, he found peace. He describes years of fantasising about torturing his family’s killers. The pain became like a prison that trapped him. Forgiveness unlocked his cell. In time, forgiveness opened up channels for the holy power of wholeness and healing. In the years that followed, he developed a new mission; to find and forgive the killers face to face. Eventually he tracked down two of the soldiers in the very village where the murder had happened. God gave him the strength to shake their hands.

We can learn from this story. Forgiveness isn’t instant—it’s a process. Forgiveness brings you the healing from pain. Forgiveness enables you to do things you never dreamed possible. You’ll survive if you hold grudges against others, you’ll get by—but only just. Forgive them and you’ll thrive. ‘Don’t repay evil for evil. Don’t retaliate with insults when people insult you. Instead, pay them back with blessing. That is what God has called you to do, and He will bless you for it.’ (1 Peter 3:9 NLT)

content.title: NATIVITY WINDOW--HEROD
content.introtext:
'That they should seek the Lord, in the hope that they might...find Him, though He is not far from each one of us.' Acts 17:27 NKJ

 

In the years before Jesus was born in Bethlehem, Herod had become increasingly unsure of the threats to his throne. He’d had three of his sons executed on a bare sniff of treason, as well as one of his wives. So, when a bunch of weary travel–stained wise men turned up looking for a baby born to be ‘King of the Jews’, it was more of a nuisance than a crisis. Herod had dealt with much more menacing problems. So long as no one got to hear about this Baby, it’d be business as usual.

Fast forward two thousand and fourteen years, give or take a few. Herod’s policy is still in play. The Baby born to be King can’t be mentioned in many classrooms. Songs that celebrate His name are deemed too controversial for airplay. Instead there are jingles about a red–clad rotund man who encourages people to wish each other ‘Happy holidays’. Semi-clad women dancing to the songs of misogynistic men are deemed a better form of entertainment than the old, old story about the coming of the Prince of Peace.

But God cannot be silenced—back in Herod’s day or now. No matter how many innocents Herod slaughtered, no matter how many nails his successors ordered hammered into a splintered cross, a new King reigns forever.

Do you know of a mate or two celebrating Christmas without knowing about Christ? Got friends who know about Santa but not the real reason for the season? Send them a text asking them how much they know about Jesus and open yourself up for discussion.

 



SoulFood Christmas Day: Is 7:14, Mt 1:18-25, Mic 5:2-5a, Is 9:6-7

content.title: NATIVITY WINDOW--RELIGIOUS LEADERS
content.introtext:
'Search the Scriptures, for...these are they which testify of Me.' John 5:39 NKJ

 

Not too many people recognised Jesus as the Son of God when He was born. In fact, only a few unnamed shepherds, some equally–anonymous wise men, an old bloke named Simeon and an old woman named Anna seemed to realise. Maybe a dozen all up. Yet, there was enough Scripture flying around at the time definitely pointing to Jesus as the Messiah. Simeon and Anna sussed the truth—so, why did most people miss Him?

Some had buried their heads in Scripture—but were too busy to go ten kilometres from Jerusalem to Bethlehem to check out a manger.

Now, the study of Scripture is absolutely necessary to a relationship with God. It’s one of the healthiest things in life. Don’t think anything different. The unhealthy thing is when you replace living out the Bible with more and more world–ignoring study. When you have more of a relationship with the words than with the Word of life Himself.

Bible reading only works as a part of a wider life. As they say: recommended as part of a healthy lifestyle. We have to use Bible study as one tool in a tool–belt. It should be right there alongside prayer, listening to God’s Spirit, and action. We really need to know Scripture inside out (after all, that’s where those prophecies about Jesus were that most people missed). But we need to keep our eyes open for real–life God–action alongside that.

content.title: FAITH BOOST
content.introtext:
'...The message...did not benefit them, because it was not mixed with faith...' Hebrews 4:2 AMP

 

Catalysts make things happen. Alka–Seltzer without water has no fizz, flour without yeast produces no bread. Faith is the catalyst in your life. Without it, religion is dry. Talking about the Israelites, Paul said, ‘When the good news of deliverance…came to them…the message…did not benefit them, because it was not mixed with faith.’ So: let’s mix it up.

Without faith, reading your Bible turns into intellectual curiosity; sermons become something to critique rather than inspire; church becomes a social club rather than a place of worship. There are no prizes for memorising verses or hymns—unless you use them as stepping stones to action. Faith requires you to move. There’s a difference between what you believe and what you trust. You may believe that a chair can hold you but never sit down; only when you put your full weight on it are you demonstrating trust. Faith is the catalyst to action.

A gold medal requires you to win. The Booker prize requires you to write. An Oscar requires you to make great movies. If you want to see examples of God’s Kingdom coming in and around your life, faith requires action. Do you sense God is calling you to something that feels ‘out there’? Maybe sharing your faith in class or at work, signing up for that mission opportunity, preaching or leading worship for the first time? Get some support. Go for it.

 



SoulFood: Job 32-34, Mt 2:1-8, Ps 97, Ecc 10:20-11:3

content.title: WAIT!
content.introtext:
'...After waiting patiently, Abraham received what was promised.' Hebrews 6:15 NIV

 

What exactly is our part in waiting? Do you wait until God arranges the clouds in the sky to spell ‘NOW!’? Do you take the initiative and expect God to bless your efforts?

Put yourself in Abraham’s shoes. He’d been waiting ten years for the promise made to him—to become ‘a father of many nations’. By now, he was starting to wonder. Perhaps the word was meant poetically—maybe he was going to be a father in a spiritual sense rather than a biological one? Maybe he’d imagined the whole thing. Or maybe he was supposed to take matters into his own hands. Sarah was too old to bear children—you hardly need a degree in biology to see that—so maybe he was supposed to shop around for a surrogate?

Waiting can play terrible tricks on the mind. Abraham would have to wait twenty–four years before seeing the first glimpse of a promise. Even then, one boy hardly made him a father of nations. And yet here we are—thousands of years later—and we know Abraham as the father of our faith (Romans 4:11).

Waiting is difficult because it means we have little control of the future. And let’s face it, we can tend towards a bit of control–freak at times. But God says: ‘You need to persevere, so that when you have done the will of God, you will receive what He has promised.’ (Hebrews 10:36 NIV)

It is said that often the waiting is more important than the receiving. So if you’re waiting on God for a promise fulfilled—it’d be a good idea to keep a journal to track how you’ve developed in the process.

 



SoulFood: Mt 6:5-15, Mt 26:36-46, Jas 5:13-18, 1 Th 5:16-18

content.title: EYES WIDE OPEN
content.introtext:
'... their eyes were opened and they recognised Him...' Luke 24:31 NIV

 

Sometimes, when we’re too busy staring at screens, updating our statuses, consuming what’s in front of us—we miss something greater. God is willing to teach us more about Himself, and to give us amazing opportunities. But it isn’t enough just to ‘get by’ and hope that we’ll find ourselves walking on the clouds all of a sudden.

Looking up to God is how we really ‘see’ things as they are, despite the fact that life often goes on in its usual fashion all around us. It’s a massive deal. And we aren’t just talking about putting life as a whole into perspective or looking at the bigger picture (although focussing on God helps that, too).

Looking to God can set you up for some life–changing moments. Forty years before God’s people entered the promised land, Moses saw it— ‘It was by faith that Moses left the land of Egypt. He was not afraid of the king. Moses kept right on going because he kept his eyes on the One who is invisible.’ (Hebrews 11:27 NLT) Why? He trusted God. Jesus spent most of His life on earth not being recognised for who He was—people just didn’t ‘see’ it. In Mark 10:46–52 he met a man born blind. A man who had to beg to earn money, who couldn’t see the ground he sat on, but who recognised Jesus as the long–awaited Messiah. That’s a great reminder for us all to look up and see God, and not down at our earthly circumstances. So, ask God to open your eyes to the awe and wonder all around you and to what He is doing in your world today.

 



SoulFood: Job 35-37, Mt 2:9-15, Ps 139:1-12, Ecc 11:4-6

content.title: OB-STUCK-LESS?
content.introtext:
'...Remove the obstacles out of the way.' Isaiah 57:14 NIV

 

Running a marathon is just too easy these days—right? Yeah, we thought so, too. Alongside the more traditional road races, a new breed of adrenaline–pumping running challenges are springing up all over the world. Take the ‘Spartan Race’ for example. As well as a steep and arduous course, the Spartan chucks in an extra challenge: obstacles.

And not just any obstacles. On the Spartan, you’ll find yourself swimming through mud, scaling craggy walls, crawling under barbed wire, heaving tractor tyres and hurling javelins. Nice. Not.

Very few of us are up for this kind of competition. Yet surprisingly, we probably scrabble through life doing a Spartan without realising. Yup. We can put up, invite in, and stubbornly leave emotional and spiritual obstacles in our way that stop us from really running ‘with endurance the race that is set before us.’ (Hebrews 12:1 NLT)

Perhaps during this edition of word4U2day, you’ve already been reminded of an obstacle that stops you from getting close to God. Holding on to such an obstacle will only lead to more hurt and less freedom. We’re not asking to you to try to be perfect, but rather to turn your imperfections over to God. So, be real with Him. Share your thoughts with Him. Turn around and thank Him for His ability to undo any tricky situation you find yourself in.

 



SoulFood: Job 38-39, Mt 2:16-23, Ps 139:13-24, Ecc 11:7-10

content.title: LINGERING LEGACIES
content.introtext:
'A good man leaves an inheritance...' Proverbs 13:22 NIV

 

‘Legacy’: a gift handed down from the past. Ok, this is not about getting; it’s about giving. About a question that hangs invisibly over each of our lives: what kind of legacy do I want to leave behind? What am I going to contribute to society to make it a better place after I’m gone? Just what kind of world do I want my kids, or whoever comes after me, to be living in?

You’ve probably never given this a thought. Our current culture of rampant consumerism doesn’t encourage you to think this way: the idea our culture promotes is that life is all about you in the now, you in the thrill of the new, you in the very midst of the experience you can enjoy right here, right now.

The Bible stops us in our tracks and makes us ask: am I here to consume or here to leave a legacy? God is a God of the long view. He doesn’t set us up for the quick win: ‘Whoever believes will not be in haste.’ (Isaiah 28:16 ESV)

Whatever stage in your education/work/life you are in right now, and whatever opportunities are floating around you, here’s a challenge as we move into a new year: Are you going to take every chance in your life for yourself, without thinking of others, or leave a legacy that will advance the Kingdom of God and peace, justice, mercy and truth with it? If you’re thinking about a New Year’s resolution for tomorrow, perhaps it should revolve around the bigger picture than just your personal goals for 2015. Now’s the time to talk to God about legacy planning.

 



SoulFood: Job 40-42, Mt 3:1-12, Ps 116, Ecc 12:13-14

content.title: CHURCH (GROWTH) HISTORY 1: Beginnings
content.introtext:
'...And the Lord added to the church daily.' Acts 2:47 NKJ

 

As the New Year begins, let’s think back to the beginnings of the church.

What started as an apprenticeship group around Jesus has spread to the four corners of the globe, taking root in many and varied cultures and in many and varied languages. Churches meet in homes, stadiums, in secret, in public spaces; some are loud, some are quiet… Globally, around two billion people make up the worldwide Church family. Reports suggest more people are becoming Christians today than at any other point in human history, even though the Bible has only been translated into 500 of the 7000 languages in the world.

How did this begin? Well, with just the first disciples. They believed in Jesus, not just as the One sent to redeem the world but as their personal Saviour. Jesus told a parable of a great banquet. The master of the house wanted his table full: ‘Then the master told his servant, “Go out to the roads and country lanes and compel them to come in, so that my house will be full.”’ (Luke 14:23 NIV) God loves for people to ‘come in’ to His family. His heart is for those of us who know what being a part of it is like to share it with others.

A New Year challenge: what ways can you, as part of the Church, do more this year to urge people to ‘come in’ and discover God’s great banquet for themselves?

content.title: CHURCH (GROWTH) HISTORY 2: Make Disciples
content.introtext:
'My people are destroyed for lack of knowledge.' Hosea 4:6 NKJ

 

The first Church grew in a world without smartphones, social media, TV or even magazines. So how did it spread? Simply by people passing on the truth about Jesus to other people. They would write letters (like Paul writing to Christians in Rome or Corinth). But more often they would just spend time showing people how to live for God in word and action.

The first Christians didn’t cling onto the truth like a gift to be hidden, so they didn’t lose it. As vital as it is, they were ready to give it away to anyone who would listen. They travelled as far and as wide as they could, passing on the world–shakingly Good News. Those first disciples have long gone, but the fearless Spirit that drove them lives on. Now it’s our turn to pass on the knowledge—the truth we have learnt about Jesus.

Contrary to what you might be thinking, you don’t need to be a theology hero for this. Acts 1:8 says that God is asking each one of us to be a ‘witness’. The job of a witness is simply to say what they’ve seen, what they have experienced. So don’t worry if you’re not an expert, don’t worry about making a mistake, just tell it like it is.

Passion is infectious. Passion helps pass on knowledge. Probably a fair few of us chose to live for God because of a passionate Christian youth leader, friend or family member in our lives. Be the most passionate, enthusiastic follower of Jesus you can be, and other people will catch that passion too.

content.title: CHURCH (GROWTH) HISTORY 3: Dynamo
content.introtext:
'... they were all filled with the Holy Spirit.' Acts 4:31 NKJ

 

It turns out cars don’t work so well with empty fuel tanks. Sometimes God asks us to do things that really stretch and challenge us, but He always provides fuel for the task.

The first Christians were tasked with something quite huge: ‘Go, then, to all peoples everywhere and make them My disciples.’ (Matthew 28:19 GNT) But whilst Jesus was still physically with His disciples He said that He would not abandon them like orphans but would send someone to comfort, counsel and encourage them, as well as remind them of everything He said and did. That ‘someone’ is the Holy Spirit.

The Holy Spirit is available to all people. He is a source of power, of peace, of God’s presence, of authority, confidence, faith. He is the greatest counsellor, the best encourager, the most gracious comforter. If you’re ever in a difficult situation, you only have to ask and He gives you the words to say. More than this, like a dynamo, the Holy Spirit doesn’t just give us that first moment of belief that allowed us to see Jesus, but He works through us, on and on, giving us the motion to keep believing, even when times get tough.

The Holy Spirit is the dynamic power of God available to all people who simply say, ‘God, please come and fill me!’ At the end of our prayers we often say AMEN. This word is more than a religious full stop. It’s one of the oldest words in human language, and means ‘let it be’, ‘I agree’, or our favourite, ‘bring it on!’ So today pray, ‘God fill me with your Holy Spirit. Bring it on!’

 



SoulFood: Lev 1-4, Luke 1:11-25, Ps 10:1-11, Prov 1:8-16

content.title: CHURCH (GROWTH) HISTORY 4: Community
content.introtext:
'The new wine is found in the cluster...' Isaiah 65:8 NKJ

 

Jesus’ first miracle was turning water into wine at a wedding reception. He loved spending time with people at huge get–togethers. So He didn’t have the best reputation with the Pharisees: they called him a ‘friend of sinners’. Problem is, there aren’t many people (in fact any, except for Jesus Himself), who aren’t ‘sinners’, left to their own devices. And that includes people inside the Church, too. Christianity is best done with others—and none of those others is perfect. (We hope this doesn’t come as a surprise, but you are one of the ‘others’ to someone!)

The fact the Church is designed as a community is a strength. Church should be a community marked by love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self control (in case you didn’t spot it, this is from Galatians 5:22–23, the Fruit of the Spirit).

There’s a challenge in today’s reading. Something for any of us who go to church every week (good habit!) Are we adding to the generous, inclusive, welcoming atmosphere that makes the Church a breath of fresh air? ‘Out there’ in the world, it’s all too easy to find that most people have layers of pretence that cover up their real selves. So, when the Church makes room for people to be real, it’s on to something. It’s time to do our bit.

content.title: REWARDS THAT MATTER
content.introtext:
'...He will reward each person according to what he has done.' Matthew 16:27 NIV

 

So, we like our faith to be clear. And one thing we hope you can see clear as daylight is this: choosing to believe in Jesus is life–saving. And life–changing. And that’s non–negotiable. Paul tells it to us straight in Romans 8:37–39. Read it and let it sink in: ‘…neither death nor life, neither angels nor demons, neither the present nor the future’ are going to prevent Jesus from holding out His nail–pierced hand for you to reach.

‘Oh, so that’s it then?’ you might think. ‘Don’t my selfless acts count for anything?’ Well, first up: be careful. Make sure your self–sacrifice isn’t a secret longing for recognition or that you’re hiding a selfish motive. We all have to be on guard: being a ‘cheerful giver’ (2 Corinthians 9:7) means you shouldn’t be checking your inbox every hour for a ‘thanx’ from the struggling person you sent a gift.

But, at the same time, it’s true there are things that count toward your eternal ‘reward’. Your God–inspired acts of kindness. That encouragement/gift may never come back round to you, but look at today’s verse—God sees it all. He’s got you. And money/success/fame? They are, at their best, a means of making God known to the world. They won’t be coming with us to Heaven, so treat them that way, too. Don’t prioritise them over serving others for God.

 



SoulFood: Lev 8-10, Luke 1:39-56, Ps 42:1-5, Prov 1:20-23

content.title: SELF: MADE
content.introtext:
'...The humble...retain honour.' Proverbs 29:23 NKJ

 

The first lie ever told was one that appealed directly to our oh–so–human sense of pride. Satan told Adam and Eve that, if they ate the fruit that God had told them not to, they definitely wouldn’t die. He said they’d become just like God instead (that’s in Genesis 3, by the way). That lie was a lie of power, and of status and, well, Adam and Eve bought it. A lot of people would have done the same; after all, we’re mostly inclined to follow our own egos. That’s why Satan hasn’t had to update that particular battle tactic since Eden. He still tells us lies about ourselves, to try and get the upper hand. Whether they’re lies that flatter our ego and make us think we’re so much better than everyone else, or lies that lead us to believe we’re losers compared to everyone else, Satan tries to make us forget God’s truth about us. And that’s so not healthy. The only way we can have a really, truly good view of ourselves is if that view comes from God. In the Psalms, David talks about being ‘fearfully and wonderfully made’ (Psalm 139:14 NIV), and that’s exactly right. We are wonderful. YOU are wonderful, because God made you. And, because God made you, you are HIS. Every human being is unique, and equal. No better, and no worse, than anyone else. Let’s start to live like it!

content.title: LIVING BY LAWS (1)
content.introtext:
'A new command I give you: Love one another.' John 13:34 NIV

 

A newspaper told a story about a boy going through chemotherapy and losing his hair. In support, his classmates shaved their heads too. When he returned to school he looked no different to any of the others. The paper carried a picture of these bald–headed students, with the headline, ‘Everything we do; we do together.’ That’s the ‘law of love’ Jesus talks about: ‘A new command I give you: Love one another.’ Even when it stings a bit.

People live by many laws. There’s the ‘law of revenge’ which says, ‘You hurt me; I hurt you harder.’ There’s the ‘law of balance’ which asks ‘an eye for an eye.’ But Jesus’ system storms the law court. It goes against our feelings. It’s a system that asks to turn a cheek and walk an extra mile. It’s the kind of justice that offers to love the enemy or pray for the persecutor. The law of love means you don’t have to get even; you can forgive. It isn’t weak or a walk–over; it’s strong enough to put others first and it chooses to withhold the punch.

1 Corinthians 13: 4–7 NLT says it well: ‘Love is patient and kind. Love is not jealous or boastful or proud or rude. It does not demand its own way. It is not irritable, and it keeps no record of being wronged. It does not rejoice about injustice but rejoices whenever the truth wins out. Love never gives up, never loses faith, is always hopeful…’

content.title: LIVING BY LAWS (2)
content.introtext:
Above all, clothe yourselves with love...' Colossians 3:14 NLT

 

Is it possible a 2015 application of the Good Samaritan might look a bit like this?

A man was attacked by thugs. A pastor saw him and crossed the road, leaving him for dead. A bunch of other folk saw him and crossed the road. But then this random church–goer came, saw and took pity on the man. He stooped down, tucked a Gospel tract into the man’s pocket and went to leave. The critically–injured man was barely conscious but held out a hand for help. The church–goer stopped and was filled with pity. So he carefully took the man through the booklet and pointed him towards some helpful resources online. Finally he invited the dying man to a church service the following Sunday. Then he left. He was disappointed that the man never showed up (being, as he was, otherwise engaged in the ICU unit of the hospital with stab wounds.)

The modern church places great emphasis on getting people into church meetings and courses. We promote prayer and study and fellowship. Not that these are bad things, but what about love? Jesus never said, ‘And they will know you by your extensive knowledge and inerrant doctrine.’ His emphasis was on demonstrating love. Clearly the wounded man needed bandaging and medical help. William Booth who founded the Salvation Army is just one of many followers of Jesus who believed in feeding and caring for the person as well as giving them the Good News—because it is part of the Good News. Be alert this week to ways you can care for others. Trust that doing good will lead to opportunities to share the Gospel in a meaningful way.

 



SoulFood: Lev 15-17, Luke 2:1-7, Ps 46, Prov 1:32-33

content.title: THRASH IT OUT
content.introtext:
'...You are members of God's family.' Ephesians 2:19 NLT

 

Working out differences with others helps to mature us in our faith. Arguments give us the chance to learn. Even disagreements can be an occasion to celebrate diversity. Some difficult stuff can be a chance to take a humble step back and ‘turn the other cheek’. Yes, we certainly wouldn’t advise you to go looking for ways to fall out or get stabbed in the back, but when we bring these things before God in prayer, He can really use them for our good.

Years ago, people would huddle together round a television or a record player. But technology now is geared to our own personal, even private, entertainment experience. Life can become like that too—so walled–off and private that we no longer feel we need others so much. Community, though, breaks down our walls. We come face to face with what we dislike in others and in ourselves. Working through disagreements can show us how to respect other peoples’ personalities—yes, don’t seek out arguments, but don’t necessarily run from ‘healthy debates’ when they flare up. God lives in community (Father, Spirit, Son) and, made in His image, we were made for community too. So make sure you aren’t going it alone and meet regularly with other Christians.

And if you’re stuck in an argument you can’t get out of, give it a rest for a bit. Stop thinking about what the other person has said, and think about where you could sensibly and generously give ground.

content.title: SMACKED DOWN
content.introtext:
'...If you suffer for doing good ... this is commendable...' 1 Peter 2:20 NIV

 

Sticks and stones may break my bones but words will… stamp on my heart with lead boots.

So how do you just get on with your life with a size ten studded footprint in your soul? Well, let’s take a look at the Son of God, giving sight to the blind and hearing to the deaf and raising children from the dead—and what thanks does He get? ‘Devil child!’ ‘He’s possessed—by Satan, no less!’ Huh.

Yet Jesus refuses to back down. He continues to heal and help. He knows what He is here for and nothing will deter Him from it. When you know what you’re here for, you’ll do the same. People are entitled to their opinions but it doesn’t mean they’re right. Yes, they can mock you. But between you and God, you know the truth.

Jesus didn’t try to look good; He was good. He didn’t try to be truthful; He was truth. Despite leading this blameless life, He still faced insult. His followers did too, and they followed in His steps: ‘The apostles left the Sanhedrin, rejoicing because they had been counted worthy of suffering disgrace for the Name [of Jesus].’ (Acts 5:41 NIV) Words are important and they can hurt. But. God’s words about you are true, and as you go through day to day life, you can probably see why it’s worth having them handy.

If you’re being insulted or accused by people—pray for them. Pray blessings for them. Why? Because it’s the Jesus way. (And it’s a pretty powerful one.)

 



SoulFood: 1 Sam 3:1-11, Act 9:1-9

content.title: SYMPATHY AND STRENGTH
content.introtext:
'For the despairing man there should be kindness from his friend...' Job 6:14 NAS

 

It’s when life comes crashing in on us that we need the love, the sympathy and the support of our friends the most. Poor Job longed for it, but didn’t get it. In the midst of his suffering his friends offered him no more than churchy clichés and pious platitudes.

Job needs what we all need when we’re suffering—not someone to try and explain why things are happening or even to suggest strategies for how to cope with it, but just someone to be with us, and share our pain. That’s the real meaning of sympathy: not someone saying ‘there, there’ but someone actually being there. Sympathy says, ‘I understand what you’re going through and I’m here for you.’ Sympathy acknowledges our struggles and gives us the strength to overcome them.

Even when there seems to be no one around who can sympathise with your struggles, there is. Jesus sympathises with us—He can, because He’s been through the full spectrum of pain and suffering: ‘For we do not have a High Priest who is unable to sympathise with our weaknesses, but one who in every respect has been tempted as we are, yet without sin.’ (Hebrews 4:15–16 ESV) Jesus is the great High Priest mentioned here. Think He hasn’t been tempted like you have? Think again! With this in mind, ask the Holy Spirit to show you someone who is hurting today, and pray for an opportunity to show sympathy in an appropriate way.

 



SoulFood: Lev 21:1-23:25, Luke 2:21-33, Ps 71:17-24, Prov 2:3-5

content.title: EPIC FAIL?
content.introtext:
'I have prayed for you that your faith may not fail...' Luke 22:32 ESV

 

We all know how it feels to fail. Perhaps you’re used to hearing a voice inside your head repeating, ‘You’ve let all these people down… but most of all you’ve let yourself down.’ Ouch. At times like these, we need to remember Jesus’ disciple Peter. Perhaps no one in history has felt the weight of failure like he did. After promising he would never turn his back on Jesus, Peter publicly disowned Him, and felt the crushing, agonising pain of his own failure (Luke 22:54–62).

That’s why we need to start telling the hopeful truth about failure. Yes, the hopeful truth. First: failure is inevitable. Don’t believe the lie: ‘If you were a real Christian, you wouldn’t have failed like that.’ When you put your trust in Jesus, He set you free from the law of sin and death, but your human emotions, appetites and desires are still at war with the Spirit at work inside you (Galatians 5:17). By His grace, you’re not the person you were, but you’re not the person you’re going to be either.

But also, notice what Jesus said to Peter before this all happened: ‘I have prayed for you...’ (Luke 22:32 ESV) Even in the middle of Peter’s ‘epic fail’, Jesus was in control. He was going to use this, the most painful episode in Peter’s life, to begin something amazing and new. Read for yourself the way Jesus restored Peter and how reconciliation made way for Jesus to use him in the future (John 21:15–19). Thank Him that He’ll use even the ugly parts of us to bring about something pretty wonderful.

 



SoulFood: Lev 23:26-25:55, Luke 2:34-40, Ps 74:1-11, Prov 2:6

content.title: STEPHEN AND THE SEVEN (1)
content.introtext:
'...And they chose Stephen...' Acts 6:5 NKJ

 

Growth often brings problems. The early church had grown so fast (like a dozen or so to 3000 on the first day!) so the demands on it grew too, and especially as they related to serving the poor. People shared so wonderfully to start with that there wasn’t a needy person among them (Acts 4:34). But slowly the early church stopped focusing on helping the poor and started discriminating against certain racial groups (Acts 6:1).

What to do? Make no mistake, this was a significant issue: remember what Jesus had to say about both serving the poor and preserving unity among believers (e.g. Matthew 25:35–40, John 17:21). In other words, it was a big deal when the apostles decided to delegate this one out. It meant they needed to choose carefully from the possible candidates. In the end, they let the community pick seven men, but they gave them a bunch of criteria to follow: the men needed to be ‘of good reputation, full of the Spirit and of wisdom.’ (Acts 6:3 NAS)

We’ll look at each in turn over the next few days. First of all, what does it mean to be ‘of good reputation’? And why does it matter? Proverbs 22:1 NLT says, ‘Choose a good reputation over great riches; being held in high esteem is better than silver or gold.’ Can you think of an example from someone in public life who has sacrificed a ‘good reputation’ for ‘gold’? Get some friends to pray with you for them today.

 



SoulFood: Lev 26-27, Luke 2:41-52, Ps 74:12-23, Prov 2:7-8

content.title: STEPHEN AND THE SEVEN (2)
content.introtext:
'Choose...men...full...of the Spirit.' Acts 6:3 NIV

 

As we saw yesterday, the seven men chosen to serve in Acts 6:1–6 were not picked on a whim. Their job was far too important to turn just anyone loose on it. So we see three things that the apostles were looking for; three things they thought were absolutely essential to do this important job: a good reputation, and being full of both the Holy Spirit and wisdom.

Why’s it so important to be full of the Holy Spirit as a leader in the church? Let’s think about why Jesus promised the Spirit in the first place. In John 14:26 ESV, Jesus said, ‘But the Helper, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in My name, He will teach you all things and bring to your remembrance all that I have said to you.’ Jesus talks about the Spirit as a Helper, sent with a purpose: to teach His followers and to remind them of everything Jesus taught.

In order to go about Jesus’ business, these seven men needed all the love, compassion and grace of Jesus Himself. Hence why they needed to be full of the Holy Spirit. The same is true of anyone who would serve in Jesus’ name. The poor don’t need us, they need Jesus. We don’t have the power to reconcile fragmented communities; only Jesus does. Start to think of a mission activity you are involved with (street outreach? Alpha course? Youth group?) in this light: Jesus hasn’t sent you alone; He’s empowered you by His Spirit.

content.title: STEPHEN AND THE SEVEN (3)
content.introtext:
'Choose...men...full of...wisdom.' Acts 6:3 NIV

 

‘Seven men of good reputation, full of the Holy Spirit and… wisdom.’ Yesterday we saw how the Spirit would ensure the men were kept on track by the close presence of Jesus through His Spirit. So what extra benefit is meant by including ‘wisdom’ in this list? What wisdom would be lacking if they already had the words of Jesus echoing round their heads?

‘Wisdom’ here likely refers to the knowledge, skills and insights gained by experience of working with people in real life and business, and the study of the Scriptures. These men were not pretty faces—they had substance. Perhaps they were experienced businessmen or leaders in their family households. They had something specific to bring to the task.

Very occasionally, God takes a man or a woman with no prior experience in what He’s calling them to—and teaches them everything they need to know on the job. But much more often, God carefully (if sometimes unusually) prepares people for the job He has in mind for them (think Moses, David, Paul). So you don’t need to go to Bible College to influence people in church, but that’s the route God sends most leaders. God can prepare you to lead and serve His people wisely in any sphere of life—in the words of your career advisor, these are ‘transferable skills’. Track down someone you consider to be a wise leader and ask them how God prepared them to serve Him. (And how about you offer to buy the coffee). You might be surprised by what you learn.

content.title: STEPHEN AND THE SEVEN (4)
content.introtext:
'...Stephen, a man full of faith...' Acts 6:5 NIV

 

Just one more thing before we move on from our look at what qualified Stephen and the Seven for being used by God. Stephen is picked out as ‘a man full of faith.’ Maybe that’s a pointer to what’s about to come—in just a few verses’ time, Stephen will launch into a sermon so powerful and insightful it gets him killed. As Stephen knew, faith isn’t just what you believe, it’s what you say and it’s what you do.

How do we remain ‘full of faith’ like Stephen? (Without the getting killed bit, of course.) One thing is to feed it. The Bible is faith food. It says, ‘…faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of Christ.’ (Romans 10:17 ESV) That’s not just a verse about what happens when you find faith for the first time—it’s about the daily nourishing effect of reading God’s Word in the Bible. If word4U2day is your only spiritual ‘food’, you’re just not going to see the same growth as if you get stuck into SoulFood as well. You need to feast on Scripture itself—the more the better.

The other way to stay ‘full of faith’ is to use it. Faith is a bit like a muscle—exercise it and it’ll grow strong; don’t and it will grow weak and flabby. If you exercise regularly and get used to flexing it in all the different areas of your life, you’ll find yourself increasingly ‘full of faith’ like Stephen. Think about how you might flex your faith muscles in each of these situations: when you find out a friend is sick; when you hear of a financial need in a local ministry; when your church asks for volunteers to serve.

 



SoulFood: Dan 3-4, Luke 3:21-38, Ps 84, Prov 2:16-19

content.title: SIMPLY DOING GOOD
content.introtext:
'He went about doing good... for God was with Him.' Acts 10:38 ESV

 

One of the most amazing things about Jesus is His approach to time management. As Peter preaches to the Gentiles about Jesus in Acts 10, one of the key things he mentions is that Jesus ‘went about doing good.’ He was a man in demand with the not insignificant task of training twelve men to lead a movement that would change the world. Yet central to His ministry was simply ‘doing good’.

Throughout the Gospels, we see Jesus’ agenda interrupted by the demands of seemingly random people. But every story was selected by the Gospel writers for a reason; nothing arrived by accident. So what are they trying to tell us? Surely that what we see is in His life is a glimpse of what He would do in His death: Jesus laid down His life for others.

Following Jesus means doing the same—laying down our lives as He laid down His. That’s a hard thing to do, and, to be honest, we’re experts at finding reasons not to obey it: I need to work these extra hours to provide for my family. I need skip that, so I can study more for these exams. I need to hang on to that money because I deserve that holiday.

But if we let them, Jesus’ words cut through our excuses: ‘If you try to hang on to your life, you will lose it. But if you give up your life for My sake, you will save it.’ (Matthew 16:25 NLT) How do you tend to respond when God tries to interrupt your inflexible, tightly–organised, written–in–concrete schedule and asks you to make time for someone who’s hurting?

content.title: TRACE YOUR PLACE
content.introtext:
'...That you may not bear it yourself alone.' Numbers 11:17 NKJ

 

At some point in our lives, we’ve all felt inferior. Not needed. On the outside looking in. Like we don’t fit—anywhere. And it hurts.

Take Church as an example: it can be SO easy in a world that seems to be run by outgoing extrovert types to believe that centre–stage is where the cool dudes hang out. But this is wrong, and there’s a bigger picture to look at. The best job you can possibly do is the one God has given you the gifts to fulfil. It’s more than likely your church is full of people who need someone to encourage them. An outcast who needs a friend. A tech desk that needs a faithful worker. A project that needs volunteers.

Is this an aspiration–knockdown? Well, you’ll be pleased to know we aren’t telling you to wash prayer meeting coffee mugs until the end of time. But God is always ready to teach someone and lead them into their ‘calling’—and that can start small. Starting with people who know you can be an ace way to trace your way into your calling.

Bottom line: get to know yourself. Praying and learning about your abilities/personality type can be really helpful. Why? Because you can relax, knowing that God ‘set His faithful people apart for Himself.’ (Psalm 4:3 NIV) Make an appointment to meet up with someone you trust, and ask them what they think your gifts are. (Perhaps the same person you found for January 16.) Commit to challenge each other to put them to service, then meet up one month later to see what came from it.

content.title: Get God's Opinion (2)
content.introtext:
'Don't let anyone look down on you...' 1 Timothy 4:12 NIV

You can't live a life that's not your own. It's really important to accept the guidance of others, and to take on board any gentle nudges (or steel-toed kicks too, come to think of it) God might give to you through your fellow human beings. However, it's not up to other people to determine what's for you and what isn't. Just because your parents want you to be a doctor, doesn't automatically mean that's what God wants. You've got to have an open enough mind for God to guide you to what you should be doing, even if it's entirely different to what your friends and family think you should be doing.

The world defines 'success' differently from God. The most successful person in God's Kingdom isn't necessarily a CEO in an Armani suit. So, defy the world's expectations. God does. Paul told Timothy, 'Don't let anyone look down on you because you are young,' because people thought Timothy was an inexperienced kid. It's easy to let other people decide what your life should look like, and just assume they're right because they're older or cleverer or genuinely lovely. But Paul thought differently; and so does God. So get God's opinion. In the end it's the only one that counts.



SoulFood: Ezra 3-5, Lk 9:46-62, Ps 78:1-8, Prov 19:21-23

content.title: Breakthrough
content.introtext:
'...They called the name of that place Baal Perazim.' 1 Chronicles 14:11 NKJ

There was a man. They called him David. King David. And the Philistines invaded his part of the land of Israel. (They had a history... David the Israelite vs. Goliath the Philistine. Awkward.) But before David slapped on his swordbelt, He checked with God. He said, 'Shall I go up against the Philistines? Will You deliver them into my hand?' and God replied, 'Go up... I will...' so David fought and defeated the Philistines through God's power (1 Chronicles 14). 'Afterwards, David said, "God has broken through my enemies by my hand like a breakthrough of water." Therefore they called the name of that place Baal Perazim (which means "breaking through").' (1 Chronicles 14: 9-11 NKJ)

What do we learn here?

(1) David reminded himself that 'the Lord had made him king' (1 Chronicles 14:2). God called you, and His Spirit lives inside you. You are His. He is on your side. That's huge.

(2) David simply asked God, 'Shall I go up against the Philistines?' (1 Chronicles 14:10 NKJ) Seriously. Just ask God. What is He telling you to do? Obey that, and you'll come out on top.

(3) David gave God the credit: 'God has broken through my enemies.' (1 Chronicles 14:11 NKJ) God does amazing things. Sometimes He does them for you, sometimes He does them through you. When He does something good, let the world know. When the breakthrough comes for you, make sure you remember to tell everyone Who made it happen. Sing His praises whenever you can.



SoulFood: Ezra 6-8, Lk 10:1-15, Ps 78:9-16, Prov 19:24-26

content.title: Courage with Cold Feet
content.introtext:
'Benaiah...went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion.' 2 Samuel 23:20 NIV

Benaiah was the warrior in charge of all King David’s bodyguards. He went into a pit on a winter’s day, maybe to shelter from the cold. Just as his feet were defrosting, he found a new pit buddy: a lion. Maybe it had come in for shelter too. Or more likely, it was hungry and at most fearless in the scarce winter months. Benaiah couldn’t turn and run because he’d only meet a wall. He had to fight, or he’d die. The strongest animal in Israel was staring him down, snow steaming off its flanks. Benaiah’s courage, especially with cold feet, is the reason he is a famously valiant member of King David’s mightiest men. Because there was no middle ground to hide in, he fought the lion and killed it. Thousands of years later, God and His people still look at this personality trait as characteristic of the God–centred soul: boldness, right at the moment that fear threatens to swamp you. Think: when you can’t keep any more distance from the thing you’re afraid of, how do you respond? What puts steel in your spine when fear presses in? If you’re frozen with fear, for any reason, a good idea would be to ask some Christian friends if you can all meet up and pray about it. While it’s great to ask for advice, praying together is much more powerful. Because praying together lets God in on the problem.



SoulFood: Ezra 9-10; Luke 10:16-28; Ps 78:17-31; Pro 19:27-29

content.title: Read and Run
content.introtext:
'And the Lord answered me: "Write the vision; make it plain on tablets, so he may run who reads it."' Habakkuk 2:2 ESV

In today’s verse, Habakkuk the prophet had been given the job of getting God’s message out to everyone in Israel. Big ask. To do this he had to write down God’s message on tablets (no, this was not like an iPad, more like an iRock.) The idea was for Habakkuk to write God’s words down so that, like an athlete in a relay race, he could pass them on to the next runner quickly. Then that runner would pass them on to the next, and so on until the message was spread around the land. People would be able to share the message quickly because it was a clear message, an obvious message; anyone could get it. God always does this when He has an important message: He makes it clear. He makes it simple. Remember how He introduced Himself to Moses at the burning bush? ‘I AM!’ Think of the most popular verse in the Bible, too: ‘For God so loved the world that He gave His one and only Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish but have eternal life.’ (John 3:16 NIV) Some of the Bible is tricky to understand, but the important stuff isn’t. So how are you introducing God to others? Is it in a way they can simply and quickly understand? For some people, the idea that ‘God is real!’ needs to be the first thing they hear. For others, the fact God is loving is a brand new concept. What message has God given you to share?

content.title: A Way Past Worry (1)
content.introtext:
'Don't worry about anything; instead, pray about everything.' Philippians 4:6 NLT

What happens when you’re praying instead of worrying? What feeds your worries? Until you can express your fears you can’t get rid of them. Putting your worries into words strips them of much of their power. In the book Life of Pi, Yann Martel’s main character, Pi, finds himself adrift at sea on a lifeboat with a 200kg Bengal tiger as his companion. While on the lifeboat, Pi begins to analyse his fears, both of the sea and the tiger. He gives this counsel: ‘You must fight hard to express your [fear]. You must fight hard to shine the light of words upon it. Because if you don’t, if your fear becomes a wordless darkness that you avoid, perhaps even manage to forget, you open yourself to further attacks of fear because you never truly fought the opponent who defeated you.’ So pull back the curtain and expose your fears, each and every one. They’re creatures of darkness and can’t stand the sunlight. Financial fears, relationship fears, professional fears, safety fears—call them out in prayer. Drag them out and make them stand before God. How do you do that? ‘Don’t worry about anything; instead, pray about everything… Then you will experience God’s peace, which exceeds anything we can understand…’ (Philippians 4:6–7 NLT) Send your fear packing. Pray, now. God’s the one who can act on the object of your fear, but the act of praying will also reassure you that you’re not being controlled by fear.



SoulFood: John 1:1-14; Matt 4:12-16; Matt 5:14-16; Acts 9:1-19

content.title: A Way Past Worry (2)
content.introtext:
'...I tell you not to worry about everyday life...' Matthew 6:25 NLT

Jesus said, ‘Therefore I tell you, stop being perpetually uneasy (anxious and worried) about your life…’ (Matthew 6:25 AMP) Not because the stuff you’re worrying about doesn’t exist, but because committing it all to God throws our focus back on the One who can fully care for us, has cared for us, and is going to carry on caring for us. Philippians 4:6–7 NKJ says, ‘...let your requests be made known to God. And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.’ And the Phillips version puts it like this, ‘Don’t worry over anything whatever; tell God every detail of your needs in earnest and thankful prayer, and the peace of God which transcends human understanding, will keep constant guard over your hearts and minds as they rest in Christ Jesus.’ (Philippians 4:6–7 PHPS) When you’re more caught up in your love for God than concerned with getting over your worry, you often find that the worry melts off like candle wax anyway. So let your problems drive you into the arms of Jesus. And when you get there, stay there. Isn’t it odd how trying not to worry can become just another thing to worry about? Shouldn’t it be easy, this whole ‘not worrying’ thing? So go to God right now, tell Him all those worries and leave them with Him. If you start to worry again, say, ‘Sorry, Lord. I took back what I’d given You.’ And keep doing this until His peace really does keep guard over your heart.



SoulFood: 1 John 3:11-5:21; Luke 11:1-13; Ps 78:40-55; Pro 20:4-6

content.title: The Barriers are in Your Mind
content.introtext:
'...He has sent me to proclaim freedom...recovery...release...favour.' Luke 4:18-19 NIV

If you look at ancient maps, you’ll see places which are marked with pictures of sea monsters (‘Here Be Dragons,’ that sort of thing) to warn off sailors. Were the dragons real? Well, they were real enough in the minds of the sailors. Think of a barracuda in an aquarium tank. A glass barrier divides one half from the other. Each time the barracuda tries to swim at it, it bumps into it. Ouch! Eventually, even if the barrier is taken away, the barracuda still won’t swim beyond that point—because, yep, it’s learned the ‘ouch’ point. The barrier is still in its mind. Jesus was sent to proclaim freedom, recovery and release. Satan will place barriers in your mind that say you can’t go beyond a certain point in life. The barriers are lies. But a lie is as effective as the truth if you believe it and act on it. The Bible is filled with stories of people who were thought to be too ‘little’ or way too insignificant to matter. Those same people went on to smash through barriers they thought they couldn’t. God used them to do amazing things. He’ll do that for you too, no matter how small or limited you feel, if you ask for it. A lie is as effective as the truth when you believe it. Christians are people of the truth, so ask God for His help to see where you or other people are struggling believing wrong things about themselves. Pray for ways to join Jesus today in proclaiming freedom, recovery and release.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 1-2; Luke 11:14-28; Ps 78:56-64; Pro 20:7-10
