content.title: Christian Lingo Bingo
content.introtext:
'...Each of you must...speak truthfully to his neighbour...' Ephesians 4:25 NIV

Christian lingo: that strange language that means we say, ‘Wow, that guy is really anointed at playing guitar’ instead of ‘nice guitar playing, friend.’ Sometimes to speak the truth properly, we have to ditch the lingo. Sometimes for people to feel heard and properly related to, we need to speak a little more, well, honestly. This isn’t to say that Christian words are wrong; specialised Christian words can make tricky ideas plain and shed light on deeper truths. But when these are overused, hard–to–spot barriers can form between Christians and our non–Church friends. To them, what does ‘grace’ or ‘God bless you’ even mean? We can throw in the odd ‘Christian–ese’ word when it needs to be there, but it is so much more honest when we say, for example, ‘I was hurt by what you said,’ than ‘You are being un–Christlike’; or ‘I don’t understand either,’ than ‘God’s ways are higher!’ The list goes on. Let’s use our language honestly to open a window on truth, not cover it up. And if there are tricky Christian words you use all the time but don’t know the meaning of, then check it out online or in one of those wildly big Bible concordances, if there’s one lying around.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 4:24-5:26; Luke 11:45-54; Ps 119:1-8; Pro 20:15-18

content.title: Quit Hitting Yourself
content.introtext:
'...I find this law at work: When I want to do good, evil is right there with me.' Romans 7:21 NIV

You know those times when you know the right thing to do, but just can’t go through with it? When we walk away from something good and we dislike ourselves for it. When we actively hurt other people and it really sticks in our gut. Maybe we know our own sin quite well—and when we see it in our actions and attitudes or the things we attach ourselves to, it hurts. Sin constantly causes that inner struggle. The back–and–forth between good and bad. Check out the bigger passage behind today’s verse and you’ll get the idea: ‘I have the desire to do what is good, but I cannot carry it out. ...in my inner being I delight in God’s law; but I see another law at work in me, waging war against the law of my mind and making me a prisoner of the law of sin at work within me... Who will rescue me from this body that is subject to death? Thanks be to God, who delivers me through Jesus Christ our Lord!’ (Romans 7:16–25 NIV) What we’re called to do when we see our own sin is not to melt down, or get really annoyed at ourselves. It’s to return to God in our thoughts, not to our guilt. Eventually, as you do this more and more, you get the sense of the ‘the fear of the Lord’. ‘The fear of the Lord’ is a gift that prods us to go to God so He can reorder our habits, our mind’s patterns. He is willing to do this, and is just waiting for us to return to Him.

content.title: The New Self
content.introtext:
'...Put on the new self, created to be like God...' Ephesians 4:24 NIV

There are times when God’s laws seem ludicrous to us. It’s probably fair to say that some of them seem beyond human ability. Like, ‘be perfect as your heavenly Father is perfect’—just what, even? But perhaps that’s the point. In Jesus you have a new, different self, and when you surrender your own ability to ‘do’ Christianity, you ‘put off your old self…and…put on the new self, created to be like God…’ (Ephesians 4:22–24 NIV) Is this still true even when you have to grit your teeth and really force yourself to obey God’s laws, moving past your first instincts? Yes. Living by God’s laws will become your instinct with time (Romans 6:17 tells us so.) It’s like when you’re coming around after waking from deep sleep. It takes a while to remember who and where you are. With time you realise you are a new person. Christian speaker Arthur Burt said, ‘I knew a man who always said “Keep looking down,” “You mean keep looking up, don’t you?”, “No! No! We are seated together with Christ in heavenly places!”’ As Christians we are no longer our old selves. We’re new, and we’re already at home with Christ and His laws, even if it doesn’t feel that way just yet. Next time you have the impulse to check Facebook or whatever on your phone, take the moment to pray for the person whose message you’re scrolling past. Caring for others is one way to ‘keep looking down’ and to ‘put on the new self, created to be like God.’



SoulFood: 1 Chron 7:20-9:44; Luke 12:13-21; Ps 119:17-24; Pro 20:22-24

content.title: The Imposter (1)
content.introtext:
'...take thought for what is honest...' Romans 12:17 AMP

We all want good, honest friendships. But we also can’t help hoping that our friends see the right ‘version’ of ourselves. They are allowed to see the carefully–crafted Facebook profile, but we keep our raw, honest selves hidden. Author Brennan Manning calls that crafted persona ‘The Imposter’, and said that we put it on when we want to ‘present a perfect image to the public so that everybody will admire us and nobody will know us.’ You may find that in your Church community or house group it’s difficult to really be yourself. There is this idea that, if we just all show up together and call ourselves Christians, everything will work out. But real life’s not always as simple as that—we have to learn to remove our masks. To make a space for honesty, we need to trust God that people won’t be so offended by honesty it will destroy us. Honesty is a decision to act for other people’s good and our own good. Actually being honest, by not holding back our shortcomings and failures, means our friends have to get used to what’s true and real about us. But this is a real relief. It is so worth it. When we live genuinely, and trust in God, before our friends and the world, then the glory of God will be on show in our lives more than ever before.



SoulFood: Exo 16:1-18; John 6:1-15; John 6:25-40; 1 Cor 11:23-24

content.title: The Imposter (2)
content.introtext:
'...In all things grow up into Him... that is, Christ.' Ephesians 4:15 NIV

Yesterday we saw that when we trust God, we can be more honest with ourselves and others about our shortcomings. Today we’re looking onwards. Ephesians 4 gives us a route into becoming someone who looks, sounds, and moves like Christ. The whole way through, this chapter is confident that we can get there. You are ‘created to be like God, truly righteous and holy.’ (Ephesians 4:24 GWT) ‘Then we will no longer be infants, tossed back and forth by the waves, and blown here and there by every wind...’ (Ephesians 4:14 NIV) What this Bible chapter says sounds next to crazy—‘You, dear reader, hello—you! Yes, you can become like Jesus!’—and it doesn’t hold back from letting you know. But spiritual growth doesn’t happen automatically. Growth always begins with a decision. When Jesus asked Matthew to become His disciple, Matthew didn’t really get all the implications of his decision; he more–or–less said, ‘Yeah, alright boss,’ and went from there. That’s all you need to get started. A decision. Nothing shapes your life like the decisions you make. If you want to know what you’ll be like twenty or thirty years from now, look closely at the commitments that rule your life today. Is the challenge of Ephesians 4 pressing into your life, now? Look at your commitments and priorities. Type them up. And put today’s verse at the top. How do the things you want or need to do line up with becoming more like Jesus? If they don’t, it’s time to rethink them.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 10:1-12:22; Luke 12:22-34; Ps 119:25-32; Pro 20:25-27

content.title: God as a Parent (1)
content.introtext:
'You gave me life and showed me kindness, and in Your providence watched over my spirit.' Job 10:12 NIV

We’re not likely to hear people say ‘God is my mother’. But some of the things we usually expect our mothers to do, God also does for us. God’s care, kindness and (yep, almost motherly...) life–giving love is there for us. We’re supposed to get comfort from it, when we need it. In Job 10, Job’s life has gone down the tube. He was alone. He was covered in painful sores. Most of his family was dead. Then he remembered where he came from in the first place. Job asked God where His comfort and care went to and why God had stopped acting like the good Parent he used to know. When we’ve lost perspective on our life because things are tough, we can turn to God like this. He’s the Provider who has promised to keep a caring eye on us all our lives, so we can say, ‘God—you birthed me into this world. You saved me and promised to look after me. Where are You now? Come help me!’ Job recognised he needed this kind of perspective. He looked back on his life and recognised that God had always been faithful, and it’s the same for us—He’s been with us since day one, and isn’t about to stop. You know that ‘just came back after a weekend/month/term away’ catch–up chat that happens when you get home? Have it with God. Just spend time talking through life right now with Him. Ask Him to have His hand in it.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 12:23-15:29; Luke 12:35-48; Ps 119:33-40; Pro 20:28-30

content.title: God as a Parent (2)
content.introtext:
'Blessed are those whose ways are blameless, who walk according to the law of the Lord.' Psalm 119:1 NIV

If we want to actually grow as His children, God wants us to do more than lean on His mercy. We need to start there. Absolutely everything has to come first from His love for us. Equally, that isn’t the end of His gift to us. He wants us to develop our character as we put His laws into practice, because we can grow into something better. God is a Father who wants to see us become closer to Him both in relationship and likeness. He doesn’t want us to see Him as Someone shouting down rules from the clouds. When we get this, His correction starts to make sense. We start to listen to His laws, to stay attentive for His voice that draws us into life, to see joy where we currently struggle with sin, to ‘get’ the need for discipline where we have no patience. He will resist our excuse–making, our posing, and our hiding from obedience because He’s painting a bigger picture. We only know whatever details are in front of us right now. But He knows how the whole thing is going to look when it’s finished! We only know the corner of the room we happen to be in today, He has the blueprints for the whole house. Be reassured that He knows what He’s building in you and that His plans are perfect.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 16-18; Luke 12:49-59; Ps 119:41-48; Pro 21:1-3

content.title: God as a Parent (3)
content.introtext:
'Give ear and come to Me; listen, that you may live. I will make an everlasting covenant with you...' Isaiah 55:3 NIV

So let’s bring these last two days’ readings together. God’s care looks like the love of a good parent: sometimes comfort, sometimes discipline. But when we zoom out, it’s all part of His promise never to stop loving us. There’s a word for that. Many Bibles translate it as ‘loving–kindness’, but the Hebrew word for it is ‘chesed’ (pronounced ‘hes–ed’). ‘Chesed’ is the love promised by God to His people. It’s very different from every other form of love out there because it involves loyalty from a perfect God. His unshakeable, undeserved love that sticks with us because He is for us. Even when we’re against Him. 2 Timothy 2:13 NIV says: ‘If we are faithless, He will remain faithful.’ God knows we’re an unfaithful bunch—But that doesn't phase Him. ‘Chesed’ is an active love: not just a one–off sweet deal at the Cross, but God moving in our lives every day. This is great news. It makes us here at word4U2day excited, anyway! And God doesn’t force us to reflect His love! We enter out of our own freedom into a relationship with Him. Even when our feelings betray us, or we have a bad day and can’t be bothered with the thought of picking up a Bible, God’s given us something that goes beyond emotions, a love that we can decide to do, not just feel our way into. One good way of helping your decision/will to support your love for God is to read the Bible everyday. If you haven’t started with SoulFood yet, why not begin today?

content.title: Beauty in Corners
content.introtext:
'Whatever is right... think about [it].' Philippians 4:8 NIV

A man chained in a prison cell wrote, ‘...whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is admirable—if anything is excellent or praiseworthy—think about such things.’ This was Paul, locked up in a foreign country just for being a Christian. He was writing the letter to the Philippians. He won’t have taken a lot of inspiration from his immediate environment—four tight corners and a damp ceiling—and, worse, he was stuck there day in, day out. It’s not always easy to get inspiration from what’s physically in front of you. Your school may not have been the nicest place to attend. Your street may not have been a great place to grow up. And on a bad day, being pushed into a tight corner just one time too many can kick off a gloomy mood. God is the stable centre of all beauty. Wherever and whenever you are, you can live healthily, if you are fixed on Him. Whether that’s some truth you’ve found in the Bible or a person who shows you the beauty of Jesus or just a morning of quiet worship while you get on with your job, it doesn’t matter. When we have God at the forefront of our minds we can say, ‘The Lord is my chosen portion and my cup; You hold my lot. The lines have fallen for me in pleasant places; indeed, I have a beautiful inheritance.’ (Psalm 16:5–6 ESV) American pastor Jonathan Martin said, ‘Whenever and wherever you see beauty, you will always be able to follow it back to Jesus.’ Keep an eye out.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 23:21-26:19; Luke 13:18-35; Ps 119:57-64; Pro 21:7-9

content.title: Your Doubts Don't Disqualify You
content.introtext:
'...Do not be unbelieving, but believing.' John 20:27 NKJ

*Previously, in the book of the Gospel of John...* The resurrection happened and someone missed it. He got a bit huffy. ‘Unless I see the nail marks in His hands and put my finger where the nails were, and put my hand into His side, I will not believe.’ (John 20:25 NKJ) Yep, it was Thomas and he wasn’t going to be taken in by any nonsense about people rising from the dead. As if! ‘A week later His disciples were in the house again, and Thomas was with them. Though the doors were locked, Jesus came and stood among them and said, “Peace be with you!” Then He said to Thomas, “Put your finger here; see My hands. Reach out your hand and put it into My side. Stop doubting and believe.” Thomas said to Him, “My Lord and my God!”’ (John 20:24–28 NIV) Jesus put an end to Thomas’ unbelief, but He didn’t tell him off for having doubts. It’s so important we get this. Jesus does not hate us for struggling with doubts—not even doubts about His existence. What He wants to do is show you Himself, not punish you for wondering or thinking. Your doubts do not disqualify you. (It’s important to add we shouldn’t allow them to take control. God isn’t a ‘tame lion’ and He won’t always show Himself up the way we ask Him to. But countless doubting Christians have found that when they’ve searched for God, they’ve found hope.) Recently been finding yourself doubting? Take it slowly. Step by step. Whatever’s on your mind, share it with someone you trust—maybe your youth pastor. And, our inbox is always open.



SoulFood: 1 Chron 26:20-29:30; Luke 14:1-14; Ps 119:65-72; Pro 21:10-13

content.title: Habitat for Divinity (1)
content.introtext:
'...This has been your manner from your youth...' Jeremiah 22:21 NKJ

How often do we go through our days multi–tasking between our ‘Christian’ mind and our ‘normal’ mind? Like tabbing between pages on a web browser, this can eventually use up all our attention and wear us out. We are whole people, not fractured beings. Splitting off our minds into a spiritual bit and non–spiritual bit ends up being unhealthy. How do we fix this? First up: habits are key. The patterns in how you think about things, how you act in certain situations, and the behaviours you return to, make up your whole person. So they’re pretty important, and God cares about them (Like, a lot. The story behind today’s verse is God calling out His people for repeatedly ignoring Him over centuries...) Habits can keep your attention on God and the person He has made you to be, bringing your mind into a focused peace. Habits free you up to do things more quickly and remove mental clutter so that you can think clearly about important things. They play a part in making your whole being a place that God can come and live in. More on that tomorrow! A good way to check your habits may be to have someone you respect and trust question you on the way you react to people, particularly when you’re tired or upset. Are your responses coming from a fear of people, or a ‘fear of God’? (check back to August 8 for more on the ‘fear of God’.)



SoulFood: John 4:4-26; John 7:37-41; Exo 17:1-7; Isa 35:1-7

content.title: Habitat for Divinity (2)
content.introtext:
'And you shall again obey the voice of the Lord and keep all His commandments... [He] will again take delight in prospering you...' Deuteronomy 30:8-9 ESV

Your habits make a habitat. If those habits make a habitat of praise, then it will be a place where God comes and lives. ‘You inhabit the praises of Israel.’ (Psalm 22:3 NKJ) When we try hard to live in a way that is in line with God’s law, though we can’t fully get it right at first (trying to love your enemies—whaaat?) our attempts make room for God to come and ‘fill in the gap’. So, for example, we may start out trying to love people who are very hard to like. It’s definitely possible to act for the wellbeing of another person without actually liking the person. And God wants it, and we’re keeping His command, so that’s great. But as we keep on trying out that ‘practical’ love, we make space for God to come and fill our hearts with a love that includes feelings, includes joy, and includes—yes!—actually liking the people we find hard to like. This is the power of the Holy Spirit. Our attempts to do things we find impossible make us fall back on the transforming power of God, and His grace. We submit to God and He enables us to make it happen. You could start (if you’re feeling brave... err, not feeling brave? Then ask Him for a bit of courage), by approaching the person who’s come to mind in this reading. A few difficult but meaningful kind words can change a lot.

content.title: A Thumbs-Up That Matters
content.introtext:
'Who is he who condemns?...' Romans 8:34 NKJ

When it comes to an area of your life that needs improvement, it’s good to be concerned about it, but not consumed with it. You’ll always be working on some area of your life, so learning that who you are in Christ is not going to change will be pretty important if you want to sleep at night: ‘There is therefore now no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus…’ (Romans 8:1 NKJ) Because God has chosen to see you ‘in Christ’, He finds you acceptable, every day (more than that, He’s downright thrilled to know you. Really.) and you always have access to Him. Your ‘who’ is not based on your ‘do’. God’s not about shaming and blaming you. Yeah, He’ll convict you (meaning His Holy Spirit will point out the things you’ve done wrong.) When you stop resisting His goodness (hint here: repent—that means decide to turn your back on your bad habits and turn to Him) He’ll get you back up on your feet, but He won’t be shaking His head and glaring while He does it. You do that to yourself. God never will. ‘Who is he who condemns? It is Christ who died, and furthermore is also risen, who is even at the right hand of God, who makes intercession for us.’ (Romans 8:34 NKJ) This means Jesus gives you His thumbs–up, and it remains the only thumbs–up–or–down that matters. Conclusion: ”What then shall we say to these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?” (Romans 8:31 ESV)

content.title: Faceplanting out of Freedom
content.introtext:
'Blessed are they... who walk according to the law of the Lord.' Psalm 119:1 NIV

Have a flick through Psalm 119, and you’ll see that the writer really, really liked getting stuck into God’s law. This is not just a hobby. So, why should we choose to focus on what only God wants for us, and not work off our instincts or other people’s advice? You’ll start to understand the Psalmist’s enthusiasm about hard moral codes if you think about kids playing on a cliff edge. Without a fence you’re counting the seconds until one of them makes a fatal faceplant. With a fence, there’s no worries. God’s law is a fence that brings incredible freedom. Maybe it’s only a matter of time until one of the kids starts wondering what’s on the other side of the fence. If they don’t know or trust the fence builder, they hop the fence—and kerplonk. Brutal. If they survive, they come back saying like the Psalmist, ‘I used to wander off until You disciplined me; but now I closely follow Your Word.’ (Psalm 119:67 NLT) The Ten Commandments start with the words, ‘I am the Lord your God…’ (Exodus 20:2 ESV) All the don’t kill, steal etc. bits come after; God speaks about the relationship first, then about the rules that keep it on safe ground. It’s when we understand that the fence builder absolutely loves us and wants the best for us we’re happy to stay on the right side of the fence. In your prayer time with God today, ask Him to point out where He’s put up important fences you might have not seen yet.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 8-11; Luke 15:1-10; Ps 119:89-96; Pro 21:20-23

content.title: Help for Stress (1)
content.introtext:
'Anxiety weighs down the heart, but a kind word cheers it up.' Proverbs 12:25 NIV

Your stomach’s in knots, you feel like an elephant’s on your chest, your thoughts are smashed by a whirlwind. Where can you find relief? In stressed–out days it’s hard to remember that you, as you are, with all your weakness and tired thoughts, are still valued by God. He has said you are His beloved. Even when you come down harshly on yourself, He does not change how He thinks about you. When you forget that God has said you are valued, it’s important to have friends who will come and show you that. Especially if you show kindness to others when they are struggling, but you don’t always show to yourself. One of the wonderful things about being part of the Church is that other Christians can ‘be’ Christ to you in those moments. They can show you what God thinks of you, in patience, quiet listening, in some well–placed humour at the right time. These are really important ways we experience the love of God through our friends who carry His Holy Spirit. Do you have those sorts of friends? And, if you’re feeling pretty on top of things at the moment, are you that sort of friend to someone else? If you’re going through a stressy patch, it could be helpful to venture out and connect with friends who’ve proven to be good listeners before. Or you can txt (0401 132 888) or call PrayForMe (1800 PrayForMe), if you want to chat it over anonymously. Find a way to bring your anxiety to God.

content.title: Help for Stress (2)
content.introtext:
'In the multitude of my anxieties within me, Your comforts delight my soul.' Psalm 94:19 NKJ

About three hundred years ago, minister Matthew Henry rifled through the Bible and wrote cool comments on all the verses. Here’s what he had to say about today’s verse: ‘The world’s comforts give little delight to the soul, when hurried with melancholy thoughts; but God’s comforts bring that peace and pleasure which the smiles of the world cannot give, and which the frowns of the world cannot take away.’ Today, most people sense there must be something deeper to how we feel than ‘just getting through’ from day to day. To stay in touch with our humanity we have to look out for God’s comforts. As you walk around today, notice what God puts in your path. The old clichés are to watch a sunset or lie on a beach. It’s true; these are things we can be grateful for when we’re able to do them. But you might have to train yourself up to look out for the beauty of God in places you can notice every day. To appreciate a conversation with a friend. To make a small gesture of kindness to someone in your family you take for granted. To stop being hurried and find that deeper comfort that the world can’t take away. When you do this, you might even find that the Author of beauty Himself sneaks up on you to delight in it with you. Nothing restores your soul more than God Himself. If you’re on autopilot today, take a deep breath, switch it off and turn to Jesus in prayer.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 16-18; Luke 16:1-18; Ps 119:105-112; Pro 21:28-31

content.title: Bring It. (1)
content.introtext:
'If you are insulted for the name of Christ, you are blessed, because the Spirit of glory and of God rests upon you.' 1 Peter 4:14 ESV

Corrie Ten Boom was a young Christian when her home country, the Netherlands, was invaded in World War II. She quickly got fearful she wouldn’t know what to do if the Nazis confronted her. So her dad told her, ‘When you are going to take a journey on the train, do I give you your ticket three weeks early or just as you get on the train?’ Corrie said, ‘As I get on the train.’ ‘So God will give you the special strength you need to be strong in the face of death just when you need it, not before.’ Are you worried you don’t have the strength to live for God? Feel like you lack the ‘oomph’ to be a powerful Christian? Whether you discover it like Corrie, facing danger and persecution, or right when you step out to tell someone the Gospel, or in the moment when you get hit by hurtful insults, God’s strength comes right when you need it. We’re even promised: ‘...don’t worry about what to say or how to say it. At that time you will be given the things to say. It will not really be you speaking but the Spirit of your Father speaking through you.’ (Matthew 10:19–20 NCV) Whether you feel it or not, your God has got your back: when you step out for God (and maybe not even a second beforehand), you’ll discover you have all that you need.

content.title: Bring It. (2)
content.introtext:
'...God led you through the wilderness...to prove your character...' Deuteronomy 8:2 NLT

In Florida, wiry trees called Caribbean Pines thrive in deadly environments. They stick out drought, fire and hurricanes. In fact, if you plant them in a setting trees normally love, they’re so hardcore they just shrivel and die. It can be a similar case with our souls: we shrivel because things go so well we feel we don’t need God. Sometimes we need a wilderness to refine our faith like the children of Israel who were led into the desert: ‘to prove [their] character, and… find out whether or not [they] would obey His commandments.’ They could choose to give up and shrivel up there, or trust Him to bring them safely to the Promised Land. When things get too comfortable, our faith actually shrivels. The odd blast of wilderness can be genuinely good for us. Sometimes God allows the fiery draught of very difficult times so we can see what’s in our faith—is it made of the good, solid stuff that trusts in God?—and to mature it and get to the true and better person inside. God leads you through the wilderness to prove your character. That also means that He’s in control. Your ‘wilderness’, if you’ve given your life to God, is both for a purpose (the best there can be: His loving plan for you) and it’s safe—in His hands. Look back on the last three months. What hard times have you been brought through? What good things have come from them that couldn’t have happened otherwise? Rejoice when rough times look like they’re about to sweep in. Bring it on!



SoulFood: John 10:1-18; Rev 7:13-17; Ps 23; Luke 15:1-7

content.title: Mentor, Mentee
content.introtext:
'...The works that I do [you] will do also...' John 14:12 NKJ

 Jesus told His disciples, ‘The works that I do you will do also.’ Skip forward to the book of Acts and guess what? They did! They took on His character and became like Him. What happened in between? He mentored them. If you want to get somewhere in life, ask God for the right mentors. Some mentors you get for a short chunk of your life, others for a lifetime. Some of them might even be close friends who end up discipling you in a quiet, hidden way. So how do you recognise a mentor? They might be someone who sticks by these promises: (1) I’m willing to spend time to build a close relationship with this friend; (2) I’ll keep believing in the potential of this friend, keep getting them excited about the future I see ahead of them; (3) I’m willing to be vulnerable and available to my friend, to share not only my strengths and successes, but also my weaknesses, failures, and generally–rubbish moments; (4) When it’s right to, I am willing to be honest in confronting my friend; (5) I am committed to standing by them through trials—even trials that they bring on themselves; (6) I’ll help them set goals for a spiritual life or ministry; (7) I’ll actually practice what I preach. None of this ‘talking the talk without walking the walk’ business. Find a mentor. Become a mentor. It’s a top way to fit all the different pieces of the Christian life together.

content.title: Thank God?
content.introtext:
'...His sheep follow him because they know his voice.' John 10:4 NIV

If you’re chatting with a good mate, there’s an ease in the flow of your conversation because you know who you’re talking to. You know the person who’s listening to your words. You feel safe in knowing what you say won’t be taken the wrong way. Talking to God is sometimes less easy when you’re first getting to know Him because it can feel like talking to a blank canvas (maybe you remember that, or you’re going through it now). Who is He? What does He want to hear? What does He want me to say? Or even if He seems to have gone quiet with you, or was never ‘loud’—how do you get into a place where you can even begin to learn to hear His voice? This is why so many of Christianity’s traditional prayers start with thanks. When we start our prayers with gratefulness we are doing what’s right (giving God His due for everything He’s given) and we’re starting to get a sense of the person we’re talking to: the Giver of all good gifts. When we’re thanking Him, we’re starting to learn His character. Ann Voskamp says, ‘Giving thanks in all things is how to pray continually [1 Thessalonians 5:17–18]... This is the way to do God’s will for your right now. Thanks to God is what calms the wild heart.’ So, praise Him! Lots! Then listen out...

content.title: Shadow Ops
content.introtext:
'He... shall abide under the shadow of the Almighty.' Psalm 91:1 NKJ

What is the ‘shadow of the Almighty’? You might think of an overcast day and wonder if this is a bit of a not–very–sunshiney gloomy thought. But if you’d been living in the blistering heat of a desert for the last forty years—which is exactly what God’s people had been doing for a fair chunk of the Old Testament (post–Prince of Egypt)—then it’s something a little more appealing. So the Israelites, as you can imagine, liked a good shadow or two. It meant shelter and comfort in a very hot climate. What does it mean for us? We know that God’s personality isn’t all–guns–blazing, instead He’s our place of safety. We can read ‘shadow’ as ‘safety’. In the blistering heat of life’s battles, temptations, and worries, God is the life–saving shadow we can always come back to. Yes, we have to go on the offensive sometimes, and withstand the attacks of Satan, and fight back with Scripture. But, in reality, as humans, we aren’t set up to be at the forefront of battle all the time. We need to rest in God. Think about this: could you spend the whole day walking in the shadow of the person beside you. How close would you have to stay to be able to manage it? Would you have to change the rhythm of your walk to stay there? What does this tell you about ‘being in God’s shadow’? Yep, stay close and move as God moves.



SoulFood: 2 Chron 29-31; Luke 17:20-37; Ps 119:137-144; Pro 22:11-13

content.title: Faith! But What Does It Mean?
content.introtext:
'Faith is the substance of things hoped for...' Hebrews 11:1 NKJ

There’s lots we can’t do on our own. Especially as Christians. Stuff like overcoming the world—see 1 John 5:4—can only be done with faith in God. ‘Faith’ is one of those words that’s not often defined for us (like ‘Hosanna’ or ‘Amen’... ‘Bless’...) But today’s verse gives a pretty clear definition of what faith is. What does it look like? (a) Being certain of victory. Back to 1 John 5:4. Our victory over Satan comes by faith, not by willpower and discipline. Faith comes from the Word of God, not from anything within ourselves. (b) Being certain of growing to be like God. Faith isn’t a one–time event that starts and finishes the moment you become a Christian. We keep growing in our faith. By learning. ‘So faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of Christ.’ (Romans 10:17 ESV) And by doing. ‘What good is it, my brothers, if someone says he has faith but does not have works?’ (James 2:14 ESV) So much of this ‘faith’ business is about being ok with the future. This is not easy… if you’re struggling to see past things that worry you, head back to August 3 & 4. And soak in the knowledge that, as you spend daily time in the Word of God (try SoulFood), that God will build faith in you.

content.title: Too Busy to Love?
content.introtext:
'...He has commanded us to love one another...' 2 John 1:6 NLT

Life can be busy. And it’s great (really, really great) you take time out with God in the middle of all that. So now, what about your on–earth relationships? Jesus made it pretty clear the second most important thing in life, right after loving God, is loving people (that’s in Matthew 22:37–40, team). And to do that, we have to spend time around others— even those irritating, imperfect, demanding, frustrating people. It’s awful for our relationships if we don’t put time and effort into them. That’s how friends ‘drift apart’ and how families can start to misunderstand each other. Plus, we need other people. That few minutes spent chatting to your mate, or that Sunday roast round the table—it all adds something to your life because God made us to live in community. The love of others is good for us. And, the love we send out is good for those others. Ask God to fill you up with His love, to the point that you’re positively overflowing with it. Then, if you take the time to really share a little of your day with another person, chances are, you’ll be able to share God in some way too. Even if that’s just in the friendly hello someone needs to hear today. A practical exercise in loving: Go to your phone. Scroll down to the 10th person you texted and start there. Pray for that person that they’ll have a really blessed day. You could even send them an encouragement to top it up, if you liked.

content.title: Keep On Keeping On and Keeping On
content.introtext:
'...but I focus on this one thing: Forgetting the past and looking forward to what lies ahead.' Philippians 3:13 NLT

In Philippians 3, Paul talks about how he really, genuinely, very–very–earnestly wants to live a Jesus–centred life. But he’s under no illusions. He knows he’s not already perfect. Read Philippians 3:12–13. There, Paul explains something so important— that, no matter how human he is in this life, he’s adamant that he’ll press on, looking forward to his future relationship with Christ perfected in Heaven. What a brilliant example! We all need to recognise where our lives don’t look like Jesus’, and take those areas to God in prayer and apologise. As soon as we give our mistakes up to God, He lays them to rest, reminding us to move on, looking ahead to our final goal of being with Christ forever. But we can have a tendency to keep hold of the past. Sometimes that’s through guilting ourselves, but sometimes in a very different way. In a weird way, it can be tempting to look fondly on our past sins (Really. Think about it… it happens more than you might realise). There’s a part of us all that’s twisted and wants to be loudly proud of those ‘wasn’t I a rebel’ moments. Truth is, that point of view is just not healthy. If you’re still tied to your past in any way, it’ll be harder to move forwards, towards ‘that perfection’ that Paul calls for us to focus on. Think: what have you done (or do you still do) that you feel stops you heading towards ‘that perfection’? Pray your apology, and ask for help. Then hit delete. Let it go from your records, just like it’s gone from God’s.

content.title: Your Life is a Tree
content.introtext:
'Endure until your testing is over. Then you will be mature and complete...' James 1:4 GWT

Tomorrow is the official start of Spring. Flowers and stuff. Great. Then, a few months from now, spring will have sprung and it’ll be sizzling into summer. Your life works the same, in cycles and seasons. That means some periods of our lives are all green grass, shiny newness and fresh loveliness. It also means some periods will be dead leaves, rain and sniffles. Whichever you have right now, God’s on it. He’s the one who decides when we get spring–like growth seasons. And when we need a stretch of... being s t r e t c h e d... He brings us into (and through) it. ‘For everything there is a season.’ (Ecclesiastes 3:1 NLT) That’s not to downplay how outright rubbish those tough seasons can feel. But they’re a necessary part of God’s long–term plan. Think about a tree. The only reason it has space to grow strong, healthy, green leaves in spring is because it lost the leaves it’d finished with last autumn. And it only grew new ones after shivering, bare–branched, through winter. If everything looks barren and cold around you right now, we 100% guarantee it’s only for a time. In that time, the best thing you can do is stick to God, and let the difficulty He has allowed you to face do its work. Seasons come and go. So it’s important to have a stable centre to your life. Are there any places in your room that you can turn into ‘prayer spaces’? It doesn’t have to be a wooden bench to kneel at, it could even just be a beanbag. Make it special place to remind you to meet with God each day.



SoulFood: Phil 2:5-11; Rev 19:11-16; Acts 3:1-16; Matt 1:18-21

content.title: Resetting the Relationship
content.introtext:
'Tell the Israelites to designate the cities of refuge...' Joshua 20:2 NIV

In the Old Testament, God’s people had a High Priest every generation, set apart and ‘anointed with the holy oil’ (Numbers 35:25 NRS) to represent that generation to God, and also to represent God to them. When he died, then the one who had represented God had passed away. God allowed his death to signify the removal of sin from His people and to ‘reset’ their relationship with Him. This was particularly useful with regard to the laws about accidentally killing someone. Legally, the victim’s family could take your life in exchange. Not good. But God is all about forgiveness. He told Israel to set up six ‘cities of refuge’—essentially safe bases. You ran to them, explained your story to the town elders, and hid out in the town, knowing they were duty–bound to protect you. No–one hunting you was allowed to enter the city at all. Safe. And the thing that really showed the extent of God’s grace was this: you weren’t even trapped there for life. When the High Priest died, you were ‘forgiven’—released from your sanctuary and allowed to go home. No one was permitted to harm you. The relationship had been ‘reset’. Spotted Jesus yet? Jesus, our ‘High Priest’, really represents us to God (Hebrews 4:14): Jesus didn’t just carry us into a Temple’s Holy of Holies but into the throne room of Heaven itself. He died once, for all time, resetting our relationship with God to ‘forgiven’. If you run to God’s refuge in Jesus, then wherever you are, Satan can’t touch you, and you’re in a completely restored relationship with God.



SoulFood: Josh 1-4; Luke 19:1-10; Ps 84; Pro 22:24-26

content.title: Brethren, Assemble (1)
content.introtext:
'Behold, how good and how pleasant it is for brethren to dwell together in unity!' Psalm 133:1 KJV

Grab a Bible and read Psalm 133. It’s short. It’ll probably take about half a second. Ok, maybe half a minute. Chances are you’ve heard that opening verse before. And yeah, it certainly is nice when we get along. But why? What is there about unity that’s so special for us Christians? Is there something more to it than it just making us feel warm and fuzzy? Well, verses two and three of Psalm 133 name oil and dew. Hmm. It might seem a bit poetic at first, but it’s got real meaning. Oil being dropped on a person happened as a symbol of the Holy Spirit ‘anointing’ them, and the power that comes with that. More often than not, that ‘anointing’ was a sign of God giving someone the power to go and carry out one of His plans. And dew crops up in Isaiah 26:19. Interestingly, it’s a symbol of that same power giving new life (by resurrecting the dead) to God’s people. Oil = God’s Spirit and power. Dew = God’s Spirit and power. So, what the Psalmist seems to be saying here is that, when we ‘live together in unity’ (Psalm 133:1 NIV), something mind–blowingly huge happens—as a community, we receive death–beating power that enables us to do what God wants. God comes to rest in a very real way over the collection of people who are brought together because of Him. As individuals, we don’t have what we have as community. Pretty good reason to do that ‘fellowship’ thing, huh?



SoulFood: Josh 5:1-8:29; Luke 19:11-27; Ps 103:1-12; Pro 22:27-29

'In Christ we who are many form one body, and each member belongs to all the others.' Romans 12:5 NIV

Yesterday was all about what happens when Christians work together. Wonderful stuff. Now. How? How do we work together? How do we do unity? Paul has some great advice in Romans. After all, He created the overall plan. He’s created everyone around you to fit together, kind of like a jigsaw. If every piece chooses to be the right shape, the overall picture will come together, no problems. And, with a God–designed team around you, you have no reason to be nervous of taking up your part in things. You can step up to your place in the knowledge that the guys and girls around you are commissioned by the same, unshakable God.

content.title: Grow Passion, Grow Fruit
content.introtext:
'...he who does wrong will receive the consequences...' Colossians 3:25 NAS

John Ortberg writes: ‘My friend Andy Chan headed up the placement office for helping graduates find work. He says that some day he wants to write a book called The Myth of Passion. This is the myth that somewhere out there is the perfect job, the idealised calling that fits my soul the way a key fits into a lock. And if I could just find that job, torrents of passion would cascade out of my heart like water going over Niagara Falls.’ Just about all of us have a romantic idea that we will find ‘job–love at first sight.’ But what if you are in a job that doesn’t excite you? What if you have to study stuff that seems downright boring? Ortberg writes: ‘Passion for our work is not usually a subterranean volcano waiting to erupt… It is a muscle that gets strengthened a little each day... as we do what is expected of us, and then some.’ Paul wrote: ‘Whatever you do, do your work heartily, as for the Lord... knowing that from the Lord you will receive the reward of the inheritance. It is the Lord Christ whom you serve. For he who does wrong will receive the consequences of the wrong which he has done.’ (Colossians 3:22–25 NKJV) Maybe it would help to put a sticker up on your phone: ‘For God’s sake—do your best!’ Why? For two reasons: (1) Because you represent Christ wherever you go. (2) When you are faithful in small things, He will promote you to greater things (Matthew 25:21).

content.title: It Is Worth It.
content.introtext:
'If I can just touch [Him], I will be healed.' Mark 5:28 NLT

Mark’s Gospel records the story of a Jewish woman who, for twelve solid years, had been suffering from an ‘issue’ of constant bleeding. For this lady, in the society in which she lived, the impact on her life was devastating. She was totally broke, having spent all her money on medical bills. The religious laws said her husband couldn’t go near her. Babies were totally off the cards. Everything she touched was considered ‘spiritually unclean’. The religious laws meant she couldn’t even go to worship God in the Temple. She was completely worn–out, and not even allowed to go to God’s house to be refreshed. At the end of her tether, she decided to put her trust in God. She went out into a crowd that was disgusted by (and probably afraid of) her, and she grabbed hold of the fringe of Jesus’ prayer cloak. And it worked. Her earnest faith did something amazing—it drew the power of God to her, and she was healed. She was freed from all of the laws that made her life difficult. She could enter God’s temple, stand tall in her community again, not look in the mirror and see ‘unclean’. And all of this, just from grabbing Jesus’ garment in an act of faith as He passed by. What could you do, if He stood in front of you now? Is there an ‘issue’ where you need to reach out in faith to Jesus to be healed? Take it to Him now.



SoulFood: Josh 14-15; Luke 20:1-8; Ps 142; Pro 23:7-9

content.title: On You Go
content.introtext:
'There are different kinds of gifts, but the same Spirit...' 1 Corinthians 12:4 NIV

Paul writes, ‘There are different kinds of gifts, but the same spirit.’ Successful people invest their time, energy and resources into their core strengths. Why? Because that is where they get their highest return! Occasionally they’ll try their hand at something new. Take Michael Jordan, for example, arguably the world’s most famous basketball player. For various reasons MJ decided to try his hand at baseball for a season. He may have enjoyed the experience, but exiting the game so early is probably not what he’d like to be remembered for. God gave you gifts that make you unique, gifts that hold great possibilities. But you have to discover them and develop them. A sign on a DIY shop says it all: ‘We’ve got it, if you can find it.’ Nobody was ever born without talent, including you, but you’ve got to find it. What keeps us from doing that? (1) The company we keep. The old saying goes, ‘If you run around with turkeys, you’ll never fly with eagles.’ The Scripture says, ‘He who walks with wise men, will be wise...’ (Proverbs 13:20 NKJV) (2) Failing to spend time in prayer and in God’s Word. God is not only the giver of your gift, He supplies the strength to function successfully in it. Aristotle said, ‘We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence then is not an act, but a habit.’ So if you want to succeed, consult God, and operate in your God-given strength.



SoulFood: Josh 16:1-19:23; Luke 20:9-19; Ps 20; Pro 23:10-12

content.title: Commitment Issues
content.introtext:
'...Let us love one another, for love comes from God...' 1 John 4:7 NIV

Oops. We said it. But relax; we’re not going to force you into marriage. What we’re talking about is Godly commitment to everyone around you, and everything you do. God commits to loving, growing and parenting you. And with Him doing that, you can’t help but share that love with others. The whole of 1 John 4:7 NCV reads: ‘Dear friends, we should love each other, because love comes from God. Everyone who loves has become God’s child and knows God.’ Now, hands up… who speaks Greek? Hmm, stick with us anyway. That second sentence, ‘Everyone who loves has become God’s child and knows God’ isn’t exactly straightforward. In the original Greek, there is one word that means ‘has become God’s child’, and it does some weird stuff with tenses. It’s past and present all at the same time; it means ‘has become God’s child right at that point, and will continue to become more and more God’s child as time goes on.’ Sooo… everyone who shows God’s love has been adopted by God and shows Him through their relationships and work. But it doesn’t stop there. God promises to put work into fathering and teaching them, every day, for the rest of their lives (pretty good model for commitment). And under that sort of attention from God, our human commitment to sharing love with the world becomes way more do–able each day.



SoulFood: Heb 11; Matt 21:18-22; Matt 8:5-13; Mark 6:1-6

content.title: It's Not You, It's Me
content.introtext:
'...be patient, bearing with one another in love.' Ephesians 4:2 NIV

When it comes to any of our ‘relationships’ with others (literally any friendships, siblings, colleagues you kinda–don’t–wanna–but–kinda–hafta sit next to, marriage, parents), there’s a simple acid–test we should be checking. Ready? Here it is: ‘Am I going in the right direction?’ But what does this question mean about navigating a world populated with friends and strangers? Well, all your thoughts, plans and decisions are either heading in your direction, or away from yourself and to God’s direction. And God’s direction is always towards the well–being of the other person. Guess it’s kind of obvious. We all have relationships we don’t enjoy, though: what about when they just keep getting it wrong, and we have to get all defensive? Or when they’re so full of gossip that it’s impossible not to join in (and maybe later gossip about them too?) Or when they’ve messed up but so have we, and still the easiest thing to do is just pass the blame entirely on to them? Hmm. When you are taking the trouble to bring about the best for another person, not to focus on their problems or mistakes, you’re doing it right. Choose not to gossip. Instead, make it a habit to give genuine compliments to others and build them up.



SoulFood: Josh 19:24-21:45; Luke 20:20-26; Ps 112; Pro 23:13-15

content.title: The Word, For You, Today (1) -- Whys and Hows
content.introtext:
'...The words that I speak unto you, they are Spirit, and they are life.' John 6:63 KJV

Jesus said, ‘The words I have spoken to you—they are full of the Spirit and life.’ (John 6:63 NIV) Obviously, the Bible as we read it today wasn’t in existence when He said that; He was talking about His own, out–loud words. But His words are recorded in what has become the Bible—the parables and sermons that He used to tell His disciples are now part of Scripture. Just like Jesus’ on–earth speeches, the rest of the Bible is made up of words that have come right from God. And they remain full of God. The potency and power that will change your life is still there, waiting for you to discover them. Sometimes, though, reading those words just doesn’t happen. Too much effort. Not enough time. Simple forgetfulness. So let’s tackle this head–on. This week’s readings will focus on how to grasp the words of the Bible, remembering that:

  • The Bible is massively important.
  • And sometimes it’s hard to know how to use it as a practical tool.
  • But we think we can help.

Over the next few days, we’re going to have a good dig into what the Bible is, what it does and how to use it. Whether you’re well up on the Scriptures, or you struggle to remember where you left your Bible, we think it’ll have something good to offer you. The Bible really is great, but it’s worth taking some time to remind yourself of the whys and hows of its greatness.



SoulFood: Josh 22-24; Luke 20:27-40; Ps 27; Pro 23:16-18

content.title: The Word, For You, Today (2) -- It's Oh So Quiet
content.introtext:
'...I have treasured the words of His mouth more than my daily bread.' Job 23:12 NIV

Job could not find God. He just couldn’t. And it’s not like he didn’t try. The thing is, sometimes God chooses to be silent for a while. Sometimes He steps back. He’d never do it without good reason (and it’s frustrating when we don’t know the reason), but sometimes it’s necessary. The question that lives in that type of silence is: ‘How do you fill it?’ If it seems you can’t feel or find God, how do you navigate your life with Him? Well, the fact is, by some sort of Design, His words are always around. You guessed it. The Bible. Even if you don’t feel bird–sized butterflies in your stomach while you’re reading it, the Bible’s still speaking directly into the life you’re living. That’s what it’s there for. Job didn’t feel the presence of God for ages, but could still confidently say, ‘I have kept to His way without turning aside. I have not departed from the commands of His lips; I have treasured the words of His mouth more than my daily bread.’ (Job 23:11–12 NIV) He loved the words of God that He remembered from the past, even when God wasn’t speaking to him in the present. And that’s what kept him going. That’s what kept his life right when he couldn’t hear God in any other way. What are some Bible verses you should write out and keep in your wallet for those days when God seems silent? Commit them to paper today.



SoulFood: Col 1-2; Luke 20:41-47; Ps 78:1-8; Pro 23:19-21

content.title: The Word, For You, Today (3) -- Mmmmm, Milk!
content.introtext:
'Like newborn babies, crave pure spiritual milk, so that...you may grow...' 1 Peter 2:2 NIV

Let’s face it. We don’t always feel like reading the Bible. It’s all well and good to be told to ‘crave pure spiritual milk’ like that, but craving isn’t a choice, is it? Not exactly. But you can choose to make it a daily practice, steering yourself towards a place where it’ll happen naturally. Scripture mentions the need to get rid of ‘all malice and all deceit, hypocrisy, envy, and slander of every kind’ (1 Peter 2:1 NIV) before craving spiritual milk. It makes it seem like Peter thinks that it’s not possible to get to a place of true, honest desperation for Godly growth whilst having a heart full of hateful emotion. Hmm, curious that… Also, 1 Peter 2:3 NIV explains that craving good God–things comes from having ‘tasted that the Lord is good.’ You have to ‘taste’ your Bible (read it a bit) and notice the positive effects, before you can start to crave it regularly. The first step towards that is to commit to a routine. To make the decision to read a bit of your Bible every day. The second step is to actually do it. Even when you really don’t want to. Especially when you really don’t want to. And if you miss a day or two (or a week), pick it up again anyway from that day. Keep going. Then, maybe after a while, you’ll find that it becomes a part of your day that you look forward to. Get started then! Plan exactly when you’ll spend that time today, then actually do it. SoulFood will help you start.



SoulFood: Col 3-4; Philemon; Luke 21:1-11; Ps 78:9-16; Pro 23:22-25

content.title: The Word, For You, Today (4) -- Lifestyle Origami
content.introtext:
'...You received His message... And this word continues to work in you who believe.' 1 Thessalonians 2:13 NLT

So, after taking yesterday’s advice onboard—what then? What do we do with the Bible that we read? Let’s look at 1 Thessalonians 2:13–14. It explains a sort of folding–out effect from getting close to God’s words—starting with hearing or reading them, and ending in living them out. Thessalonians 2:13 lays out the in–between steps that makes living the Bible possible. And they’re pretty interesting: (1) ‘You received the word of God…’ —That’s the reading, the listening. There’s no way around it. Read your Bible. (2) ‘You accepted it not as a human word, but as… the Word of God.’ —This is about recognising the value and authority of those words of God. It’s so important to remember the Bible is a Spirit–infused letter, full of God’s authority and knowledge. (3) ‘Which is indeed at work in you who believe’ —All of that Spirit, authority and knowledge of God that’s in the Bible… well, it’s ‘at work in you who believe.’ If you read God’s words and acknowledge the power of them, that power starts to work as part of your life. Then, after the reading, the accepting, and the having–it–work–in–you, comes the action. And it comes very naturally. Once you’re changed on the inside, the choice to ‘live it out’ should be an easy one. You’ll learn the best way to act from your Bible (Jesus is a good example for that), and find yourself more ready to follow it.



SoulFood: Neh 1-4; Luke 21:12-24; Ps 78:17-31; Pro 23:26-28

content.title: The Word, For You, Today (5) -- The Letter of the Law
content.introtext:
'Your promises have been thoroughly tested, and Your servant loves them.' Psalm 119:140 NIV

Psalm 119 is kinda incredible. It’s a really impressive acrostic poem (remember them? They’re the ones where the first letter of each line spells out a word or name) and it constantly refers back to the words of God. Every single thing that this Psalm says about God, or asks of Him, comes back to the Torah (the old Hebrew word for teaching or direction. It comes from an archery term and the idea behind it is instruction on how to hit a bullseye every time). It’s veeeeerrrryyy obvious this poet was extremely focused on it; he’s clearly read it a lot and constantly comes back to it. All of the stuff the poet knows about who God is circles back around to his knowledge of the Torah. There’s something we could (and should) learn from this. In 2014, Christians always seem to stress the relationship with God as the important thing. And that’s true. But, over the centuries, it’s possible we’ve lost touch with the fact some of that relationship is built through following the Bible’s instruction. We can get to know so much about God’s personality through the pointers He gives us in His Word on how to live. When we really get to grips with how to live as God wants, we automatically get to know Him better. Psalm 119 demonstrates it. When we read the Bible in a way that changes us and our actions, we open ourselves to being pulled a whole lot closer to Him. So, if you don’t already, why not dedicate a day a week to God as a ‘Sabbath’ holy day? Decide to rest, to make real time to dig into His written word (start with Exodus 20:8–11), and serve Him through serving those around you.



SoulFood: Neh 5-7; Luke 21:25-38; Ps 78:32-39; Pro 23:29-35

content.title: Jesus the Mediator
content.introtext:
'There is one...mediator between God and men...Jesus.' 1 Timothy 2:5 KJV

You’re a professional bricklayer. We all are. We spend our days adding bricks to the wall that separates us from God. Most Christians call that wall ‘sin’. Call it what you will, it’s built to separate us from any sort of relationship with God–the–Father. And sin would’ve gotten away with it, if it wasn’t for Jesus. He came, He gave Himself up, and He tore down all the walls we ever built (and ever will build) between us and the love of God. That’s what 1 Timothy 2:5 means—that Jesus is the one who stands alongside humankind and God–the–Father at the same time. He communicates across the gap between us and God, and makes things right—He even prays on our behalf (see John 17 for details). When Jesus said, ‘No one comes to the Father except through Me’ (John 14:6 NIV), that’s exactly what He meant. No one can kneel, stand, sing, whisper, cry or anything before God if they don’t go to and through Jesus first. He fought and died for our right to be on good terms with God. And that’s the absolutely vital importance of Jesus in Christianity. If it wasn’t for the Master–Plan of His sacrifice, we’d have no place before God. We’d have no Heaven to look forwards to. Instead we’d have, well, nothing but outer darkness for company. Practical exercise: grab a scrap of paper. Write down the name of a particular sin you feel is really hard to shake off at the moment. Read your Bible. Pray that God will remove that sin away from your life through the power of His Son Jesus.



SoulFood: Heb 11:23-28; Exo 3; Exo 33:7-23; Exo 34:29-35

content.title: Pardon True
content.introtext:
'...The Lord forgave you, so you must forgive others.' Colossians 3:13 NLT

It’s fair (and right) to work through feelings of hurt, not deny them. But, forgiveness still has to happen. Have a look back at yesterday’s reading. Jesus stepped in to fix things between us and God. This hurt Them—the Father and Jesus both. It hurt Jesus in the shape of metal nails, whip–lashes, spears and a crown of thorns. And it came with its own soundtrack of the careless laughter of His enemies, alongside the heartbroken cries of His family. But He embraced the experience, full of forgiveness. Jesus shows there is a healthy way to get over hurt. Forgiveness is not about staying the victim, but about taking control through loving–but–strong action. He did it so we could be let off for all of the wrong things we still do. Wow. That’s inspiration enough to forgive the people who’ve acted really terribly towards us. Still, it doesn’t actually make it much easier to do. (And sometimes there need to be other steps first—like letting people know if you’ve been seriously hurt and it’s been kept secret.) But it provides the reason to. And, incidentally, the whole amazing plan of the Cross provides a bridge back to God as well as access to His power. And if anything can help you to forgive, it’s God’s power. Just ask Him.



SoulFood: Neh 8-10; Luke 22:1-13; Ps 78:40-55; Pro 24:1-4

content.title: Knock Knock
content.introtext:
'Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you.' Matthew 7:7 NKJ

In Matthew 11:5–8, it tells the story of some guy who knocks on his neighbour’s door in the middle of the night to ask to borrow some bread. The neighbour mutters to himself, rolls over, grumbles, rolls over some more and finally, because he can’t stand the guy’s continual knocking, opens up and gives the guy what he wants. All because he wouldn’t stop knocking. You see, God admires persistence. It’s not that He wants us to be rude, He wants us to know what love He has for us. He invites us to ask for what we need so that we will experience that love. He makes it pretty clear—‘Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you.’ (Matthew 7:7 NKJ) If you want to hear from God, start up the conversation. Ask Him to speak. Don’t shout out from a distance, go right up to the door of His Word and knock. Steadily. He’s already on the other side of the door, waiting to answer. But don’t hightail it outta there as soon as you’ve pressed the buzzer once. Stay there, and make sure you’re ready for His response. It’s no good asking anything of God if you don’t make space and silence to hear back. Stay parked at the door of His Word, reading it carefully and you’ll find what you truly seek.



SoulFood: Neh 11-13; Luke 22:14-23; Ps 78:56-64; Pro 24:5-10

content.title: Crossing Paths
content.introtext:
'...By love serve one another.' Galatians 5:13 KJV

To work for God properly we have to have the right people around us, giving us the necessary pointers, handing us the necessary materials or just cheering us on when we need it. And God makes sure that happens. Whatever He’s planning for you, He’ll first drop you in exactly the right situation to make it happen just how He wants. That means He’ll steer you into the right place, at the right time, with the right group of people around you. That’s pretty good of Him, huh? All of the people around you are there because God wants them to be. Seriously. If you carry the person of Jesus in you (like… by being a Christian) then God will be arranging appointments for you. He’ll put people in your path. And they might just be the key to His next step for you, whether that’s by developing some part of your character, or by sending an opportunity your way. So take your relationships to God, the good along with the bad, and ask Him for the strength and maturity to recognise God–given people and opportunities. And make sure to be patient with every single person in your life. Extend grace to them constantly. Who knows what role they may end up playing in the future? And lastly, pray for those around you. Whenever you get the chance.



SoulFood: Micah 1-4; Luke 22:24-38; Ps 78:65-72; Pro 24:11-14

content.title: An Active Good
content.introtext:
'We know that all things work together for good...' Romans 8:28 NKJ

It’s a danger to stop Romans 8:28 right after the word ‘good’ as lots of people do. We miss some critical information that way. This verse packs a real punch. It calls for active life–changing. Take a moment to read it again, slowly, out loud. ‘And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love Him, who have been called according to His purpose.’ (Romans 8:28 NIV) Try the same with John 14:21 NIV: ‘Whoever has My commands and keeps them is the one who loves Me. The one who loves Me will be loved by My Father, and I too will love them and show Myself to them.’ So, those who obey God love Him. And those who do that have everything in their lives sewn together for their good. If we want the ‘all things working together for good’ bonus, we’re called to live like God wants. We have to actually love God in our actions and thoughts, not just sing it in songs and tell Him in prayers every now and then. Re–reading Romans 8:28 with that thought in mind feels a little punchier. It’s no longer just something encouraging to say when someone’s had a bad day. It becomes a call to act in the way that Jesus teaches us to, in order to have a really good life.



SoulFood: Micah 5-7; Luke 22:39-53; Ps 24; Pro 24:15-18

content.title: Jesus-Like (1) -- Humility
content.introtext:
'Your attitude should be the same as that of Christ Jesus.' Philippians 2:5 NIV

Think about all the rights we have enshrined in Australian law. The right to education, free speech and communication, to live free of all sorts of discrimination. But, sometimes, we can cling to our ‘rights’ until our fingers turn blue and we’re kicking and climbing on others to keep hold of what we think we’re entitled to. That isn’t Jesus–like. Think about it. Then check out Philippians 2:1–11. That’s right. Jesus ‘...did not think that being equal with God was something to be used for His own benefit... He gave up His place with God and made Himself nothing.’ (Philippians 2:7 NCV) He took on the status of a slave. A slave. The King of the universe didn’t see Himself as too entitled to anything to step right down onto this messy, ignorant earth. And He didn’t step down onto a comfy, shiny, golden throne; He placed Himself in a rough old animal trough. More than that—He died the death of a criminal. He definitely didn’t deserve that. And that’s our example to follow. If stuff that we don’t deserve comes our way (and it will, at some point), Jesus shows us that it’s our job to deal with it gracefully. We’re called to find the balance between living healthy lives for ourselves, and putting others (appropriately) first. Tricky, but it’s definitely do–able. That’s the way that Jesus lives. 



SoulFood: 2 Tim 1-4; Luke 22:54-62; Ps 19; Pro 24:19-22

content.title: Jesus-Like (2) - On Offer Live like Jesus.
content.introtext:
'Grace and peace be yours in abundance through the knowledge of God and of Jesus our Lord.' 2 Peter 1:2 NIV

You’ve heard it. You probably aim to do it. Why, though? To show your friends what Christianity should look like? To make the world a better place? To please God? They’re all good reasons, and they all happen, in their own way, when our lives start to look more like that of Jesus. But God has a far more personal reason to ask us to imitate His Son. You see, the request for us to ‘live like Christ’ is an offer, not just a command. After He’s set you free from sin (and only after that), God offers a new way of life, filled with ‘grace and peace’. The fact of the matter is this: living that new, Jesus–style life is exactly what we were built for. So once we start allowing ourselves to act like God wants, we start to look like the person He designed us to be. That’s when that ‘grace and peace’ come into play. Making the decision to delve as deeply as you can into Jesus’ life, and putting what you learn into practice, won’t lead you any way other than towards God. And, the closer you get to God, the more you’re surrounded by His ‘grace and peace’. So, when He asks you to live like Jesus, what’s He’s saying is ‘come closer to Me, and life will start to feel as it should.’ And that is the ultimate offer of all time.



SoulFood: Zech 1-4; Luke 22:63-71; Ps 3; Pro 24:23-25

content.title: Jesus-Like (3) -- Give It Heart
content.introtext:
'...Leaving you an example, that you should follow in His steps.' 1 Peter 2:21 NIV

Jesus’ heart is geared towards others. He loves us, and He loves God. Everything about Him is built on His own relationship with His Father and the Holy Spirit, which is, safe to say, entirely perfect. He’s also intent on bringing us imperfect humans into that relationship. So, obviously, Jesus is pretty plugged in to the Holy Spirit and God–the–Father. Jesus’ first recorded sermon starts: ‘The Spirit of the Lord is upon Me…’ (Luke 4:18 NAS), and He went off alone to talk to His Father heaps of times throughout the Gospels. He’s so in tune and in love with the Spirit and the Father that they’re a constant feature of His words and actions. That’s a great model to live by. The way that God works (the Jesus–Spirit–Father bond) is the best model of living in relationship that you could wish for. It’s worth spending some time having a look into how Jesus lives it out in the Gospels. That others–focused heart is one of the foundation–bricks of knowing how to live like Him. If we’re raring to love and serve God and, by extension, the people He’s created, then being Jesus–like becomes more of a natural leaning. If you think you’re ready, pray to God that He will make your heart more like Jesus’. Ask Him to prompt you throughout the day to act in a Jesus–like way towards others.



SoulFood: 1 Ki 17:1-6; 1 Ki 18:16-39; 1 Ki 19:9-18; 2 Ki 2:1-12

content.title: Jesus-Like (4) -- Except Not, Though.
content.introtext:
'...Take the yoke I give you. Put it on your shoulders and learn from Me...' Matthew 11:29 CEV

Have the last three days got you worried? Does the challenge to ‘live like Jesus’ sound too much? Stop, and maybe even write this down somewhere. The first call of Christianity is not ‘Live Like Jesus’. The first call is: ‘Come Home, All Is Forgiven.’ The call to live like Jesus is for after that. It’s for after you’ve come home, after you’ve been picked up and held safe by the Father of the universe. So if you’re worried that you’re not thinking, or acting, like Jesus, don’t panic your way out of His arms. From inside those arms you can watch His heart and thoughts close up. It’s only once you’re home that you can see how the Son deals with problems. Sure, we really want you to live like Jesus. (Fact is, we really want us all to live like Jesus...) Imagine what the world would be like if we all did. But if we allow ourselves to slip into thinking, ‘If I don’t live like Jesus... am I really a Christian?...’ we’ve allowed ourselves to swallow the secret lie that it depended on us being holy enough, or doing enough ‘things’ as a Jesus–copy. That’s not what the Cross was for. Living like Jesus is something that God grows (and not overnight) in the lives of those who have been called to Him whilst they were still dirty, tired, and broken. The only thing that every single one of us needs to ‘do’ is receive the love of His Father. The rest comes from there.



SoulFood: Zech 5-8; Luke 23:1-12; Ps 39; Pro 24:26-28

content.title: A Regular Chill
content.introtext:
'...Let's go off by ourselves to a quiet place and rest awhile...' Mark 6:31 NLT

In today’s verse, we notice Jesus telling His disciples He wanted a decent bit of quiet time. Did He get it? Well, no. Not right then. They went off to find that ‘quiet place’ and got followed by crowds. Instead of a chilled Jesus–and–His–pals time, a little thing we’ve come to call the ‘Feeding of the Five Thousand’ happened. Not that relaxing at all. As soon as that amazing miracle was done, Jesus ‘went up on a mountainside to pray.’ (Mark 6:46 NIV) Just like the rest of us, Jesus needed time out. He had a busy, busy, busy life but He never allowed Himself to be overwhelmed by His work. When things were too hectic, He took Himself off, normally up a mountain, and spent a while away from everything. Just Him and God. Now, even though we don’t have crowds chasing us around, our lives can feel (nearly) as hectic as that of Jesus. And, just like His, our planned time off can be sniped far too easily, either by work or by that super–active eager friend. It’s so important to step back every now and then, sometimes to just do nothing (yes, that really is ok sometimes), as well as having those times to spend with God. So, pick a day. A whole day. Schedule it in as a day for nothing but rest, relaxation and time with God. Plan to do something you enjoy. And stick to it. Put it on your calendar now. Maybe even think about making that a regular thing… Yes! Actually have a Sabbath?!



SoulFood: Zech 9-11; Luke 23:13-25; Ps 34; Pro 24:29-31

content.title: Go, Fish
content.introtext:
'...All...were astonished at the catch of fish...' Luke 5:9 NIV

Jesus never trained as a fisherman; His trade was carpentry. Yet, in Luke chapter five, He gave fishing advice to professional fish–catcher Simon and his partners. Simon had worked all night and seemed to have decided to follow Jesus’ advice more to humour Him than anything else. Despite showing more than a hint of doubt, he still did what Jesus said. He didn’t say, ‘Look, buddy, I’m the professional here. It’s not the right time to fish.’ He simply said, ‘Because You say so.’ It works exactly the same for us. Whatever our specialist area is, God knows what we need to do to max–out our potential in it. And He’s ready to share that know–how. The problem is, we often assume we know best. Or that God isn’t particularly interested telling us how to be the best essay–writer ever, or most–efficient barista ever to have worked the coffee bar. But if God’s placed you in a role, He’s the best person to advise you on it. Just ask Him. Don’t let doubt stop you from saying, as Simon did, ‘Because You say so.’ Taking God’s advice in the everyday can often be more important than it seems. Simon did what Jesus suggested concerning his fishing–job. Then, as soon as that was done, he found himself moving on to being a ‘fisher of men’. God’s current plans and instructions may be preparation for, or a sign of, bigger plans to follow. So, take Him up on His advice, and see what happens.



SoulFood: Zech 12-14; Luke 23:26-34; Ps 52; Pro 24:32-34

content.title: Weighty Words
content.introtext:
'...God...calls things that are not as though they were.' Romans 4:17 NIV

Umm, stop a second. Just think about that verse. God ‘calls into being things that were not.’ God speaks, and things that didn’t exist suddenly… do. That’s huge in two ways. First, only God has that power. The Bible definitely doesn’t say we call into being things that were not. It doesn’t say your parents or friends call into being things that were not. At the end of the day, no matter what effect we feel people’s words have on us, they don’t actually change anything. Just because someone you thought was your friend called you an idiot, doesn’t make it true. If your parents tell you you’re going to be a doctor, it doesn’t automatically mean it’s going to happen. On the flipside, it means that whatever God says is absolutely 100% true. Whatever He speaks comes into being. If He says you’re going to be a doctor, you will. And by Him saying it, it becomes a thing. A real–life, living–breathing, guaranteed thing. You need to have faith like Abraham and be “fully convinced that God [is] able to do what he [has] promised.” (Romans 4:21 ESV). We’ve pointed out God’s promises and declarations for you lots of times before. (If you missed them, then Romans 8:1 & Romans 8:31 should get you started.) Forget what anyone else has said. The only important thing is what God has said.

content.title: Don't Let Rejection Put You Off
content.introtext:
'...His own received Him not.' John 1:11 KJV

We all come up against rejection. Jesus had a lot of it. ‘He came to that which was His own, but His own did not receive Him.’ (John 1:11 NIV) There are two examples of ‘His own’ here: His very own created universe, belonging to Him. And ‘His own’ did not receive Him; this means His people—those whom He chose and loved as His own didn’t want to be seen near Him. Ow. They even accused Him of being fake (check out Matthew 12:24, for instance.) When God gives you a passion for something, when you’re dead set on making a positive change, then it’s usually not a dead–end (unless you’re ignoring God–honouring motives and into something a bit reckless or stupid—worth asking your church leader if you want a double–check!) Jesus didn’t let one person’s voice silence Him, He simply moved on and took His life–giving message to whoever would listen: ‘...to those who believed in His name, He gave the right to become children of God.’ (John 1:12 KJV) So, what matters most, rejection or reaction? Whenever you feel put down by someone’s dismissal of you, going back to God first is your best bet. Don’t go into a knee–jerk defence, ask your heavenly Father to defend you. 



SoulFood: 1 Cor 1-3; Luke 23:35-43; Ps 54; Pro 25:1-3

content.title: Treasured
content.introtext:
'Where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.' Matthew 6:21 NIV

Ever been to a pawnshop? The idea is simple; if you need money, you take a valuable item like jewellery or a musical instrument to the shop where the pawnbroker checks out the quality of it and gives you cash in exchange. But if you don’t return within the specified time to redeem the item, you lose ownership. Although it was yours originally, you no longer have legal possession till you buy it back. And if you wait too long, it can be lost forever. Have you ever thought of yourself as somebody who needs to be redeemed, so you can be returned to your rightful owner? God created us to enjoy a relationship with Him. But sin caused us to fall into ‘the snare of the devil...held captive...to do his will.’ (2 Timothy 2:26 NAS) Restoration to God, your rightful owner, could only come through redemption. And that’s exactly what God did! ‘For God so loved the world, that He gave His only Son, that whoever believes in Him should not perish but have eternal life.’ (John 3:16 ESV) Christ’s death was the price of your redemption; that’s how much God values you! But redemption only becomes a reality when you realise you’re a sinner, and trust Christ as your Saviour. The moment you do, He reunites you with God—ransomed, redeemed, restored to your original owner. So the question is: have you taken up His offer of salvation, the one that makes you a member of His family? If you’re able to read this, it’s not too late. You can do it right now wherever you are. (If you’re a little hazy on what to pray, check out the inside back cover of this devotional for some help.)



SoulFood: 1 Cor 4-6; Luke 23:44-56; Ps 13; Pro 25:4-8
