content.title: Pray As You Can, Not As You Can't
content.introtext: 'You will seek Me and find Me when you seek Me with all your heart.' Jeremiah 29:13 NIV
content.fulltext:
When it comes to prayer, God isn't moved by the quality or the quantity of your words. He's moved by a heart that spills the burdens of the day across the altar, exposing every worry to His power. Your confidence in prayer is not based on your 'can' - on your ability to speak, for instance, but rather on God's 'can' - His ability to hear and understand. He knows what you are trying to say.

The old hymn goes: 'In seasons of distress and grief, my soul has often found relief. And oft escaped the tempter's snare, by thy return, sweet hour of prayer.' If you want that sort of comfort and control over yourself, give your 'distress and grief' up to God. Because whatever you give to God, He handles. What you keep, you burn yourself out trying to handle.

Prayer gives you back the strength, energy to cope and right focus that everyday life takes away. When you pray, you're saying, 'Lord, I believe You're more competent to deal with this than I am, and I trust You to do it.' God will intervene on your behalf, just stay committed to Him. 'Commit your way to the Lord, trust also in Him, and He shall bring it to pass.' (Psalm 37:5 NKJ)

Today step outside of routine, of the unhelpful bits of 'religion' that hold you back from naturally spending time with God. 'Pray as you can, not as you can't.'



SoulFood: Judg 12-15, Mk 9:1-13, Ps 97, Prov 13:9-10

content.title: Hedges and Fences
content.introtext: 'You have beset me and shut me in - behind and before, and You have laid Your hand upon me.' Psalm 139:5 AMP
content.fulltext:
Today's verse makes it sound like God is hemming us in, locking us off, sealing us tight away from the world. One of the more literal Bible versions even says that God is 'besieging' us!

Can that be right? Hmmm... yes. That is just what He's doing. There are two parts to this verse, and it's best really to hear them both as one. When we make a commitment not to sin, when we repent and say, 'God, I reject evil and choose your path,' we begin an agreement with Him. For the rest of our lives (for better or worse, richer or poorer, and so on...) His part of the agreement is to help us fight off sin and lift us up to live a better life. He's going to help us bat away wrong thoughts. He's going to give us a way of escape when temptation hits (so there's no excuse ever for saying, 'I couldn't help myself.') He's going to put safeguards around us.

This doesn't mean it's going to be a cruise. It's going to be tough sometimes. If we start down a route with dodgy thoughts or actions that He won't like - too right He's going to put up fences to shut us off. It is never to oppress us or abuse us - only ever for our good and for our proper freedom. Of course we can still ignore the fences but, if we're wise, we'll thank Him for them.

The Hand that holds you up is the same Hand that keeps you out of destruction's path - be careful when you teeter on its edge and don't ignore the prompt to head away from danger.



SoulFood: Judg 16:1-19:15, Mk 9:14-29, Ps 47, Prov 13:11-12

content.title: Storm Shelter (1)
content.introtext: '...When a storm strikes...God will keep safe all who obey Him.' Proverbs 10:25 CEV
content.fulltext:
God doesn't lie to us. God doesn't pretend that we're never going to have trouble in our life. In fact He even uses the word 'when', not 'if': 'When a storm strikes...' (Proverbs 10:25), 'When you meet trials of various kinds...' (James 1:2 ESV), 'When we run into problems and trials...' (Romans 5:3 NLT)

That might not sound like much comfort to you.

But coming right up behind it is some good news. God doesn't lie about Himself either. 'The name of the Lord is a fortified tower; the righteous run to it and are safe.' (Proverbs 18:10 NIV) God's 'name' speaks of His character, His reliability and His faithfulness. People without God are forced to be their own god (and that's a pretty terrifying thought, on many levels), relying on their own strength and wingspan to get them through life's turbulence. Those who love God can say, 'God is...always ready to help in times of trouble. And so, we won't be afraid! Let the earth tremble and the mountains tumble into the deepest sea. Let the ocean roar and...its raging waves shake the mountains.' (Psalm 46:1-3 CEV)

If God won't lie about who He is (a safe place to hide), then He definitely isn't going to hold back who He is (YOUR safe place to hide) when you need Him.



SoulFood: Gal 5:23, 1 Jn 2:15-17, Prov 29:18, Gen 39:1-23

content.title: Storm Shelter (2)
content.introtext: 'You have been...a shelter from the storm...' Isaiah 25:4 NIV
content.fulltext:
Christianity isn't just for sunny days. In fact, your faith shines all the brighter in the middle of a storm. God is like a rock-hard barrier; He's tougher than the storms that surround you. God's Word tells us in Psalm 18:2 ESV, 'The Lord is my rock and my fortress and my deliverer... in whom I take refuge...' So trust in God and His Word and you'll be able to out-weather the nastiest downpour.

Look at Job. He went through the wildest storms, and his only conversation with God kept him standing. He said: '...I have treasured the words of His mouth more than my necessary food' (Job 23:12 NKJ), which quite conveniently brings us onto the topic of fasting.

Food-fasting is a biggie of an issue, and we're not going there today. However, fasting means much more than the odd dinnerless day. The history of the word shows that it really comes from 'to hold yourself in firm control', 'to hold fast' - an ability that we can gain by fasting from habits and activities just as much from fasting from food.

Scrolling down our newsfeeds whilst instagramming our breakfast can become just as 'necessary' to our lives as eating that breakfast (bringing to mind the age-old question: if you didn't Instagram it, did you really eat it?)

Challenge: wouldn't that Facebooking-Tweeting-Instagramming-time be better spent checking-in with God and building self-discipline? Here's a fast of a different kind: Log out of all your social media accounts. Stay logged out for a day, a week, or even a month. Whenever you crave logging back in, use the time to pray. A social media fast may be just the thing to storm-proof yourself in prayer.



SoulFood: Judg 19:16-21:25, Mk 9:30-37, Ps 45, Prov 13:13-16

content.title: Storm Shelter (3)
content.introtext: 'I am with you and will watch over you wherever you go...' Genesis 28:15 NIV
content.fulltext:
No matter how bad we feel, God is the great redeemer. Being overly self-focused on our mistakes can be our greatest weakness; a flaw in our make-up that sends us tripping up over our every self-doubt.

Maybe you've felt it on your worst days: a string of nervy thoughts that keep you looking inward. 'Oh, what have I done wrong now...?'

But the court's adjourned, God's judgment has come in. Paul the apostle wrote: 'I care very little if I am judged by you or by any human court; indeed, I do not even judge myself. My conscience is clear, but that does not make me innocent. It is the Lord who judges me.' (1 Corinthians 4: 3-4 NIV)

In Jesus we are seen as though we have His total spotlessness, God's judgment on us is, 'These are all good. I've got them. I'm for them.'

Paul knew it, so he didn't even judge himself when he messed up.

That doesn't mean ignoring our problems, or that there won't be consequences if we're constantly acting out a sin we know we shouldn't. But when we make mistakes and start a little internal storm, feel deserted by others or judged by them, we can say with Paul that '... the Lord stood with me and gave me strength ... All glory to God forever and ever!' (2 Timothy 4:18 NLT)



SoulFood: Gal 1-3, Mk 9:38-50, Ps 128, Prov 13:17-19

content.title: Worship and Worry
content.introtext: '...Let him...rely upon his God.' Isaiah 50:10 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Nobody likes to feel burdened by others, but check this out - God actually wants to be burdened by you. 'Give your burdens to the Lord, and He will take care of you. He will not permit the godly to slip and fall.' (Psalm 55:22 NLT) We need to use one of our biggest assets: worship. Whatever the situation, make the stone-cold rock-hard choice to rejoice and be glad. Choose to worship God, who has given you the ultimate Guide (to life, the universe and everything) that will help you through your day. 'Do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God.' (Philippians 4:6 NIV)

Practical tip: Music as a form of worship can really help with squashing worry (BTW: Did you know there's far more to worship music than secular music... but let's discuss that another day...) One of the best ways to get to know another country's language is to learn songs in that language (think primary school Italian or Mandarin.) It's the same with learning not to worry. If you fill your head with songs that focus on Godly values, you'll learn His language of comfort and freedom. Not in a metaphorical way, but in a literal mind-renewing kind of way. It's worth having a favourite worship song on standby in your brain, for every time you start to feel majorly anxious. Even repeating it silently to yourself in your mind can help to bring calm.



SoulFood: Gal 4-6, Mk 10:1-12, Ps 101, Prov 13:20-23

content.title: God at the Top and the Bottom
content.introtext: '...Underneath are the everlasting arms.' Deuteronomy 33:27 NKJ
content.fulltext:
'Mountaintop moments.'

Perhaps you've heard the phrase? Maybe you've even experienced them yourself - those epiphany moments when everything makes sense; when God feels close and your destiny seems clear. The Bible gives us plenty of evidence that God does spectacular things for His people on mountaintops. On Mount Moriah, He met with Abraham and Isaac. On Mount Horeb, He spoke to Moses through a burning bush. On Mount Sinai, He gave the Ten Commandments. On Mount Carmel, He sent down fire from heaven.

But after one such mountaintop experience, Moses showed the people that God isn't only to be found when you're feeling 'on top of the world'. Addressing the nation of Israel for the last time, Moses told them, 'There is no one like the God of Israel. He rides across the Heavens to help you... The eternal God is your refuge, and His everlasting arms are under you...' (Deuteronomy 33:26-27 NLT)

God's presence is always there for you when you look down. No matter how steep the valley you have to walk, no matter how sharp the descent, God's presence is deeper. Underneath you are His everlasting arms. The truth is: He's not just Lord at the top, He's also Lord at the bottom.



SoulFood Ascension Day: Lk 24:50-53, Acts 1:1-11, Eph 4:7-10

content.title: Good vs 'Good'
content.introtext: '...As we have opportunity, let us do good to all...' Galatians 6:10 NIV
content.fulltext:
'Do not forget to do good and to share...' (Hebrews 13:16 NLT) So what does 'doing good' mean, in these verses? A little giving to charity or a bit of schoolyard-style swap: 'You can have a piece of my chewing gum because you gave me a crisp yesterday'? There's that. Those things are ok, but not as the upper limits of what it means to 'do good to all.' It's easy giving when people give to you and taking when other people take. Then there's the life of Jesus - what we're called to be like. We must, often, choose between the world's 'good' and God's good (this choice happens everyday, not just in Sunday school lessons...) Francis of Assisi summed up what he thought living out God's 'good' looked like, in this prayer:

Lord, make me an instrument of your peace,

Where there is hatred, let me sow love;

Where there is injury, pardon;

Where there is doubt, faith;

Where there is despair, hope;

Where there is darkness, light;

Where there is sadness, joy.

It's different. It's difficult. But with God's life in you, you start to realise, and let out, your natural compassionate side. Living it out is when you are most truly yourself.



SoulFood: Lam 1:1-3:39, Mk 10:13-22, Ps 108, Prov 13:24-25

content.title: I'm Not Ashamed (1)
content.introtext: 'They looked to Him and were radiant, and their faces were not ashamed.' Psalm 34:5 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Not ashamed. As a follower of Christ, that should be your testimony. Because you have placed your trust in Him you are able to say, 'I am not ashamed' of:

(1) His birth. Mary was His mother, but God was His Father. So He had no inherited sin or practised sin, so He met all of God's requirements to be our Saviour.

(2) His miracles. He never demanded money in exchange for a miracle. Not one supernatural act was performed for selfish or showy purposes, but only to meet people's needs.

(3) His preaching. Even His enemies had to admit, '...No man ever spoke like this Man!' (John 7:46 NKJ) His words transform us.

(4) His claims. He said, '...He who has seen Me has seen the Father...' (John 14:9 NKJ) You see who God is by looking at Jesus Christ.

(5) His death. He bore your shame. You were morally and spiritually bankrupt. But He satisfied all of God's claims against you at the cross, writing 'Paid in full' across your account.

(6) His resurrection. His promise is, '...Because I live, you will live also.' (John 14:19 NKJ)

(7) His mediator-ship. Picture this: when you fail, He stands before God on your behalf, offering His blood as atonement for your sin. If you saw Him now would you say, 'I am not ashamed of Jesus'?



SoulFood: Lam 3:40-5:22, Mk 10:23-34, Ps 113, Prov 14:1-4

content.title: I'm Not Ashamed (2)
content.introtext: 'I am not ashamed of the Gospel...' Romans 1:16 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Not ashamed. 'I am not ashamed of the Gospel, because it is the power of God for the salvation of everyone who believes...' (Romans 1:16 NKJ) Huge, right? Paul had a massive reputation for being a religious fanatic. But, you know what, he didn't let that stop him being true to what he believed. More than that, it didn't stop him stamping his foot and shouting out loud, 'I am not ashamed.'

He stuck with his faith in God, and his calling to share the Gospel, without even slightly diminishing in his enthusiasm. If anything, the insults made that fire burn brighter.

And that's a good lesson to learn. No matter how you share your faith, you'll probably come up against someone who calls you a fanatic at some point. The only thing to do in that situation is to own it. Step up and say, 'Yeah, I'm a Christian. And "I am not ashamed" of it.'

Also, take a sec to think about the last bit of that verse. 'The Gospel... is the power of God for the salvation of everyone who believes.' Well, that's too massive a thing to allow your own shyness to get in the way.

There is no room to be ashamed when people's very souls are on the line. Shout out for the sake of the Kingdom.



SoulFood: Mt 5:3, Lk 18:9-14, Is 57:14-21, 2 Sam 7:18-29

content.title: I'm Not Ashamed (3)
content.introtext: '...Let me not be ashamed of my hope.' Psalm 119:116 KJV
content.fulltext:
What is your big hope for the future? Do you hope to be famous one day? Or rich?

Jim Carrey said, 'I wish that everybody could get rich and famous and everything they ever dreamed of - so that they could see that's not the answer.' And he's one of Hollywood's richest and most famous actors! Fame is a hope that will ultimately disappoint. Wealth will disappoint too.

As Christians, our 'big hope' is this: 'Your Kingdom come' (Matthew 6:10) - a Kingdom where people are loved just as they are; a Kingdom where the cleaner is as honoured as the movie star; a Kingdom where the young aren't patronised and the old aren't ignored; where the grieving are comforted; where the lonely are befriended; a Kingdom where the thief and the victim are restored by justice.

God promises us that the 'big hope' of seeing that 'Kingdom come' is one that we can count on. And that, friends of word4U2day, is why we don't need to be ashamed. Our hope is absolutely assured. It's shout-it-out-without-fear-of-ever-being-wrong guaranteed. So step up and claim it.

content.title: Get-Outta-There
content.introtext:
'... He will show you a way out...' 1 Corinthians 10:13 NLT

 

Feeling lost isn’t new to the society we’re in. It’s the result of ‘doing our own thing’, which human beings have done at every point in history. Giving in to temptation ends up leaving you dejected and fed up.

But: everyone gets tempted. Others have resisted; and so can you. God, your God, will show you a way out.

Great! But what does that help look like? The first practical tip is recognising which people and situations can cause you to fail badly. Be honest.

Secondly, get–outta–there. Turn over the channel and choose not to give in to your feelings. Make a phone call. Get accountable. Pray. Whatever you do, don’t just sit there and attempt to fight it with your own willpower. Maybe turning to someone outside of yourself feels the same as giving up. But the first thing Christianity teaches us that every one of us, on our own, will fail when left to our own devices. It’s totally valid—and a much better option—to look outside yourself and turn to God, even when all you feel is the desire to sin. Look to God, because He’s bigger than our own drive to do wrong. Turn to friends who you trust and who love you and will stand with you.

And, when you see one of these exit routes, take it. Ways out can be here one second and gone the next. Don’t miss out on stepping out of temptation, and into God’s better life. Telling another person you’re struggling with something can be hard, but worth its weight in gold (Check out James 5:16!) Pray for courage, and then make the move to connect.



SoulFood: Jer 25-27, Matt 25:14-23, Ps 31, Pro 8:34-36

content.title: Guiding Light
content.introtext:
'... Let your light shine...' Matthew 5:16 NIV

 

Whether you know it or not, you’re being watched. Not by a hidden camera at the bottom of your street ... but by other people. And especially by God, ‘For the eyes of the Lord range throughout the earth...’ (2 Chronicles 16:9 NIV)

Footballers, celebrities and sadly even politicians provide society with shaky role models. Even though they’re shot into the limelight, it doesn’t take much scratching to discover all sorts of not–so–glamorous history lurking beneath the surface. When things are falling apart, it’s the church’s chance to offer an alternative. So the question you need to ask is—‘what are you modelling’?

There are heaps of ways to bless people around you. Are your friends going through a tough patch? Take them out for a coffee and encourage them. Are your mates counting every cent? Give them a generous treat. Has your church leader asked you to serve tea and coffee? Go the extra mile: clean the kitchen while you’re at it. Darkness might be all around but your good deeds can penetrate any gloom. A little love goes a long way, ‘For all creation is waiting eagerly for that future day when God will reveal who His children really are.’ (Romans 8:19 NLT)

So if your light is fading away tonight, it’s time to ask Jesus to help you discover how to let it shine more brightly for Him.



SoulFood: Jer 28-30, Matt 25:24-30, Ps 72:1-11, Pro 9:1-6

content.title: Suffering in Style
content.introtext:
'You've been given... the privilege of suffering for Him.' Philippians 1:29 NLT

It may not be the kind of message that will see your non–church mates sprinting into a Sunday service, but Jesus never hid uncomfortable truth. ‘Taking up your cross’ wasn’t just poetic language. It meant something very visible for the people of the early church, and they knew it wasn’t nice.

It was this kind of preaching that made the disciples question Jesus’ choice of message, but He didn’t shy away from it. The Bible seems to ask the impossible when it tells us to think of times of suffering as opportunities for punching the air in joy. It seems to have a different outcome in mind to the rest of us; ‘When your faith is tested, your endurance has a chance to grow… When your endurance is fully developed, you will be perfect and complete, needing nothing.’ (James 1:3 NLT) We want to be happy. But God wants us to see things from His point of view, leading to holiness. Then, our happiness isn’t based on shaky foundations.

As Dr Robert Pickles said: ‘Joy depends on Jesus, happiness depends on happenings.’

The secret? He saw things from God’s point of view, not his own. He had God’s perspective, right priorities and knew the best source of Power. How’re you doing today? Take a look at whether you’re chasing ‘happiness’ or ‘joy’. Is contentment in your life dependent on happiness or Jesus?

content.title: Noise Pollution
content.introtext:
'Then Moses said to the Lord...' Exodus 33:12 NKJ

Sound is important to our daily lives. But noise isn’t. Noise is classically defined as ‘unwanted sound’, and it’s a bigger problem today than ever before. How do we filter out the unwanted and keep the wanted? Maybe it’s the same with our Christian faith. Never before have we had as many resources, sermons, podcasts, e–books etc. How do we decide which to listen to or read? Even word4U2day is a daily choice in all these resources.

But does this make it easier? Not necessarily. With all this noise, God’s voice can be even harder to hear. Track back to Paul’s day and there was a similar problem: ‘Even though you have ten thousand guardians in Christ, you do not have many fathers, for in Christ Jesus I became your father through the Gospel.’ (1 Corinthians 4:15 NIV) There were lots of people with helpful advice, but few people to be a ‘spiritual father’ (the type of really wise, holy individual who’d devote themselves to your growth). Track back another couple of thousand years and even Job had his own form of noise pollution: the world–famous ‘Job’s comforters’. It seemed like they were saying the right thing—after all, they loved Job. But in the end, they turned out to be just a bunch of nosey, noisy neighbours.

Learning to hear God’s voice above all the others is vital. It takes dedication and practice to listen for Him, but (obviously), it’s the most worthwhile Voice you’ll ever hear. So if you feel you’re in a one–sided relationship, where God never speaks to you, talk to a Christian you reckon can help and ask how you can change that. It’s so worth it.



SoulFood: Jer 33:1-36:26, Matt 26:1-13, Ps 32, Pro 9:10-16

content.title: Growth in Tough Times (1)
content.introtext:
'... but be of good cheer, I have overcome the world.' John 16:33 NKJ

The Bible is surprisingly full of people having really tough times. It seems that after thousands of years of getting to know God, mankind still hasn’t been able to get its collective head around our good, loving God allowing us to face ‘times of trial’. It’s a tough question in theory, but it’s much harder again when you’re living the tough times in reality. Bad things happening in life is a sad reality of living in a fallen world.

Not–so–‘news’–flash: following Jesus is not a ticket for a life free from pain. Jesus wasn’t lying when He said, ‘Here on earth you will have many trials and sorrows.’ (John 16:33 NLT) But He doesn’t stop there. He goes on to say, ‘But take heart, because I have overcome the world.’ This is the good news in a nutshell. Not only did God so love the world that He gave us Jesus, but we can overcome trials and sorrows with Him. It’s all to do with how you respond. Apparently, if you break a bone in your leg, the bone will actually heal stronger than it ever was originally; the break will heal, then another layer of bone will grow over the area, reinforcing it. That’s cool. For our hearts, being broken could be the start of finding your strength in God.



SoulFood: Gal 5:22, 2 Pet 3:3-15, Matt 5:39, 1 Sam 25:1-42

content.title: Growth in Tough Times (2)
content.introtext:
'... God intended it all for good...' Genesis 50:20 NLT

 

Sometimes bad things happen even to those we’d call ‘good people’. Knowing a Sovereign God who could command a whole legion of angels to meet your every whim, but for some reason doesn’t, might be frustrating at times. So why doesn’t God sort out all our problems? It’s not that God isn’t bothered by your pain. A big part of the reason is that God wants to bring us closer to Himself. He wants us to have good qualities that reflect Him; He wants character, perseverance and hope.

Instead of gift–wrapping those qualities and handing them to us on a plate, He puts us in situations where we have to develop them. Those situations are not usually ‘fun’. God’s using your exact situation to discipline you: to disciple you. ‘No discipline is enjoyable while it is happening—it’s painful! But afterward there will be a peaceful harvest of right living for those who are trained in this way.’ (Hebrews 12:11 NLT)

When you pray for blessings, you might be thinking of achievements, money, or that special someone stepping right into your life. But there’s more to be gained in this life than those things: God sees the bigger picture of your character development. The Beatitudes in Matthew 5 give an alternative definition of ‘blessed’. Special mentions go to the poor in spirit and the persecuted. When we do eventually leave this life, and meet God face to face, what will we actually get to take with us?

content.title: Growth in Tough Times (3)
content.introtext:
'...My grace is sufficient for you...' 2 Corinthians 12:9 NKJ

 

The story of Joseph (you know, the guy with the rainbow–coloured dreamcoat) is a classic. But what makes the story worthy of being made into a musical production that played on New York’s Broadway and London’s West End theatres? Maybe it’s because the hero doesn’t sail into his destiny without a bumpy ride along the way. Kidnapping, enforced slavery, false accusations and prison all spring up as road–blocks in the life of the man who had been promised greatness. Circumstances went from bad to worse, then to worse still, as he rode his personal ancient–Egyptian rollercoaster. But there was one key recurring truth: ‘The Lord was with Joseph.’ (Genesis 39:2 NIV)

Joseph might have wanted things simple and easy. He might have revelled in watching his brothers bow down to him in awe—without any of the hard stuff on the way. But God had a bigger plan for him, one that focused on Joseph becoming the man God wanted him to be: someone capable of leading a nation. He wouldn’t have been that way without the challenges. He also wouldn’t have had the opportunity to experience God’s presence along the way. Over the thirteen years of suffering, God was growing Joseph. He was teaching Him a spiritual paradox that says it’s when you’re weak that you can fully allow God to be God. As God said to Paul, ‘My grace is all you need. My power works best in weakness.’ (2 Corinthians 12:9 NLT)  So don’t pray for tasks that match your gifting, but for gifting that will match your tasks.



SoulFood: Jer 41-44, Matt 26:26-46, Ps 25:8-15, Pro 10:1-3

content.title: Tune In
content.introtext:
'They nominated... Barsabbas...and Matthias.' Acts 1:23 NLT

 

The early Church was full on, packed with faithful disciples, ready to lay down their lives for God! They were totally in tune with God, right? Right! (Well, one or two exceptions—but even they were examples for the rest.)

But yet, despite being ‘in tune’ with Him, God was unpredictable. His Holy Spirit ‘blows wherever it pleases’ (John 3:8). Which means even your pastor or minister or chaplain hasn’t got Him figured out! You see, sometimes, we might go the way we think right, but God will steer us somewhere else.

Case study. The disciples weren’t sure what to do. Judas was gone; the team of apostles was a man short. A quick replacement was in order, so ‘Barsabbas and Matthias’ were nominated (two leadership hotshots). To decide who’d get the role, they use an ancient method of voting. As a result, Matthias got chosen. Who was he? Um, no idea (he’s never mentioned again)! But Barsabbas, the man who didn’t win the vote, went on to be a pioneer in teaching.

Did the disciples get it wrong? Was Matthias the right man for the job? Whether they got it right or wrong actually isn’t so important. Matthias might have gone on to do great, unrecorded, things. What matters is the fact they were seeking Him, and God honours that. Are you after God? Whether or not you hear His voice or feel His nudge, you’ll still see His Lordship. So write down three things you’d like God to change in you. Pray about them, and look back in a couple of months to see how He’s answered! (It might not be the way you expected, but that doesn’t matter!)



SoulFood: Jer 45-48, Matt 26:47-56, Ps 25:16-22, Pro 10:4-7

content.title: Rock-Solid Relationships
content.introtext:
'Blessed are the poor in spirit...' Matthew 5:3 NIV

 

Ok, sometimes our relationships aren’t perfect. We’re definitely not just talking about that guy/girl you like, your parents, or your friends or class/work–mates. We’re talking about anyone who has an influence in your life. What can we do to build good relationships: how can we be totally sure others can confidently build trust and ‘Do Life’ with us?

A clash of personalities or testing circumstances can seem to put real strain on relationships. Although we’re talking about a broad range of people you know today, we think Jesus covered a lot of ground with the ‘Beatitudes’. If you aren’t familiar with them, have a read of Matthew 5.

How about four key points to blessed relationships? (1) Be humble. Self–promoting and always demanding your rights brings misery, while humility, self–denial and considering others’ needs bring happiness. (2) Be meek (restraining your power). Maybe even hold back those harsh words that contain a bit of truth? (3) Be merciful. You know when you’ve been hurt and left out? Don’t seek revenge from that. Instead, contribute to an atmosphere of forgiveness. (4) Be a peacemaker. During the week, if your brilliantly–genius ideas get ignored, don’t sweat. The ability to let go of our pride and not ‘win’ approval decreases the chance of conflict. Jesus was pretty good at that sort of stuff, being God and all. There’s definitely some stuff we can apply here to make the most of our time with others. Is there something you need to let go of in a relationship? Holding grudges is a killer—face up to the challenge of making peace today.

content.title: Tough Job
content.introtext:
'I know that my Redeemer lives...' Job 19:25 NKJ

 

Boils, bankruptcy, bereavement. What kept Job going? Even his wife had lost faith, ‘Are you still holding on to your integrity? Curse God and die!’ (Job 2:9 NIV) Yes, he was holding on. Job demonstrates a grit, determination and trust in God unparalleled in the rest of the Old Testament.

Was Job cold–hearted to be able to struggle on when his family were killed? Not a bit (flip to Job 1:20). Instead, Job knew that God was good, faithful and powerful. And even if he didn’t know exactly what was going on, no worldly thing was going to distract him from that, even when his world was crumbling down around him.

‘I came naked from my mother’s womb, and I will be naked when I leave. The Lord gave me what I had, and the Lord has taken it away. Praise the name of the Lord!’ (Job 1:21 NLT)  Now that’s real God–perspective.

Praising God when the sun’s shining is ok, but choosing to do it when your world is falling apart demonstrates Job–like trust. Even when it looked like God had walked away, gone on holiday and turned off the phone, Job chose God, ‘For I know that my Redeemer lives, and He shall stand at last on the earth; and after my skin is destroyed, this I know,that in my flesh I shall see God…’ (Job 19:25–26 NKJ) Job didn’t have a fake smile fixed to his face but, deep in his heart, he chose to trust God.

 Thousands of years later, that Redeemer was born and His name was (and is) Jesus. What about you? Do you know Jesus as your Redeemer yet? Turn to the inside back cover to find out more.



SoulFood: Jer 51-52, Matt 26:69-75, Ps 50:16-23, Pro 10:11-13

content.title: Death Defeated
content.introtext:
'I will see God.' Job 19:26 NIV

 

Death is a fact of life. Your attitude towards it, however, is where your Christian faith could come into its own. When you fully understand that this life is not all there is, you’re free from the fear of whether or not there’s an ‘afterlife’.

Peter describes the Christians he’s writing to as ‘temporary residents and foreigners.’ (1 Peter 2:11 NLT) He was reminding them that they didn’t really belong to this world anyway. Their real home was with God. No matter what it says on your passport, your true citizenship is Heaven. That means our loyalty should be to God’s truth, His way of life and to His people. That should put your hissy fit about not being able to watch the TV programme you want into perspective. When you put ‘set apart–ness’ (or ‘consecration’) into practice, you probably will feel like an alien in a foreign land. ‘Not fitting in’ is par for the course if you want to be a true disciple.

But death isn’t the end of the matter. Christ offers us eternal never–ending life. ‘Death is swallowed up in victory. O death, where is your victory? O death where is your sting?’ (1 Corinthians 15:54–55 NLT) Jesus won the biggest battle ever waged because He took your place for you to win eternal life for you. That’s worth living, and dying, for. Check out the whole of 1 Corinthians 15 to get a fuller idea of what the Bible says about death and resurrection. Be encouraged!



SoulFood: Joel 1-3, Matt 27:1-10, Ps 56, Pro 10:14-16

content.title: Marked Out
content.introtext:
'...Well informed, quick to understand... qualified to serve...' Daniel 1:4 NIV

 

We all want to be a good witness. Or at least, we should want to be. You’ll probably have opportunities to share your faith with people at school or uni or work or anywhere else you find yourself. But what better way to shine than by the example you set? Aiming to be the best for others speaks a thousand words. It shows your faith has meaning and that you’ve got deep roots.

Daniel was the kind of person who had made up his mind not to conform to the pattern of the world around him, but to be changed by the renewing of his mind to discern God’s will for him (check out Romans 12:2). God favoured him, and was working on his behalf, but Daniel had to play his part too.

In a strange new place, he worked hard to adapt to a new culture. Culture alone wasn’t the enemy; his first battleground was compromise. He didn’t use his God–given commission as an excuse to not put any work in. He was polite, determined and steadfast in doing right. Daniel knew who he was, because he understood Whose he was.

More tests came along Daniel’s path (including his friends being thrown into a fiery furnace and some hungry lions), but his faithfulness in the small decisions prepared him for the life–changing stories that we read about today. Hard work is worth it. Give some thought to this question: has there been any unhealthy compromise in your life recently? How can you change this?

content.title: Unforgiven
content.introtext:
'We love because He first loved us.' 1 John 4:19 NIV

 

Richard Wurmbrand was kidnapped, imprisoned and tortured for 14 years under Communist Romanian rule. He tells a story about the torture of a fellow Christian: ‘A minister I had heard of in Romania had been horribly beaten and was thrown back into the cell with the other prisoners. He was half–dead, with blood streaming from his face and body. As some of the prisoners washed him, others cursed the communists. Groaning, the minister said, “Please, don’t curse them! Keep silent! I wish to pray for them.”‘

Those who tortured the minister had not asked for forgiveness. Nor had they shown remorse. And they would continue to beat him the next day. Yet the minister summoned up the ability to pray for them. He asked God to bless rather than curse his enemies.

It’s one thing to agree with Jesus’ teachings; it is another to carry them out whilst blood seeps from your head. So maybe you’ve not been physically tortured, but perhaps emotionally you have. Maybe your heart feels black and blue. Maybe the last thing you want to do is pray rather than curse. Ask God for the courage to love your enemies—if you hate them, they have already defeated you.

This doesn’t mean, by the way, that if someone is hurting you, it’s ok to let it keep happening. Forgiveness isn’t about putting yourself in harm’s way. Talk to someone about the problem and get help.

content.title: Forgiveness: How?
content.introtext:
'... Forgiving each other, just as... God forgave you.' Ephesians 4:32 NIV

 

Forgiving isn’t easy. It takes hard work, and determination, and the bigger the wound, the harder it is to forgive. So how about some practical ‘How–To–Forgive’ tips to help you?

(1) Deciding to ‘re–forgive’ every time old thoughts of unforgiveness pop into your head. It’s a question of your will deciding to forgive, and forgive and forgive. Ask yourself if you have really forgiven them? Ask God to help you with those difficult memories, and decide to make peace with them until you feel the Holy Spirit doing its work in your heart. (2) Release poisoned relationships—if you break free of a situation, keep a watch for people trying to drag you back. They may not even realise they’re doing it, but it’ll block your moving on. (3) Don’t be discouraged that it’s not instantly fixed. Just as your salvation was immediate but you have to walk out your sanctification, so the release of your forgiveness is immediate but you have to walk out your healing. (4) Living free from the burden of resentment and the toxicity of unforgiveness is a choice followed by a series of choices. It’s a step–by–step thing, but with every step, it gets easier, and your feet get lighter.

Finally, ‘It is for freedom that Christ has set us free…’ (Galatians 5:1 NIV) God is in the business of freedom, and when you free someone or something that’s been a burden on you, the freedom you receive from Him for yourself overflows. So take whatever hurtful situation springs to mind as you pray today and use these tips to walk out your release.

content.title: Vice President of the Universe
content.introtext:
'Do you see a man skilled in his work? He will serve before kings...' Proverbs 22:29 NIV

 

Irritating, isn’t it? Clearly you’ve got the voice that should be heard by millions on iTunes, and yet nobody has given you the opportunity. Or maybe you look at the stars of the screen and know you could do a better job if opportunity would throw you a lucky break. And maybe, just maybe, you’ve snored your way through one too many Sunday sermons, so you just know you could lead this church better than the current guy does.

So why are you Billy Nobody when you could clearly run the world far more effectively given the chance? Why isn’t God promoting you to Vice President of the Universe? Could the answer lie in the Luke 16:10? ‘If you are faithful in little things, you will be faithful in large ones...’ In other words, ‘you’ve got to start somewhere!’

So before you lead millions in worship on CD, think about singing honestly to God alone in your bedroom. Or joining the choir. Before you start planning to lead a world–renowned church, try volunteering to clean your current church toilets. If you are faithful with a toilet brush now, you might just be faithful serving a large church in the future. In God’s eyes, it’s not about glam jobs, only faithful servants.

Meditate on Colossians 3:17—‘Whatever you do or say, do it as a representative of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks through Him to God the Father.’

Now, about those church toilets...

content.title: Approach with Confidence
content.introtext:
'...The curtain of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom...' Matthew 27:51 NIV

 

Brief history lesson: Long ago there was a time when the high priest would go through the temple curtain to enter the ‘Holy of Holies’ (where God’s presence was) once a year. Once. And the only thing that qualified him to be there was the blood of a sacrificed lamb—nobody can physically come before God by themselves without purification. The blood was placed above the Ark of the Covenant. What’s that? Well, it contained God’s perfect standards, the ten commandments (and yes, we’ve all broken them). Now fast–forward to the moment when Jesus died on the cross. The blood of the ‘lamb’ was shed again, for us. The Bible states that the temple curtain, separating man from God, was torn in two (Matthew 27:51). And this is nothing less than wonderful news for us: when we reach out for God, when we seek God with honest hearts, He will reach back for us.

Which means that factually, without a doubt, no matter how you’re feeling today, you can ‘come boldly to the throne of our gracious God.’ (Hebrews 4:16 NLT) Even if you feel undeserving (and we all are), it doesn’t affect how much God longs for you to reach for Him. God doesn’t reside behind a curtain, He’s in us. HINT: ‘Your body is a temple.’ (1 Corinthians 6:19) So come boldly to the throne and ask God for what’s on your heart.

content.title: Never. Too. Late.
content.introtext:
'..."Lord, remember me when You come into Your Kingdom."...Jesus said... "Today you will be with Me in Paradise."' Luke 23:42-43 NKJ

 

‘Good Friday’ always seems a strange way to refer to Jesus’ death. The ‘Good’ part is what Jesus dying on a cross achieves: that, through faith in Jesus anybody—absolutely anybody—can stand before Father God and be declared righteous. All because Jesus gave His life for you.

So, to take a closer look at that today, we’re looking at the criminal on the next cross over. What better demonstration of God’s grace to us as undeserving humanity than seeing a guy who actually deserved his punishment being told he’ll be in Heaven with Jesus later that day? No action required. Not even a weeping confession. Just this: recognition of who Jesus was, and one request: ‘...remember me?’

Here’s why this is important to you: are you like that guy on the cross, all hope gone, and somehow deserving what you got? Turn your head to the side and look at Jesus taking everything you deserve. He’s offering you paradise.

Or do you know someone that’s ‘too far gone’ to ever be saved? The criminal was, literally, at the end of his life. He was a thief who’d made some ‘not exactly wise’ decisions and, if he had any friends or rellys who cared about what happened to him, you’d have understood if they’d given up hope... and yet... ‘...remember me?’

It’s not too late. For you, or someone you’re praying for. Keep praying. In fact, pray today as you read through the Gospel story of Jesus’ crucifixion (John 17–19), remembering what He has done to make it possible for you to be part of God’s family.



SoulFood Good Friday: Gen 22:1-18, Mt 27:33-56, Ps 22, Is 53

content.title: The Cross: Shame
content.introtext:
'...like a lamb to the slaughter...' Isaiah 53:7 NIV

 

Did you hear about the guy who had to get up and dance in his job interview? It’s not the start of a joke, it’s a true story. Last year, an electronics store actually made applicants dance for each other as part of their interviews for sales jobs. ‘I just felt so embarrassed and uncomfortable,’ said Alan, one of the job hopefuls. ‘I ended up dancing and doing rubbish robotics in my suit in front of a group of strangers.’ Ouch.
Poor Alan experienced the way shame makes us feel: alone, exposed, powerless. He said he felt like a fool and wished the ground would swallow him up. Who would willingly choose to feel shame in that way? Who, if they had the power, wouldn’t say ‘Stop! Enough!’?
Jesus, that’s who. Isaiah writes, ‘He was led like a lamb to the slaughter, and…he did not open his mouth.’ On the cross, in the face of all that shame, of brutal torture and gut–wrenching anguish, Jesus could have defended Himself. He could have appealed to legions of angels to rescue Him. All it would have taken was a word. But He chose not to. He instead chose to empty Himself of His power (Philippians 2:7-8) to fulfil the perfect plans of His Father. He did it for you.
So, take some time now to thank Jesus for His willingness to humble himself so that we could know freedom. What does His example mean for you in your life?



SoulFood: Acts 8-9, Mt 27:57-66, Ps 130, Prov 10:24-26

content.title: The Cross: Victory
content.introtext:
'...He made a public spectacle of them...' Colossians 2:15 NIV

 

Can you imagine the victory laps Satan and his cronies were doing the day Jesus was crucified? They really thought that they had wrecked the greatest mission in history. They were convinced they had snuffed out the salvation plan of the Father. Lying in a cold dark tomb was their evidence—God’s only Son, broken, bruised, beaten.

But the deceiver was deceived. As Philip Yancey writes in The Jesus I Never Knew, ‘In the most ironic twist of all history, what Satan meant for evil, God meant for good. Jesus’ death bridged the gap between a perfect God and a fatally–flawed humanity. On Good Friday God defeated sin, routed death, triumphed over Satan, and got His family back… He took the worst deed of history and turned it into the greatest victory… Between the cross and the empty tomb hovers the promise of history: hope for the world, and hope for each of us who lives in it.’

At the cross, Paul writes in Colossians 2, Jesus cancelled the record of wrongs against us, nailing them up. And He disarmed the devil and all the spiritual rulers and authorities at his command, nailing them down. He comprehensively triumphed over Satan. So, as you celebrate with God’s people today, keep Jesus’ victory over your sin and over Satan at the front of your mind.



SoulFood Easter Sunday: 1 Cor 15, Mt 28:1-10, Lk 24:1-12

content.title: Get Wise (1)
content.introtext:
'And at midnight a cry was heard...' Matthew 25:6 NKJ

Jesus told a parable (that you might find isn’t mentioned all too often) about some bridesmaids waiting for the groom to arrive.

Five of them were wise, and five of them were foolish. Having a burning lamp was a requirement for taking part in the wedding feast in those days, yet the foolish bridesmaids didn’t have enough oil, so they tried to grab some from the wise ones. They replied ‘‘We don’t have enough for all of us... buy some for yourselves’ (v9). So the foolish bridesmaids had to trot off for oil. But while they were gone, the wedding got underway and the door was locked and bolted.

Here’s four lessons from the foolish bridesmaids: (1) It’s wrong to depend on others. The fact your mum and dad / church family are Christians won’t on its own make you a believer. You need to seek God for yourself. (2) It’s stoopid to be last–minute about important things. Are you putting off saying a full ‘yes’ to Jesus until you’re a bit older or you know more? (3) God’s judgment is final. ‘..the door was shut… “Open the door for us!” But He replied, “I tell you the truth, I don’t know you.”’ (Matthew 25:10–12 NIV) (4) Morality alone won’t get you into Heaven. ‘God saved you by His grace when you believed. And you can’t take credit for this; it is a gift from God.’ (Ephesians 2:8 NLT) Being generally nice unfortunately doesn’t make up for the wrong we’ve done; Jesus does. Are you fully trusting in God, or is your oil half–empty?... Meaning: are you not fully committed? Are you like someone trying to walk around with your feet pointing in different directions? See how easy it is (not!) and ask yourself, ‘Do I need to sort out my relationship with God?

content.title: Get Wise (2)
content.introtext:
'While the bridegroom was delayed, they all slumbered...' Matthew 25:5 NKJ

 

Let’s look a bit more into the story that Jesus told about the wise and foolish bridesmaids. In verse 5 it says this, ‘The bridegroom was a long time in coming, and they all became drowsy and fell asleep.’ So we’re all on the same page, the bridegroom in this story represents Jesus. Your average wedding service tends to involve us waiting anxiously for the bride to walk down the aisle, yet here, the bride (representing the true church) is waiting for the groom. Jesus, the person we’ve been waiting for, whom we depend on, is coming soon (Romans 13:11), yet we’re fast asleep.

What do you think Jesus is getting at here? In 1 Thessalonians 5:6–8 it says, ‘...let us not be like others, who are asleep, but let us be awake and sober... putting on faith and love.’ Are we preparing ourselves, actively seeking God on earth, or chasing after what will ultimately not count for much? (The answer’s probably found in the way you spend your time).

‘At midnight a cry was heard: Behold, the bridegroom is coming; go out to meet him!’ (Matthew 25:6 NKJ) Midnight? Eh? There’s no time God excludes (or is excluded from). Seeking after Him needs to be a whole–of–life endeavour—there’s never a ‘time–out’. So get wise today! Wake up and be prepared for Jesus by tucking into His Word.



SoulFood: Acts 12-13, Mk 1:1-13, Ps 103:13-22, Prov 10:30-32

content.title: Samson vs Joseph (Round I)
content.introtext:
'These things happened to them as examples...for us...' 1 Corinthians 10:11 NIV

 

Over the next two days we’re comparing and contrasting two Bible characters, with a view to draw out some juicy wisdom. First, Mr. Samson. He was the product of a miracle (see Judges 13), brought up by godly parents and most famous for his supernatural strength. If he was the beefy, all–round superman of a guy that we often see depicted, he’d probably be all over your Twitter feed (#strongmansamson). Yet he ended up failing miserably (see Judges 16). Why? He didn’t pray. Most of the time, he relied on his own strength and wisdom rather than God’s. The only time there’s a mention about Samson praying was when he was in trouble. Ring a bell? We can’t be surprised if we live according to our will only, then wonder why we’re in a mess!

There’s another big decision–making lesson we can learn from him. Rather than being led by God’s Word, he was led by his feelings to marry the wrong woman, who eventually betrayed him. Being led by your emotions before checking in with God might feel ‘right’ for a short while, but never turns out too well. Samson sought revenge, but Joseph prayed for those who hurt him. He was motivated by greed, whereas Joseph worked hard.

Why mention these things? If it can happen to Samson, it can happen to us! Samson’s story is a good pointer to keep our God–given strengths in check... and check–in with God instead. What do people say you’re good at? Today make time to thank God for that, and devote it to glorifying Him.



SoulFood: Acts 14-15, Mk 1:14-22, Ps 16, Prov 11:1-2

content.title: Samson vs Joseph (Round II)
content.introtext:
'These things happened to them as examples...for us...' 1 Corinthians 10:11 NIV

 

In brief, Joseph had his head screwed on. He wasn’t perfect, but we can certainly learn from the way he dealt with misfortune and rejection (compared to Samson’s set up in life), temptation (compared to Samson’s head–firstness), and his attitude.

If you’re at all familiar with their stories, you’ll have noticed that Samson had everything going for him, while Joseph... well, didn’t. He didn’t get off to a great start; his brothers didn’t like the favour God had for him at all and they sold him into slavery. But Joseph forgave them (that’s massive), acted in faith that God was with him (Flashback to April 15) and ended up helping his family out big time during famine.

He also resisted temptation; turning down a married woman multiple times. He lived with determination to stay on track with God (Genesis 39:9). Yet it was because of this rejection that the married woman falsely accused him—and it was this that landed him in prison... where he became one of the leaders! (God was with this boy).

Comparison time: Samson has a position of authority... Joseph ends up in prison. Samson goes for the girl his lust tells him to (and it ends badly)... Joseph resists temptation, and through his hard–times never turns his back on God... Who had it planned for Joseph to end up as Prime Minister. Samson lived out of his own strength, turning to God when times got hard. Joseph lived, trusting in God despite his situations, with massively different results. The Joseph story (Genesis 37–46) is about staying true. What can you learn from how he responded to tough–times?



SoulFood: Acts 16-17, Mk 1:23-34, Ps 7:1-9, Prov 11:3-6

content.title: Praying When You Don't Want To
content.introtext:
'...Father...Take this cup away from Me...' Mark 14:36 NKJ

 

 

How do we pray when we don’t feel in any way holy? Nobody feels incredibly devout 24/7. Motivation is important—we can’t always ride off the back of a wave of intense spiritual emotion. Sometimes, it’s clear and sunny outside, and you know you still have to fit in your morning’s fifteen minutes with God. Sometimes, the last thing you’ll want to do is listen to your depressed friend and quietly ask God to help them (while you could be happily zoning out to your favourite playlist.)

CS Lewis said, ‘I must say my prayers today whether I feel devout or not; but that is only as I must learn my grammar if I am ever to read the poets.’ Yeah, poetry was the thing that got Lewis’s tastebuds tingling, but feel free to replace that with your own activity of choice... The point is that the ‘drudge’ of learning grammar (or lifting weights, or learning guitar chords) changes you. Not just in patience. You grow closer to an experience that is beyond flat, normal, just-getting-by human life. You start to change inside. This is especially true with prayer. Even when it looks like practice, speaking words to an empty room, you will be opening your life to God. And God, because He is good, will come along and meet you, because you have tried. Maybe you’re thinking: ‘Don’t believe the hype.’ Well, the core of prayer is very exciting—conversation with the Creator!—but in reality it doesn’t always feel like a life–changing experience. That’s ok. What’s your usual prayer routine? Go do that, even if it feels quiet. Don’t have one? Have a look at Greg Laurie’s Becoming a Person of Prayer at ucbdirect.com.au

 



SoulFood ANZAC Day: Acts 18-19, Mk 1:35-45, Ps 7:10-17, Prov 11:7-9

content.title: Mirror, Mirror
content.introtext:
'Does the clay dispute with the one who shapes it, saying, 'Stop, You're doing it wrong!' Isaiah 45:9 NLT

 

Ok, sensitive topic time. We don’t always exactly enjoy what we see in the mirror. Let’s face it, despite anything we might be taught in church about self–acceptance, it’s not easy to suddenly appreciate all your God–given features. Whatever you’ve inherited, there are some spiritual truths worth your time: (1) Truly resenting your looks puts you at odds with God the Creator. The Bible says, ‘You have no right to argue with your Creator. You are…a clay pot shaped by a potter. The clay doesn’t ask, “Why did you make me this way?”’ (Isaiah 45:9 NIV) God intends us to carry His presence, as clay containers. We’re not designed to just be a fancy ornament on display.

(2) Comparing your outtakes to someone’s highlight reel will never give you a true perspective on...well… humankind. Just look to the famous people who seem to be dropping like flies; we ALL desperately need God to truly live. And, although it can be hard, let’s make sure that our conception of a ‘good’ appearance isn’t decided by what we see on our screens and billboards. An airbrushed model isn’t a role model. ‘…They are only comparing themselves with each other, using themselves as the standard of measurement. How ignorant!’ (2 Corinthians 10:12 NLT) Be careful.

So, if we aren’t to compare ourselves to others, what option is left? Only one—God! ‘…look only to Jesus, the One who began our faith and who makes it perfect…’ (Hebrews 12:2 NCV) When we’re focussed on Him, the rat–race for popularity and good image will grow ‘strangely dim in the light of His glory and grace’.

content.title: Make Something Wonderful Of It All
content.introtext:
'...Make every minute count.' Ephesians 5:16 CEV

 

The Bible tells us that there is a ‘time for everything.’ (Ecclesiastes 1:3 NCV) What are you going to do with the time given to you?

In the third stage of its life, a caterpillar forms a chrysalis and, inside, mushes all its body parts into gross bug goo (yeah, don’t google ‘inside a chrysalis’...) When it’s strong enough, it pushes its way out of the shell as a butterfly and uses its wings for the first time. Rush this process, try to help the butterfly out by opening the chrysalis early, and you’ll be releasing an underdeveloped bug hybrid with teeny wings. Also you’ll be killing its chances of surviving out in the wild.

We must be wise with our time. It’s tempting to take shortcuts even when you sense a chance to grow, but rather than try to rush through everything, play the long game. Put the slow work into character–forming and you’ll make something great out of your life. All of the ingredients we get in our life are given to us by Him. Some learning experiences we choose, and others, both good and bad, are thrust upon us. The story of who you are is written in your scars as well as your good experiences. They’re not coincidences. God is crafting and making you and building into you the ability to fly. So don’t shrink back into the goo, make something wonderful out of it all. Yes, God has ‘...made everything beautiful in its time.’ (Ecclesiastes 1:9 NLT) Think: have you even considered this might already be you?



SoulFood: Acts 22-23, Mk 2:13-22, Ps 144:9-15, Prov 11:12-13

content.title: War of Words
content.introtext:
'The tongue that brings healing is a tree of life, but a deceitful tongue crushes the spirit.' Proverbs 15:4 NIV

 

We each say around ten thousand words every single day. Give or take. Words that can cheer up and bless, or divide and put down. They can start wars or heal hearts. Just look at soap operas, where many of the plots are based around the loving or wounding words of broken humanity. Chances are, of those ten thousand words you speak each day, one or two may not be very well thought through. At least.

The Bible says, ‘If you claim to be religious but don’t control your tongue, you are fooling yourself, and your religion is worthless.’ (James 1:26 NLT) Oops. So, how can you get a bit more control over your mouth?

(1) Encourage: Encouragers are God’s frontline against lies of the enemy which rid others of hope and joy. Use your words to lift the mood. (2) Ask for wisdom: ‘Take control of what I say, O Lord, and guard my lips.’ (Psalm 141:3 NLT) Be quick to listen and slow to speak, asking God to guide you when choosing your words—including those you speak about yourself. (3) Speak truth and life: Jesus is ‘...the way, the truth and the life.’ (John 14:6 NLT) As His family and followers, our speech should reflect this. Talk truthfully and you’ll speak words which, like a ‘...life–giving fountain’ (Proverbs 13:14 NLT), point others to God.



SoulFood: Acts 24-26, Mk 2:23-28, Ps 94:1-11, Prov 11:14-15

content.title: Restor(e our N)ation
content.introtext:
'...He sought his God... And so he prospered.' 2 Chronicles 31:21 NIV

About 61% of Aussies claimed to be ‘Christian’ on the last census. But you wouldn’t know it by the number of people in church of a Sunday. Australians are also, according to a recent Credit Suisse Global Wealth report, the richest people on earth. How long can God’s favour last? It’s just like how things were in ancient Israel in Hezekiah’s time. In spite of all God’s blessings, many of the people there had turned their backs on Him. So as believers, how can we play our part in restoring God’s values in times like these? In Old Testament times, King Hezekiah set his heart on restoring God to His rightful position of leadership in the land and this is what he did:

(1) He put God’s Word first (2 Chronicles 31:4 NLT);

(2) He challenged corruption (2 Chronicles 29:5 NLT);

(3) He called the people to return to the Lord (2 Chronicles 30:6 NLT) and

(4) He called people to worship God (2 Chronicles 29:28 NLT). Most importantly: ‘In everything that he undertook…he sought his God and worked wholeheartedly. And so he prospered.’ (2 Chronicles 31:21 NIV)

The result? Israel was transformed. We need to play our part. As you watch or listen to the news today, find a story that you can pray about or act on. Ask your mates to pray too and to join with you in putting God first.

content.title: Bigger on the Inside
content.introtext: 'A great...door has opened to me.' 1 Corinthians 16:9 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Paul writes, 'For a great and effective door has opened to me, and there are many adversaries.' So, what are you focusing on? The open door or the adversaries - the opportunities or the obstacles?

Story time: In 1866, a newbie geologist (a rock geek) noticed some South African children playing with a shiny rock. He asked the kids' mother if he could purchase it. Thinking it was worthless, she gave it to him. Later, when he examined it, he discovered it was a premium 21 carat diamond. When word got out, a Scottish mineralogist (a mineral geek) named James Gregory was sent to investigate. He reported back that South Africa wasn't suitable for finding diamonds. He guestimated that the previous discoveries had resulted from ostriches, of all things, eating the gems in far-away lands and plopping them in South Africa by their poop. So gross! A few days after Gregory's report was made public, an 83 carat diamond was found in the area he had visited. It is now known as The Star of South Africa, and it began the region's first mining operation in what is today the world's largest producer of diamonds.

Well, what about Gregory? His name lives on, but not as he might have wished. In the diamond industry, when someone exhibits bad judgment, it's called 'pulling a Gregory'.

So don't 'pull a Gregory'; ask the God who opens doors to how you what you need to see. Remember, if Jesus could turn water into wine and feed five thousand people with a boy's lunch, think what He can do through you. The question is: what do you see? The open door or the obstacles?



SoulFood: Deut 1-2, Mk 3:13-22, Ps 35, Prov 11:19-21

content.title: 'Measure of Faith'
content.introtext: '...God has dealt to each one a measure of faith.' Romans 12:3 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Life in late 18th century England was horrific: kids as young as five were sent to work twelve hour days in dangerous conditions; public hangings were common and the conditions of prisons were unspeakable. When the jails threatened to overflow anyway, they shipped the prisoners half way around the world to a place called... yep, Australia. And then there was slavery - hundreds of thousands of human lives traded annually for money, money, money. Shockingly, most 18th century English people thought this was all perfectly jolly (or, at least, not changeable). There were even lots of church people who believed if you were born poor or black, the gutter was your lot in life.

Why would anyone take on that mountainous mess? Especially if you were well-educated, wealthy and insulated from the world around you? Well, thankfully, somebody did. God gave William Wilberforce a 'measure of faith' that came from his deep understanding of grace. Faith that his life could count. Faith that things could change.

What this measure of faith did in Wilberforce was cause him to use what he had, in the place where he was, to change the world. Jesus said: 'I tell you the truth, if you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you can say to this mountain, "Move from here to there" and it will move. Nothing will be impossible for you.' (Matthew 17:20 NIV)

A mustard seed is a bit bigger than the size of the full-stop at the end of this sentence. Whenever you think you don't have what it takes to change a situation for good, think again. It doesn't need much when you trust in Jesus.



SoulFood: Deut 3-4, Mk 3:23-35, Ps 2, Prov 11:22-23

content.title: Choosing to Have an 'Opposite Spirit'
content.introtext: 'You do not know what manner of spirit you are of.' Luke 9:55 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Jonathan Martin wrote about a missionary friend in Palestine: 'Sister Margaret was in the crowded village market one day when an angry man accosted her. Taking out his apparent frustration at Western military interference in the region, he began cursing her. He cursed... everything he could think of. She felt the eyes of the entire village watching. As he hurled abuse at her, she quietly prayed for wisdom. When he was finally done, Margaret responded, "I am so sorry I hurt you. I never had any intention of hurting you. God loves you, and I love you. He loves this village and He wants to bless you. When you get over being angry, will you remember I'm still your friend?" Perplexed, he turned and walked away. In words that are forever etched on my soul, Margaret said, "Satan doesn't know how to respond to the gentleness of God's Spirit."'

'The Spirit of God, who raised Jesus from the dead lives in you...' (Romans 8:11 NLT) How do you live out that resurrected-difference when you're with your friends? When you get unfairly bad-mouthed? To respond in love very often means not just mimicking the way that the world reacts to things, but standing solidly and being a gentle, positive opposite.

When the rest of the world is too busy to care for individuals, do you choose to have an opposite spirit? Simple things - actually offering prayer for a friend with a headache or telling that mate who owes you ten bucks it's a gift - will set you apart.



SoulFood: Deut 5-7, Mk 4:1-12, Ps 37:1-7, Prov 11:24-26

content.title: Open Mouth. Insert Foot.
content.introtext: '...Peter...not knowing what he said.' Luke 9:33 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Ever find yourself saying the wrong thing, at just the wrong time? Never fun, is it? Peter had a tendency to spill exactly what was on his mind. This meant sometimes he was spot on with what he said and sometimes he was way off. There were occasions when physically putting his foot in his mouth would actually have been more constructive than carrying on the conversation.

In Matthew's Gospel, Jesus praised Peter and said he was blessed for recognising Him as the Messiah. Then, just a few verses on, Peter put his foot in it (again) and Jesus rebuked him with the remark, 'Get behind me, Satan!' (Matthew 16:23 NIV)

Most of us have these ups and downs, right? Striding along confidently for God one minute, then falling over our own feet the next. Well, next up in the story, God gave Peter some pretty good advice that could help us all. Jesus took Peter, James and John up the mountain to pray, and while there, the disciples saw the glory of Jesus displayed as he met with Moses and Elijah. Peter, totally stunned, spoke impulsively, comparing Jesus and the Old Testament prophets as being equals. While still mid-sentence God interrupted him, saying, 'This is my Son, whom I have chosen; listen to Him.' (Luke 9:35 NIV) They were all afraid and speechless after hearing that.

We can all use a bit of correction sometimes. To refocus and 'listen to Jesus' can be a make-or-break thing. The more you pay attention to what God has said, the less you'll say things that He wouldn't want you to say. So, if you find yourself in a situation where you think you might say something a bit brainless, take a breath, and pray for God's wisdom.



SoulFood: Gal 5:22, Lk 6:27-36, Ex 23:1-9, Rom 12:14-21

content.title: Night Terrors
content.introtext: 'They came to Him...saying, Master, master, we are perishing!' Luke 8:24 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Recognise this situation? You're lacking sleep. It's late, maybe around midnight. And your thoughts go a bit... well, dark. This is a top time for doubt (over real life issues or God's goodness or sudden fear) to come out in full force.

Does that ever happen to you? Do you ever wonder why it happens? Don't worry. You're definitely not alone. It happened to the disciples in a night-time thunderstorm. '...He got into a boat with His disciples. And He said to them, "Let us cross over to the other side of the lake." And they launched out. But as they sailed, He fell asleep. And a storm came down...and they...were in jeopardy. And they...awoke Him, saying, "Master, Master, we are perishing!"' (Luke 8:22-24 NKJ)

To the disciples, in the moment, doubt and fear felt like all there was to reality. Here's the thing though: these sorts of doubts don't sum you up and they're not the full measure of you. You can be aware of dangerous, not-from-God thoughts trying to get at you, but you don't have to be scared. 'Then [Jesus] arose and rebuked the wind and the raging of the water... But He said to them, "Where is your faith?" And they were afraid, and marvelled, saying to one another, "Who can this be? For He commands even the winds and water, and they obey Him!"'

Whatever the storms of life, Jesus can calm them. No matter how deep your doubt or your fear, turn to Him and put your trust in Him. For He is the One with the power to command even the winds of fear and the waves of doubt to obey Him.



SoulFood: Deut 8-10, Mk 4:13-25, Ps 37: 8-15, Prov 11:27-29

content.title: Reach Out in Faith!
content.introtext: '...And You say, Who touched Me?' Luke 8:45 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Jesus suddenly stops in a marketplace and says 'Who touched Me?' No one owns up. Peter, in an almost You-can't-be-serious tone, pipes up, 'Master, the people are crowding and pressing against You.' But Jesus said, 'Someone touched Me; I know that power has gone out from Me.' (Luke 8:45-46 NIV)

Jesus knew the difference between the clumsy bump of a passerby and a deliberate faith-filled grasp. Peter was led by his human senses, Jesus was led by a more supernatural sense. He knew in His spirit that someone had touched the tassels on His cloak that symbolised prayer. With that touch, someone had prayed in faith and received an answer.

Because of her illness, the woman who'd done it held back from revealing herself. She was seen as cursed by the people. Now this same woman, made whole, dropped at Jesus' feet, trembling. Because Jesus called her, she could respond.

It's vital to our growth as Christians that we start to get in touch with Jesus too. Faith draws on His power and brings results! Notice, this woman touched the 'hem' of Jesus' garment, the prayer tassels. The last thing a tailor does when making a garment is to sew up the hem. So the hem represents 'the finished work'. The same back of Jesus that bore the cross to take away your sins, also bore the stripes which take away sickness. '...And by His stripes we are healed.' (Isaiah 53:5 NKJ) What do you need today? Forgiveness of sins? Healing for your body or mind? Reach out in faith and touch Jesus, and you too will be made whole.



SoulFood: Deut 11-13, Mk 4:26-41, Ps 37:16-24, Prov 11:30-31

content.title: Forget You
content.introtext: 'A dispute arose among them as to which of them would be greatest.' Luke 9:46 NKJ
content.fulltext:
Do you remember being little and having those 'my dad's the best' arguments? Then, we got older and it stopped being about mum and dad. Instead it became all about us. We don't often say it out loud (at least not in church), but in reality, our hearts can often drift towards a judgemental, self-promoting spirit, bigging ourselves up, assuming we're better than other people. It makes us feel secure.

Good to know it's not a new thing, then. Jesus discovered His disciples were arguing about the oh-so-mature topic of... 'Who will be the greatest?' Have you noticed, a lot about 'living for God' is living in opposites? Like loving your enemies instead of hating them? Forgiving people instead of making them pay? Putting others first, rather than ourselves? Well, when Jesus had a few words with His disciples about this argument over greatness, He didn't quote a great philosopher to make His point. Instead, He pointed at a child. 'Whoever welcomes this little child in My name welcomes Me; and whoever welcomes Me welcomes the One who sent Me. For he who is least among you all-he is the greatest.' (Luke 9:48 NIV)

As long as your motive for serving is to make yourself look good, you'll never enjoy God's approval. And His 'well done' is the only thing that counts. So, if you've been bigging yourself up lately, take note of what Jesus said here and become teachable, trusting and tender-hearted, just like a young child.



SoulFood: Deut 14-17, Mk 5:1-10, Ps 37:25-31, Prov 12:1-3
